PHR: T-type calcium channels (T-channels) play an important role in controlling neuronal excitability. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Spectroscopic MRI provides increased sensitivity and specificity for detection of brain tumors relative to conventional MRI by measuring differences in metabolism between aggressive brain tumor and normal brain tissues. Our 3-site pilot study using spectroscopic MRI to guide radiation dose escalation not only demonstrated feasibility and safety, but also showed potential for significant improvement in clinical outcomes for patients diagnosed with glioblastoma (GBM). This project will increase the performance of spectroscopic MRI to improve image quality and reliability, to reduce acquisition and processing times, and will facilitate clinical adoption of this technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW HAMPSHIRE ACADEMY OF SCIENCE, INC.
PHR: Project Narrative The Learning Science Through Research program (LSTR) employs the scientific and educational resources of the New Hampshire Academy of Science (NHAS), the Fairbanks Museum and Planetarium (FMP), and Colby Sawyer College (CSC) in providing authentic STEM research experiences to students, their teachers, and prospective teachers from underserved rural communities. By fully involving parents, teachers, and students, the program will: 1) inform all parties to the broad and growing opportunities in health and science careers, 2) transform middle/high school science teachers into inspirational mentors and educational leaders, 3) enable students to carry out the practices of designing, executing and publishing scientific research, 4) enable teachers and students to access peer-to-peer support as well as the mentorship of experienced STEM professionals from regional STEM corporations to become ethical and productive scientists, and 5) advance the STEM career development of underserved students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is effective in preventing HIV infection among people who inject drugs (PWID) yet studies suggest that its use is low among this population which is particularly vulnerable to HIV infection. The criminal justice (CJ) system, at the intersection of increased risk of HIV infection and substance use, presents a unique opportunity to engage PWID in HIV prevention care that incudes PrEP. The study will characterize the facilitators and barriers to PrEP initiation, adherence and linkage to care among male PWID that are experiencing incarceration and develop the “PrEPare-for-Release” intervention to promote PrEP initiation, adherence and linkage to care upon release from incarceration into the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal is focused on understanding the molecular mechanisms regulating protein synthesis and stress response pathways and how these processes are beneficial or adverse in a given biomedical context. Specifically, we are addressing how a collection of protein kinases that phosphorylate a translation initiation factor, eIF2, recognize nutrient stresses and disruptions in protein folding and implement differential translational control that serves to repair and sustain cells. This research is important for understanding the progression of many diseases, including diabetes, obesity, and Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), with a long term goal of development of biomarkers and therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Life-saving cancer treatments can destroy the finite source of potential eggs and sex hormone-producing cells, and, therefore, ovarian tissue cryopreservation is offered to young girls as the primary fertility preservation method. Hormones and/or fertility can ultimately be restored following transplantation of cryopreserved tissue, but current methods are not suitable for those with cancer cells in the ovary, are not effective in producing children for the majority of individuals and are not long-term solutions for hormone restoration. The goal of this study is to define the microenvironment of the bank of potential eggs in order to develop an engineered ovarian transplant that restores safe, effective and long-term function for cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The Child Health Research Center Development Award (CHRCDA) Program at CNH will train the next generation of pediatrician-scientists who will perform cutting-edge basic, translational, and clinical research on issues of importance to child health and development. While there are many opportunities to use molecular biology, biomedical engineering, and translational science to advance treatment of pediatric diseases, the required technologies and techniques are complex, labor intensive and require a comprehensive understanding of the most recent scientific advances. Because the necessary research experience is often lacking among most academic pediatricians who have recently completed clinical training, the CHRCDA Program at CNH will provide 2-4 years of career development and practical experience under the direction of committed senior mentors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Plasmodium falciparum, a causative agent of human malaria, inflicts an enormous burden on global human health. Even though P. falciparum is a eukaryotic organism, there are vast differences in the mechanisms of mRNA translation and surveillance between P. falciparum and humans. This project will apply new approaches to understand better the evolution of the previously unexplored process of protein synthesis in the AT-rich genome of malaria parasites and exploit new parasite-specific drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A Non-Human Primate Model for Closed-Loop Anesthesia Delivery Narrative Closed-loop anesthesia delivery (CLAD) systems are an invaluable, but yet unrealized paradigm that can: improve second-to-second brain state monitoring of patients during general anesthesia; provide precise computer-controlled anesthetic dosing; and reduce highly prevalent anesthetic side effects such as post-operative cognitive dysfunction. By combining pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamic modeling with modern control theory and artificial intelligence approaches, we will develop a non-human primate model for design and testing of CLAD systems for two widely used anesthetics: propofol and dexmedetomidine. If successful, this research will provide a critical foundation for the eventual, widespread deployment of CLAD systems in anesthesiology and intensive care unit medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Innate immune genes are under natural selection to protect the host from pathogens, but emerging evidence suggests that at least some immune genes may also function in development and the response to stress, complicating our understanding of immune system evolution. We plan to uncover the extent of shared genetic architecture between innate immunity and development and determine its influence on the dynamics of host-parasite coevolution. Understanding evolutionary constraints on host-microbe interactions will improve predictions for pathogen evolution and ultimately shed light on the genetic basis of sepsis and other human diseases with complex genetic origins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Failure of monoclonal antibody treatments against central nervous system (CNS) metastases, which occurs for 15-40% of cancer patients, is due to their inability to enter the CNS. I propose a novel nanotechnology for effective delivery of monoclonal antibodies to the CNS, potentially enabling treatments for cancers of the CNS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transposable elements are mobile DNA sequences which spread through eukaryotic genomes, making up ~50% of the human genome. The mobilization of transposable elements is implicated in the onset and progression of many cancers, as well as age-related neurodegenerative diseases. The proposed research uses Drosophila melanogaster as a model to reveal the mechanisms and evolution of host cellular responses to transposon mobilization.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Nearly half of all patients with epilepsy have deficits in attention and executive function, with no available medical treatment. To determine efficacy of methylphenidate (MPH) for the treatment of epilepsy-related cognitive dysfunction would be of particular importance to combat Veterans and others with traumatic brain injuries (TBI), as epilepsy and neuropsychological dysfunction are among the most common sequelae of TBI. If MPH is shown to be efficacious and safe for the treatment of epilepsy-related cognitive dysfunction in a large randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled trial over an extended treatment period in patients with post- traumatic and other epilepsies, the results could guide clinical management and greatly impact daily function, quality of life, and employability in Veterans with seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Over a decade after the release of the human genome sequence, we are continuing to discover that many diseases arise from mutations in DNA regulatory regions, which “decide” specifically where and when to produce proteins in our bodies. While we have made great progress in our ability to predict where proteins will be produced, we have only recently begun to appreciate how much DNA sequence precisely dictates when production will ensue. The work proposed here seeks to reach a predictive understanding of these processes that will empower scientists and physicians to “read out” when and where cellular decisions are made from DNA sequence, just as the function of an electronic circuit can be predicted from its wiring diagram. This understanding, combined with synthetic biology, will set the stage for the predictive bioengineering of the development of multicellular organisms and future precision therapeutic tools for repairing developmental defects and halting states of unchecked cellular proliferation in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Neural circuits in the spinal cord are directly responsible for controlling movement, and damage to these circuits through neurodegenerative disorders or acute trauma can severely impair motor output. The research described in this proposal aims to significantly advance the understanding of the identity and circuitry of interneurons in the spinal motor system, which should facilitate the development of new therapeutic approaches to the treatment of developmental motor disabilities and spinal cord injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 90,000 US children, adolescents, and young adults live with a severe neurologic impairment; these children are typically marginalized and understudied, and a majority suffer from uncontrolled pain. Using a rigorous research approach, we propose to pilot test the PediQUEST ResPOND intervention, which combines the use of electronic parent reported outcome measures with integration of a specialized pediatric palliative care team to systematically address pain and distress in these underserved children and their parents that, if successful, will lead to a multisite Phase III trial. The proposal ultimately aims to improve quality of life and promote health equity and access in children with severe neurologic impairment and their parents, which is aligned with top priorities of the National Institute of Nursing Research, National Academy of Medicine, and World Health Organization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microtubule motor-based transport is essential for the clearance of phagosomes in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), a cell type that performs numerous functions essential for the health of the retina, and therefore normal vision. The proposed project will utilize advanced techniques in molecular and cell biology, in combination with state-of-the-art live-cell imaging, to investigate the role of dynein in phagosome transport, maturation, and clearance, in human RPE. This study will advance our current understanding of phagosomal transport, and the mechanisms by which microtubule motors operate to ensure the fidelity of this vital RPE function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The detailed examination of the fundamental chemistry and biological mechanism of action of natural products is critical in the development of new treatments for a variety of human ailments. This program aims to discover, develop, and apply new chemical synthesis strategies and methodologies for efficient preparation of bioactive and structurally complex natural products and designed derivatives. Whereas the immediate impact of this program is access to precious and rare samples of complex alkaloids for structure validation, collaborative biological evaluation, and mechanistic studies, the long-term and broader impact of this program is the establishment of precedence for the application of new chemistries in synthesis of other complex molecules, natural or rationally designed, with therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Childhood status epilepticus (SE) is a common life-threatening emergency, with a high risk of death and high risk of disability among survivors. This large cohort study of children with SE in northern Nigeria will determine the phenotypes of childhood SE, clinical and genomic predictors of SE resistance to specific first-line drugs (benzodiazepines), clinical and genomic predictors of SE outcome (death and disability), and clinical and genomic predictors of epilepsy among children who survive SE as their first seizure. This research may lead to a better understanding of this cause of childhood death and disability, informing future improved strategies for treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Previous studies have identified the signaling pathways that couple receptors to the translation machinery to regulate protein synthesis during long-lasting synaptic plasticity and long-term memory formation, and several of these translational control pathways are dysregulated in brain disorders including Alzheimer’s disease (AD), fragile X syndrome (FXS), and autism spectrum disorder (ASD). In this proposal we will use novel mouse lines and viruses that we have developed to determine the specific cell types in the amygdala, hippocampus, and prefrontal cortex that require de novo protein synthesis for memory consolidation, reconsolidation, and extinction, and will identify the mRNAs that are translationally regulated following learning in these cells. In addition, we will utilize ribosomal profiling, translating ribosome affinity profiling, and de novo proteomics in mouse models of FXS and AD in order to generate new therapeutic targets for these devastating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Innate immunity must be tightly controlled to fight pathogen infection as well as to prevent autoimmune disease. An RNA editing enzyme termed ADAR1 is a key regulator of innate immunity preventing the unwanted autoim- munity. To understand the molecular basis for autoimmunity and to ultimately harness this understanding for therapeutic development, we will investigate the underlying regulatory mechanisms of how ADAR1 functions along with other players at the molecular and cellular level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When a cell reproduces, the chromosomes are first duplicated and then segregated into a pair of daughter cells. The proposed studies focus on regulatory proteins that control chromosome segregation. This research will provide a better understanding of how errors in this process can result in genetic damage or defects in chromosome number, which can accelerate cancer progression or cause developmental defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite considerable progress toward global goals for ending the HIV epidemic, limited utilization of HIV services by those at highest risk continues to drive HIV transmission. In western Kenya, men who purchase sex constitute a particularly high-priority population because they face high risk of HIV infection and are inherently challenging to identify and reach with existing approaches. This project will evaluate an HIV self- testing intervention that relies on sexual networks to reach men who purchase sex and promote their utilization of essential HIV services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Male smoking prevalence in Viet Nam is one of the highest in the world (45%), and rates of tobacco use are even higher among people living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA) (59%). The goal of this proposal is to conduct a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of three multi-component interventions that are embedded in HIV outpatient clinics. The research is significant for its potential to guide large-scale adoption of promising, cost effective strategies for implementing and disseminating tobacco use treatment in HIV care settings in Viet Nam and will serve as a model for similar action in other LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: For four decades, advanced-stage empyema in adults, a disease with high rates of mortality in the elderly, has lacked diagnostic tests to advise clinical decision-making and approved non-surgical interventions. By combining novel companion diagnostic test, FPA, that predicts treatment outcomes with the delivery of low dose PAI-1- targeted fibrinolytic therapy, we will define a personalized, safe and efficient treatment for advanced-stage empyema.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Calcium influx in dendritic spines is essential for synaptic plasticity. In this project, we will investigate how ketamine influences calcium signaling in dendritic spines in the mouse frontal cortex, and whether this process contributes to the compound’s rapid antidepressant effects. The results may provide important insights into the biological basis of the action of fast-acting antidepressants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Myelinating glial cells traditionally viewed as inert “insulation” to neuronal processes, simply providing functional support, have been recently reported to respond to a variety of stimuli (i.e. social environment, gut metabolites, mechanical forces). The detection of their impaired function in a number of neurological and psychiatric conditions, even in the absence of neuronal damage, has led to new interest in understanding the biology of oligodendrocyte lineage cells and in developing myelin regenerative strategies. This proposal addresses key open questions with the potential to open new venues of regulation of the regenerative process in response to external signals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many patients with in situ breast cancers are overtreated because we cannot predict which of these cancers will progress to form dangerous invasive tumors. We will identify the molecular and physical changes to breast cancer cells that are necessary to progress to invasive disease using primary human breast tissue and genetically engineered mouse models. Successful completion of our long-term goals will decrease the fraction of women given radical treatments for low risk in situ tumors, and provide new targets for preventing the progression of these tumors to invasive disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research in Project SMART is relevant to public health because sexual and gender minority (SGM) youth are at significantly higher risks of vaping compared with non-SGM youth in the US. The study aims to develop and test the effectiveness of a culturally responsive social media campaign to prevent initiation of electronic cigarette use (or vaping) among SGM youth between the ages of 13 and 18 years and help reduce vaping-related health disparities among vulnerable populations. This proposal directly addresses key scientific priorities of RFA-DA-21-009 to test the effectiveness of interventions to prevent initiation of vaping among adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The fundamental processes of metabolism — breaking down nutrients to generate energy and using that energy to create the molecular building blocks of life — take place in a highly organized environment inside cells. In response to changes in environmental conditions many enzymes that control cellular metabolism dynamically reorganize into large assemblies that regulate and coordinate metabolic reactions. We propose to study the role of enzyme assemblies in multiple important pathways to gain insight into metabolic control, how enzyme misregulation causes disease, and how enzyme assemblies might be manipulated in new medical therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative About 5% of focal epilepsy is associated with neural autoantibodies and may respond to immune-modulating treatment, but the diagnosis of autoimmune epilepsy remains limited to neural autoantibody testing. In this proposal, we explore novel PET and MR imaging methods that can visualize and quantify microglial activation and blood brain barrier disruption in people with definite autoantibody positive autoimmune epilepsy, and clinically suspected but antibody negative focal epilepsy. These studies may improve the diagnosis of autoimmune epilepsy, explore its neuroinflammatory mechanisms, and develop more broadly applicable markers of disease that may be used in the context of treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To successfully replicate and disseminate in their hosts, viruses employ different strategies to manipulate the host immune responses. One such viral immune evasion strategy is the inhibition of host cell death. We have identified a viral inhibitor that targets a specific mammalian cell death pathway. We propose that this viral inhibitor not only inhibit host cell death, but also interferes with anti-viral inflammation. In this proposal, we will examine the molecular mechanism by which this viral inhibitor targets the host cell death machinery. Using mouse infection as model, we will also examine the effect of this viral inhibitor on anti-viral immune responses. The proposed study will reveal important knowledge on how viruses cause disease in human and shed light on new strategies to control viral diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The primary cilium is an antenna-like structure that protrudes from the cell surface. Defects in primary ciliary formation and function result in dysfunctional Hedgehog signaling, which is directly associated with human birth defects and cancers. Thus, understanding how ciliary gene mutations affect Hedgehog signaling will provide insight into the identification of potential therapeutic targets, possibly leading to the development of drugs for cilia- and Hedgehog- related human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall Project Narrative Alzheimer disease (AD) has a long asymptomatic stage in which brain changes accumulate silently before finally culminating in symptoms caused by declines in memory and thinking abilities. The Knight Alzheimer Disease Research Center will coordinate and support integrated, cutting-edge transdisciplinary research initiatives to examine the mechanisms that underlie the transition from preclinical to symptomatic AD and that enhance the understanding of the pathobiological disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The research aims outlined in this proposal seek to better understand the molecular pathways that contribute to neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration in Alzheimer disease (AD), which as the most common form of dementia, is a major source of human suffering and significant source of cost to the public health sector. This research has the potential to identify novel aspects of AD pathogenesis and to point to novel therapeutic targets. Ultimately, the long-term goal of these studies would be to facilitate novel treatments that could treat or prevent AD, leading to longer lives with less disability for affected patients and reduced caregiver burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE KSHV, the viral agent of Kaposi sarcoma (KS), alters expression of cellular genes involved in iron metabolism in order to acquire iron for growth while resisting an iron-dependent form of cell death known as ferroptosis. Iron addiction coupled with ferroptosis resistance is a feature of several tumors and activation of ferroptosis is considered a promising therapeutic strategy, but the relationship between iron and ferroptosis in KS has not yet been characterized or explored as a treatment option. Our goal is to address this deficit by (i) defining the importance of iron in KSHV pathogenesis, (ii) understanding how KSHV-infected cells resist ferroptotic death and (iii) evaluating the therapeutic potential of ferroptosis activation in an in vivo KS tumor model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Abnormal chromosome numbers in eggs or sperm cause developmental disabilities or miscarriage. These abnormalities often arise because of improper separation of chromosomes caused by defects in meiotic homologous recombination. This project will address fundamental questions about the mechanism and control of recombination and thus is of direct relevance to human reproductive health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The objectives of this proposal are to develop aging-relevant human neuron models of late-onset Alzheimer's disease, using direct reprogramming technology in combination with CRISPR/Cas9-mediated gene editing, and to dissect the underlying mechanisms of apoE2's protective roles in Alzheimer's disease. The outcomes of the proposed studies will likely identify novel targets for anti-Alzheimer's disease drug development, especially for treating or protecting late-onset Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Biased ligand design is an attractive approach for designing drugs that target a particular signaling pathway with high specificity and selectivity to minimize side effects, however, it is also a grand challenge due to lack of computational tools. Also, there is an urgent need to expand the druglike chemical space for promising drug targets which have plenty of potent ligands developed, but unfortunately, no approved drugs. We plan to apply artificial intelligence (AI) techniques to overcome the two challenges by developing interaction profile scoring function models to enable biased ligand design and Drug-GAN models to achieve de novo novel chemical structure design.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic activity is dynamically regulated across cell states in development and disease and can contribute to the establishment of cell fate through metabolite-dependent effects on chromatin organization. The goal of this research proposal is to identify the mechanisms by which metabolic pathways drive chromatin changes to support the exit from naïve pluripotency in mouse embryonic stem cells. These studies will enhance our understanding of how metabolic control of gene expression enables successful execution of developmental programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In today's twenty-four-hour society, women suffer disproportionately from the negative health consequences associated with sleep loss. Since negative sleep responses to daily challenges may be a predisposing factor for morbidity, it is important to determine the influences of biological sex and reproductive development on the ability to tolerate sleep loss. These experiments use EEG/EMG recording in juvenile and adult mouse models to determine whether genetic, gonadal, and phenotypic determinants of sex are predisposing factors for sleep dysregulation during and after sleep loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is highly relevant to public health because it addresses the need for a resource- appropriate, scaleable tobacco cessation intervention for low-resource settings. There is limited knowledge about how best to translate effective interventions from high-resource settings to low-resource settings and how to use technology to support the ongoing training of busy practitioners. Upon completion, our study will deliver practice-focused strategies that can be adapted to other health issues and other low-resource settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  The long term goal of this proposal is to characterize the microstructural thickness variations of the tear film lipid layer and their association with clinical characteristics of dry eye disease. This work will not only advance our understanding of the factors that contribute to human precorneal tear film dynamics and help identify novel diagnostic biomarkers, but also inform the development of new therapeutics to slow or prevent the development of dry eye disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The maintenance of chromosome integrity is critical for preventing genetic disorders and avoiding cancer. The work described in this proposal will investigate how chromosomes break, and how cells choose different options for repairing that damage. Factors that affect chromosome pairing and orderly DNA replication will be studied to determine how they act to maintain the organization of genetic material in the nucleus, an important factor for its normal function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasingly, students in four-year undergraduate Biomedical Engineering programs are expected to gain advanced knowledge and enhanced training for workforce preparedness by engaging in learning experiences outside fundamental engineering content taught in the classroom, such as: (1) immersion and observation in a clinical setting, and (2) understanding the process and pathways of translating biomedical innovation towards commercialization for clinical and patient use. This project seeks to design and deliver valuable hands-on, learner-centered content to Union College's Biomedical Engineering majors through an intensive Summer Clinical Immersion Program at Albany Medical College where students will identify unmet needs in the clinic, feeding directly into a sustained educational experience through an expanded Capstone Design Course Sequence that encourages exploration of the translation pathway while also providing the expertise, resources, and mentoring necessary for students to jump-start their solutions towards commercialization. Union's proposed Summer Clinical Immersion Program and enhanced Capstone Design Course Sequence will not only create solutions to meet current medical needs but will also better prepare undergraduates to contribute immediately to established or startup biomedical device companies, bolster students' understanding and expertise in biomedical device development, and empower them to confidently navigate the path from initial solution to final product.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms (LUTS) that a patient perceives are a function of how information flows from the bladder to the brain and how it is interpreted. Growing evidence suggests urinary tract infections (which are far more prevalent in females and than in males) in early childhood are associated with LUTS in later life. Using mouse models, we wish to study how recurrent early life urinary tract infections and the accompanying inflammation alter bladder-to-brain signaling, if these changes are also accompanied by psychological consequences (such as anxiety- and depression-like behavior), and if these changes persist across the lifespan in female mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a common and costly syndrome causing 250,000 deaths/year in the USA and despite much research, almost all new therapies have not helped patients survive longer. Artificial intelligence may allow healthcare workers to identify and treat sepsis by using data available from the electronic health record and has shown major promise to help combat sepsis. The goal of my research is to become an expert who can use new technology to improve the care and well-being of people who have sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance Statement) Traumatic brain injury (TBI) perturbs the glucose metabolism of the brain and causes energy crisis that accelerates the development of neurodegenerative diseases in needs of a sensitive imaging tool for diagnosis and prognosis. This project introduces a novel glucose detecting CEST MRI to obtain brain glucose images with resolution ~100 times greater than the current PET images to assist clinicians in determining the best treatments for TBI. We still utilize CEST MRI, in concert with multiple advanced MRIs on a rat model of TBI, to evaluate the treatments of neurological impairments in associated with the disruptions of glucose metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preventive pharmacological therapy (PPT) for kidney stones is infrequently used due to gaps in the available evidence. Findings from our study will fill these gaps by providing data on clinically relevant outcomes, treatment tolerability, and potential healthcare savings. In doing so, our findings will help raise provider acceptance of and bolster guideline recommendations for PPT. To the extent that greater provider acceptance and more informed clinical practice guidelines increase the level of PPT use, patients with kidney stones will be the ultimate beneficiaries of our research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative ECoG is a critical methodological bridge between basic neuroscience findings and our understanding of the human brain in health and disease. However, adoption of ECoG for basic neuroscience, and realizing its full potentials in humans, is impeded by a lack of understanding of the precise biophysical processes generating cortical surface electrical potentials (CSEPs). We propose to use direct electrophysiological monitoring and optogenetic perturbations in rats and mice, combined with biophysically detailed simulations, to reveal the origins of distinct frequency components of ECoG- recorded CSEPs. We hypothesize that distinct CSEP components represent distinct cell types and laminar sources within a cortical column, and thus report different types of information in the local cortical network associated with these sources. This research will provide understanding of the cellular and biophysical origins of ECoG signals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: Computational Enzymology to Study Diverse Catalytic Strategies of RNA PI: Darrin M. York, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08854-8087 USA. RNA enzymes are fundamental in biology, and have important applications for chemistry, biotech- nology and medicine. The goal of this proposal is to develop and apply a novel computational RNA enzymology approach to gain a predictive understanding of the diverse array of catalytic strate- gies exhibited by RNA enzymes. Powerful computational tools and insightful guiding principles for ribozyme engineering are likely to emerge that enable the design of new biomedical technology and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-meal glucose control is challenging in individuals with type 1 diabetes, and it is associated with diabetes comorbidities. This project will assess the effect of dietary fat and protein on post- meal glucose control and examine if this information can be used in artificial pancreas systems in order to improve glucose control without meal announcement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Intracerebral hemorrhage is the most devastating form of stroke, with a mortality rate approaching 40% and with survivors suffering substantial disability. There are currently no proven treatments to limit neurologic injury after intracerebral hemorrhage, creating a critical need for new research into mechanisms of injury that can lead to novel therapeutic targets. Dr. Bevers’ career development plan has outstanding potential to further our understanding of the role of inflammation after brain hemorrhage and in doing so to bring the field closer to potential therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the remarkable success of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) in reducing morbidity and mortality related to HIV disease, numerous studies have reported cART-related adverse effects on mental health including depression in people with HIV. Our proposed Bayesian statistical methods for understanding the longitudinal cART effects on depression and optimizing personalized sequential cART assignments will have substantial public health relevance in preventing increased likelihood of HIV transmission, and potential clinical utility by assisting physicians in making effective personalized treatment decisions and contributing to the ultimate goal of precision medicine in HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Pterygium is a fibrovascular growth of the conjunctiva that extends into the transparent cornea, causing a decline in vision. Ultraviolet exposure is an established risk factor for pterygium formation, but the exact molecular mechanism leading to pterygium progression is unknown. Here we will test the hypothesis that ultraviolet radiation induces activation of endogenous retroviruses, which are otherwise suppressed at basal conditions, and in turn promoting cell migration via non-canonical NF-κB signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Narrative A better understanding of how mutations interact in combination to affect biological processes would improve our ability to predict the effect of genetic variation on health and disease, design proteins and cellular systems with desired functions, and target biological systems with chemical and genetic therapies. New technologies have been developed to measure the effects of large numbers of mutations, singly and in combination, on biochemical properties, but they have never been applied to understand the effects on fitness of the specific set of mutations that have actually occurred in real proteins during real evolutionary processes. Here we combine those technologies with methods to reconstruct the evolutionary history of genes and proteins to reveal the historical effects and interactions among all mutations that occurred over a billion- year long trajectory in the biologically essential protein Hsp90, which helps hundreds of client proteins in the cells of humans and other species fold and function and plays crucial roles in many disorders and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Based on the success of trauma systems, the Alabama Department of Public Health is planning a five-year statewide quality improvement initiative of trauma communications center coordinated stroke triage which aims to transform the fragmented acute stroke care system by coordinating prehospital and inter-facility emergency stroke care. This allows assessment of both the public health impact and the “how and why” of implementation of an innovative acute stroke care model that will aid in future implementation efforts. This project, if successful, can serve as a model for how the trauma system infrastructure that already exists in other regions and states can serve as the basis for a more integrated and effective system of emergency stroke care throughout the US.

PHR: Project Narrative Cell division is crucial for life but can also threaten life by causing overproliferation as it does in cancer. The goal of this project is to understand how proteins that drive cell division are produced and how this affects their function. This will help to understand how cell division can go awry and may provide new entry points for blocking uncontrolled division.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-compliance with clinical practice guidelines compromises patient outcomes after injury, and is particularly prevalent among the elderly. One of the critical barriers to reducing preventable deaths after injury is the absence of methods to identify the source of physician non-compliance and to personalize the selection of implementation strategies. The objective of this proposal is to develop and to validate a serious game (an applied video game) to understand physician behavior in trauma triage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on understanding how a class of drugs called PARP inhibitors, drugs being used to treat cancer and being tested for an expanding number of non- malignant human diseases, cause the serious blood and bone marrow toxicities seen in some patients taking them. This proposal will provide key mechanistic insight into which cells in the bone marrow require the enzymes targeted by these drugs for normal functioning, and whether these drugs have the capability to mutate the DNA of these cells to predispose patients to bone marrow failure or blood cancers. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the National Heart, Blood, and Lung Institute’s mission to promote the prevention of blood diseases and enhance the health of all individuals so that they can live longer and more fulfilling lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The ventromedial prefrontal cortex is generally believed to mediate the inhibition of fear, however it is also paradoxically activated in a large subset of post-traumatic stress disorder patients, where fear expression is greatly enhanced. The proposed work will investigate the mechanisms underlying fear encoding in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex. Overall, results will reveal new information regarding how the medial prefrontal cortex participates in the encoding and expression of learned fear with important implications for disorders of pathological fear and anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: NARRATIVE Both Alzheimer's disease and normal aging are associated with a dramatic decrease in the production of new neurons in the hippocampus and this decrease may underlie the associated cognitive impairments. Slowing or even reversing this decrease may be important for addressing the cognitive decline due to old age or disease. We have recently developed a new approach for studying the birth of new neurons from stem cells, and we will now apply this approach to determine the trajectory of neurogenesis while it is compromised by aging and Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Only 13% of adults living with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) have normal cognitive function. Black ESRD patients are uniquely vulnerable to premature cognitive aging; systemic racism (i.e., structural, institutional, and interpersonal racism) is a likely cause of health disparities in cognitive impairment, cognitive decline, and Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementia (AD/ADRD). In collaboration with The National Kidney Foundation, Alzheimer's Association, and a local community advisory board, we seek to address key priorities for the National Institute on Aging among ESRD patients in the national registry (n=1.36 million) and an ongoing, NIA- funded, multi-center, prospective cohort study (n=5,275): 1) to estimate the impact of structural and institutional racism on incident AD/ADRD; 2) to quantify the contributions of lifecourse systemic racism on cognitive impairment and decline; 3) to test whether resilience to systemic racism protects against cognitive impairment and decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: This study extends an existing national longitudinal study of aging and health in Mexico, with two additional waves of core data collection and one more wave of its ancillary study on cognitive aging, The resulting public use databases will extend over twenty-six years. Highly comparable to similar studies in the U.S. and other countries, the study will allow enhanced research on aging, Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, health, and mortality in a rapidly aging developing country with limited institutional support for the elderly, and with long-lived health, economic, and social ties to the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose the first and largest multi-ethnic study to investigate the association between per- and poly- fluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) and breast cancer risk using innovative laboratory technologies and statistical methods and integrate the comprehensive information on PFAS, PFAS-associated metabolic alterations, genetics, and breast cancer risk factors to identify subgroups of women at increased risk for breast cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Microneedle patches (MNP) are an emerging technology for painless, low-dose, prolonged drug delivery. Polymerized drugs, i.e. poly(pro-drug)s, are a unique class of macromolecules composed almost entirely of a pro-drug molecule in long chain repeating sequences. In this application, we propose to develop the first ever MNP composed of a poly(pro-drug), specifically crosslinked thermosetting polyester resins of pro-17β-estradiol for prolonged low-dose estrogen delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The newest approach to treating diabetic kidney disease is to reduce physical and metabolic stress on the kidney by inhibiting the renal glucose transporter, SGLT2. This research is dedicated to gaps in knowledge about the mechanisms whereby inhibitors of SGLT2 and of other glucose transporters reduce physical and metabolic stress on the kidney and whether these mechanisms might be leveraged to improve outcomes in non- diabetic chronic kidney disease. This research uses rat and mouse models of human diabetes and chronic kidney disease because key variables can be measured in these models that cannot be measured in vitro or in human subjects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement/Project Narrative Understanding the role of the pharmaceutical industry in propelling the current opioid crisis in the U.S. is an essential strategy for preventing future epidemics. Using various forms of textual data and analytic methods, this project examines the specific impacts of industry efforts to target military veterans as opioid consumers and the ways that the industry attempts to popularize new narratives, or scripts, about opioid analgesics within veteran-specific periodicals. The identification of dominant narratives and their circulation through veterans' media outlets represents a critical case study in pharmaceutical industry efforts to change prescribing policy and popular culture. Findings will be translated into deliverables which positively impact pain management policy, practice, and the attitudes and expectations of our nation's veterans and others struggling with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance – Obesity occurs when fat tissue expands and adversely affects health. Obesity is a leading cause of type 2 diabetes, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and dyslipidemia. Interactions between immune and fat cells and how they regulate lipid balance is important in understanding how obesity contributes to these disorders. Defining immune-fat cell interactions offer the possibility of developing therapeutic strategies to combat obesity-associated diseases.

PHR: Narrative: Research scientists focused on the fields of pregnancy and reproduction are critically important in the advancement of national public health. Nonetheless, the increasing complexity of such research across clinical and non-clinical specialties means there may not be enough future cross-trained scientists to meet our health needs. We propose a partnership of the Faculty of the Integrated Program in Endocrinology with Clinical Fellowships in the depts ObGyn, Pediatrics and Medicine, in conjunction with outstanding Campus Research Centers and Cores to provide an excellent environment to train these future scientists in translational research, and we propose here a training program plan to achieve that goal.

PHR: Narrative The intestines are home to a community of bacteria, but also of viruses and fungi. Fungal microbiota is usually studied trough methodologies exploring the fungal DNA imprint and then the functional characteristics of these fungi are explored using model fungal organisms that are not the one present in the patients. Using fungi from the intestines of inflammatory bowel disease patients, that we discovered to be functionally different across different individuals, we will study the process on inflammation where these organisms might influence response to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is the most common life-threatening autosomal-recessive condition among Caucasians, with clinical care for patients in the U.S. alone totaling over $450 million annually. Although airway submucosal glands are severely affected in this disease, little is known about the biology of this glandular stem cell niche or how CF airway disease impacts function of this stem cell compartment. The proposed research will utilize mouse and ferret models to dissect the basic biology of glandular stem cells and disease-associated changes in CF that may be important to stem cell-directed therapies for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed ARDS, Pneumonia, and Sepsis (APS) Phenotyping Consortium Coordinating Center, CAPSTONE, will be a highly functional and integrated coordination and support infrastructure that will raise the quality and scientific rigor of the research conducted by the APS Phenotyping Consortium. The team, composed of leading content experts at Vanderbilt, Johns Hopkins, and University of California San Francisco, will simultaneously harmonize the needs of varied stakeholders; guide design, analysis, and data collection; and keep ahead of technical, societal, and medical evolutions. CAPSTONE will expand foundational work on APS phenotyping, identify gaps, and help create statistical and other methods for redefining critical illness syndromes with the ultimate goal of improving and personalizing management strategies that will curtail the devastating morbidity and mortality caused by APS.

PHR: BOREALIS - Narrative The BiOengineering Research Education to AcceLerate Innovation in STEM (BOREALIS) research education program is designed to advance the diversity of the bioengineering research workforce by creating a pathway to bioengineering graduate study for regional, sociodemographically diverse students. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: CENTER OVERVIEW PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Colorado Denver (UC Denver) is renowned for its basic, translational and clinical diabetes research programs, which encompass Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes, diabetes complications and autoimmunity. The purpose of the UC Denver Diabetes Research Center (DRC) is to unite this community and facilitate their research endeavors by providing efficient and innovative shared resources, developing enrichment programs to facilitate interactions and collaborations between center members, and implementing a strong pilot and feasibility program to bring new investigators into the diabetes field. These efforts will result in improved understanding of disease etiologies and progression, and promote the development of diabetes treatments and cures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. Cigarette smoking is now the leading killer of people with HIV (PWH) in the US, and most cessation strategies tried to date have failed to increase long-term quit rates. An “all or none” approach to smoking cessation in PWH offers little benefit to the large majority of PWH who are unable or unwilling to quit. In this proposal we argue that a harm reduction approach (i.e. cut down, get screened for lung cancer, control your blood pressure and cholesterol) has the potential to yield significant benefits in terms of the private and public health of PWH in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Employing a range of methods with extant quantitative data and newly collected qualitative data to study the link between having young adult children with serious conditions and mothers’ health in late-midlife, this project situates the health risks and benefits of aging mothers, the strains and rewards of parenting, and the needs of young adults within the overall life course, the parenting career, and ecological context while elucidating thorny social psychological processes that explain why some mothers suffer in late-midlife while others are resilient. This approach can better serve this increasing number of American women by identifying when and where to intervene and facilitating better understanding of what they need. In these ways, this theoretically grounded and policy-focused project on vulnerability and resilience in a growing population of older American women captures the spirit of Healthy People 2030 and advances many general goals of NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek to understand the mechanisms underlying human thalamocortical pathway development and to study how genetic mutations found in patients with neurodevelopmental psychiatric disorders may disrupt the thalamocortical pathway formation. In order study these processes in human cell-based models, we will take advantage of human pluripotent stem cell technology which enables scalable in vitro differentiation into tissue models of the cerebral cortex and the thalamus. Moreover, using cutting-edge single cell sequencing technologies, we will identify the molecular pathways that may be involved in regulating thalamocortical pathway development in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE How multiple transcription factors interact at cis-regulatory elements to regulate transcription remains a fundamental question in biology. In this proposal, we will exploit the regulation of rhythmic transcription by the mammalian circadian clock to uncover fundamental mechanisms by which transcription factors cooperate and compete with histones to control transcription. Our findings are expected to provide important insights into the mechanisms that enable the circadian clock to coordinate the temporal organization of biological processes across the 24-hour day, and more generally into how transcription factor cooperativity regulate transcription.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this project is to determine the cellular mechanisms responsible for neurodevelopmental disorders associated with mutations in the gene, ATP1A3. This gene encodes a protein involved with maintaining ion gradients in neurons, which are required for normal neuron function. ATP1A3 mutations cause severe childhood-onset neurological diseases with inadequate treatment options, and our work will help inform new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our ability to recognize the category, or behavioral significance, of visual stimuli is essential for planning and carrying out successful behaviors in response to our surroundings. The goal of this research project is to provide a detailed and mechanistic understanding about how the brain learns and recognizes visual categories. A detailed understanding of these brain mechanisms is critical for understanding and ultimately addressing the profound deficits of learning, memory and visual recognition that frequently accompany brain diseases and conditions such as stroke, schizophrenia and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance Disruptions of mitochondrial structure have been found in many neurodegenerative and mitochondrial diseases which afflict millions of people worldwide with tremendous global economic and societal burdens. An effective treatment is desperately needed but the underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms of their destructive path remain poorly understood. This proposal aims to elucidate the mechanisms underlying mitochondrial strucutral maintenance and provide novel therapeutic strategies to alleviate oxidative damage, is therefore relevant to public health and the mission of the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Most medications are molecules that work by binding tightly to a specific pocket in the surface of a protein involved in a disease process, and thus blocking the protein’s disease-related function. This project aims to develop advanced computational methods and software that will speed the discovery of new medications by helping scientists identify druggable pockets on protein surfaces then design or discover molecules that will bind tightly to a targeted protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative. Diabetic retinopathy is a vascular complication of long-term diabetes, and the vascular complications of diabetes are associated with increased levels of extracellular vesicles in plasma, but from where those extracellular vesicles originated from has not been defined. Evidence that neural retina contributes to the etiopathogenesis of diabetic retinopathy is accumulating, and the research proposed in this application will unravel the role of retina- derived extracellular vesicles in the disease. I propose a multipronged approach to understand the influence of retina-derived extracellular vesicles in the development of diabetic retinopathy, the role of the visual cycle in their cargo sorting, and potential therapies to inhibit the interaction of retina-derived extracellular vesicles and the recipient cells, including retinal endothelial cells and leukocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a significant health problem in the United States that poses great medical and socioeconomical burdens to this country, the solving of which demands new molecular insights into its mechanisms of development. Here we employ human brain samples, advanced cell models and epigenomic techniques to explore a new area of enhancer-derived RNAs in human brain gene deregulation and AD pathology. This study will lead to molecular characterization of unexplored ncRNA players in AD that can provide novel targets and pathways for AD diagnosis and therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research (CIBMTR) plays a unique and important role in facilitating clinical research in hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HCT) and adoptive cellular therapy (ACT). It is committed to developing its research database, in volume and scope; its statistical expertise; and data sharing capabilities, to meet the needs of investigators in a rapidly evolving field. This award will allow CIBMTR to build on the infrastructure made possible by support from U24-CA076518 to better serve the research and healthcare community and to address issues important to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human patients suffering from sweat gland deficiencies are unable to properly maintain body temperature, which can lead to hyperthermia, heat stroke, brain damage, and potentially death. We will investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying sweat gland development at different stages and how the progenitor cells respond to environmental cues which shape the morphogenesis. Upon completion our work will significantly advance our knowledge in sweat gland biology, as well as facilitate development of novel strategies to regenerate sweat glands for the patients who loss sweating ability to regain thermoregulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Randomized clinical trials of interventions to prevent and treat acute and chronic respiratory failure are the bedrock of evidence-based practice. However, there are several threats to the equity of such trials, including failures to enroll participants with similar characteristics to persons to whom the interventions would be applied, and the possibility that commonly used scoring systems for risk adjustment within such trials would perform inequitably across groups defined by race, ethnicity, or sex. This mid-career investigator award in patient- oriented research will take essential steps toward surmounting these challenges in the context of a multifaceted training program that will make the Principal Investigator a more effective mentor and team leader.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Self-renewal of adult stem cells is a fundamental property required for stem cell maintenance and tissue homeostasis. In this project, we will study hair follicle stem cells and their niche and investigate molecular mechanisms that govern the formation of the hair follicle stem cell compartment. Knowledge gained from the proposed study will provide new insights into the maintenance and aging of hair follicle stem cells and help to develop potential applications using hair follicle stem cells for regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gene tribbles pseudokinase 1 (TRIB1) has been repeatedly identified by human genome-wide associations studies as a key regulator of cardiometabolic health in human, and in vivo mouse studies have highlighted the importance of hepatic Trib1 in these associations. However, despite the overwhelming human and experimental evidence of the importance of TRIB1, very little is known about its main mechanism of action in the liver. The proposed studies in this application will elucidate how hepatic TRIB1 regulates protein ubiquitination and degradation, determine the therapeutic benefit of increased hepatic TRIB1 activity in preclinical models of cardiometabolic disease, and leverage a unique human genetics data set to identify rare DNA variants in TRIB1 that can inform its therapeutic efficacy and safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative How visual information is processed and transformed by cortical and subcortical pathways to generate visually guided behavior is a fundamental question for visual research. By focusing on the superior colliculus, a conserved visuomotor processing center, we will investigate how visual signals from two external input sources, primary visual cortex and ventral lateral geniculate nucleus, shape visual processing in superior colliculus neurons and impact related visual behaviors in a context-dependent manner. This research may help to provide potentially new information on general neural principles for our understanding of control and modulation of visually guided behaviors in normal subjects as well as in neurological and neuropsychiatric conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Successful completion of the goals of this project will reveal how heme oxygenases regulate heme and carbon monoxide levels and protect cells against renal, cardiovascular and central nervous system pathologies induced by oxidative stress. Studies on Rev-Erb, which links the circadian clock to metabolism and inflammation, will help explain why abnormal circadian rhythms are associated with cancer, disturbances in the cell cycle and metabolic disorders. Our research on heme responsive motifs (HRMs) will reveal their multi-tier regulation of Rev-Erbβ and heme oxygenase-2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Despite the prevalence and socioeconomic burdens of Osteoporosis and the associated fragility fractures, screening rates using standardized bone density scans are abysmal. This is attributed to disparities in access to screening, which can potentially be corrected with accessible pre-screening tools in physician offices and community clinics. Therefore, this proposal aims to develop an accessible, noninvasive optical vibrational spectroscopy tool to assess bone quality and fragility fracture risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Bone fractures in type 2 diabetes cannot be accurately predicted by current bone density-based clinical tools as T2D patients exhibit normal to high bone mineral density. This project will establish Carboxymethyl-lysine (CML) as a new biomarker of T2D fracture and determine how the oxidation and glycation processes, associated with diabetes under obese and non-obese conditions, impact accumulation of CML and other Advanced Glycation Endproducts (AGEs) and enhance bone fragility. The results will provide new strategies to diagnose, treat and mitigate T2D and fragility fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small molecules that selectively activate targeted signaling pathways of the μ-opioid receptor (MOR), such as biased/partial agonists and/or chemogenetic probes, can help to disentangle the mechanisms of analgesia versus dangerous side-effects involved in opioid addiction, as well as potentially act as novel pain management drugs without addictive properties. Here, we will develop computer-aided drug discovery tools that can model large-scale induced-fit conformational changes during drug design and simulate chemogenetics design (receptor-ligand co-design), which we will then apply to identify partial and biased agonists of the MOR and MOR-based DREADDs. In silico molecules and DREADD designs will be experimentally validated and enter hit- to-lead optimization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative JC virus (JCPyV) infects greater than 50% of the human population worldwide and causes a fatal central nervous system disease in humans known as Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy or PML in individuals with compromised immune systems. This proposal focuses on understanding the pathophysiology of JC virus induced PML. Our work is focused on translating our significant work on the basic biology of JCPyV infection to the clinic by the identification of biomarkers and the identification of small compounds that can prevent or treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Oral potentially malignant disorders (OPMD) are a common and heterogeneous group of mucosal lesions in the oral cavity without robust and consistent biomarkers for their risk of progression to can cer. Here we propose to use whole slide imaging analysis of routine clinical samples to develop a more robust risk assessment process. These analyses will be combined with genomic and immune biomarkers that should provide improved clinical risk assessment as well as new insights on the biology of progression in OPMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adult stem cells perform tissue maintenance and repair throughout our lifetime but a decline in stem cell function with age leads to progressive and systemic degeneration. There are still significant gaps in our understanding of how aging influences skeletal stem cells. In this proposal, we will determine the molecular mechanisms that regulate skeletal stem cell function and investigate 2 potential therapeutic targets for improved bone healing in the elderly patient.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative The main objectives of this program are to ensure that a well-trained group of Indonesian researchers have the capacity to detect and characterize pathogens of potential human significance from clinical and environmental samples and to examine archival and prospective samples for the presence of human pathogens using a range of virological and molecular methodologies. This new research proposal is designed to build on programmatic elements that were implemented in the CK15-001 which will conclude 7/31/2020. With infrastructure, trained personnel, and primary equipment in place, we can now proceed to discover, diagnose, and characterize vector-borne and zoonotic pathogens; strategically conduct surveillance to establish the role of these pathogens in presentations of acute febrile illness (AFI); and investigate the transmission dynamics of vector-borne and zoonotic disease agents. By the end of Year 5 of this new cooperative agreement, we anticipate having significantly increased and broadened Indonesia’s capacity for molecular diagnosis of emerging vector-borne diseases. Specifically, we plan to have the ability to routinely carry out deep sequencing of selected AFI specimens, institute metagenomic testing, and establish routine testing for Rickettsia and arboviruses found in neighboring countries. We anticipate testing 1000-1500 samples per year collected from all regions of the country. Additionally, we plan to incorporate testing for several pathogens that cause symptoms similar to vector-borne agents and would be included in any differential diagnosis, including leptospirosis and hantavirus. Additional partners and studies will be incorporated in later years of this agreement (CK20-002) to incorporate areas with distinct ecologies and transmission potential as opportunities are identified and deemed appropriate to the goals of the program.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CK20-002 - Enabling Rapid and Accurate Identification of Emerging Vector-Borne and Zoonotic Threats in Indonesia

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We will develop new computational methods that learn from millions of examples to design antibodies that can be used to help cure a wide variety of human diseases such as cancer and viral infection. Previous antibody design approaches used a trial and error approach to find antibodies that worked well. In contrast our mathematical methods will directly produce new antibody designs by learning from large-scale experiments that test antibodies for function against disease targets. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health since long-term survival rates for patients with tumors of the stomach or esophagus remain stubbornly low despite advances in genomics. This work directly addresses this challenge based on the hypothesis that it is possible to use living patient samples ex vivo on rapid timeframes to refine and validate associations between genotype and therapeutic dependency. Since this approach will enable both basic and translational cancer research it is centrally focused on the NCI’s mission to support research to reduce the morbidity and mortality of difficult-to-treat tumors such as gastroesophageal adenocarcinomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research program will use computational approaches to advance genomic, biological and clinical understandings of human disease. We propose a series of studies to: i) quantify population-based penetrance of clinical variants; ii) dissect the phenotypic heterogeneity of complex disease; iii) assess the impact of natural selection using the deleterious load on human phenotypes; and iv) use human genomics to guide drug side effect prediction. Findings from these studies can lead to new biological insights and useful tools that can inform prevention, diagnosis and treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although remarkable progress has been made on a scientific level in understanding regulatory processes governing the activity of the immune system against cancer, the clinical application of these findings to develop effective cancer therapies requires a more detailed knowledge of the molecules and pathways involved. Despite recent advances in anti-PD-(L)1 therapies in over a dozen different cancer types, treatment resistance remains a major unsolved clinical problem. Our objectives are 1) to characterize intratumoral factors, including immune cell, tumor cell, and stromal components, underlying anti-PD-(L)1 resistance; and 2) to use this knowledge to develop more effective cancer immunotherapies based on PD-1 pathway blockade, by co-targeting additional tumor immune resistance pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precise regulation of the DNA repair machinery is essential to protect our genetic material from DNA damage and prevent genome instability, which is a hallmark of cancer. Therefore, understanding the regulations how cells control the choice of DNA repair pathway is essential for devising a therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. Our goal is to elucidate the molecular mechanism on the cell cycle- regulated DNA repair by identifying a key histone mark reader that potentially regulates repair proteins homeostasis at damaged chromatin.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) is a cardiovascular disease manifesting from atherosclerotic blockages in the leg arteries which results in physical activity induced claudication, leg pain, discomfort, or cramping. PAD is the most common disorder treated within the surgical service at the Omaha Veterans Affairs Medical Center (VAMC). As the median age of VA patients increases, the number of patients suffering from PAD is expected to rise. PAD results in inability of the ankle plantarflexors to generate normal torque and power in legs. We are currently testing whether ankle foot orthoses can offset ankle plantarflexor torque and power deficiency. The current proposed exoskeleton footwear was developed to address limitations identified in our ongoing trial. Determining the levels of EF assistance force that produce better walking performance and subject-reported preference can improve EF intervention efficacy and prescriptive specifications. The project will provide fundamental information for future implementation and clinical trials in Veterans with PAD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Rural residents, especially Appalachians, have among the nation’s highest rates of cardiovascular disease (CVD), diabetes, and obesity, all associated with unhealthy diet and lack of physical activity. New tools, including personal technology, offers an opportunity to make long lasting behavioral changes and improve health. We will test a culturally adapted evidence-based multicomponent mHealth intervention, Make Better Choices 2 (MBC2), a behavioral program consisting of personalized health coaching, an app, accelerometer, and financial incentives and, explore optimal implementation and sustainment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The emerging henipaviruses are a growing genus of viruses that include the Nipah and Hendra viruses, which are deadly to humans. This study focuses on the viral glycoproteins, which coordinate their efforts to mediate entry of these viruses into host cells, and cell-cell fusion, a pathogenic event in viral infections. Our studies will provide a fundamental understanding of viral entry and cell-cell fusion and identify viral targets for the development of anti-viral therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood stress and trauma are pernicious public health problems linked to increased risk for an enormous array of behavioral and psychiatric disorders and chronic medical conditions across the lifespan. However, progress toward prevention and intervention to reduce the toll of childhood stress and trauma and promote resilience is limited by the small number of researchers trained to conduct translational, developmentally- informed research focused on mechanisms and health consequences of childhood stress and trauma. Training a cohort of diverse researchers to conduct cutting-edge, rigorous research in childhood stress, trauma and resilience is critical to improve childhood health and prevent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although repeated exposure to stress has been known to impede higher level cognition, including decision- making, our understanding of how stress affects brain regions associated with these functions remains incomplete. Here, we propose a multi-level approach to comprehensively link the behavioral, circuit and cellular level consequences of stress. Our research will yield a mechanistic understanding of how stress influences cognitive function and likely contribute to the future development of intervention strategies.
