IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (3 sentences) Pharmaceuticals for treatment of B cell malignancies rely on a class of inhibitors that irreversibly bind the ATP-binding cleft of Bruton's Tyrosine Kinase. Due to their covalent binding within this pocket, these inhibitors have significant off-target side effects and are susceptible to resistance mutations. The goal of this project is to elucidate the lipid-binding and oligomerization of Btk to understand the mechanism of membrane association as potential alternative sites and pathways for Btk inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Autoimmune, or insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, is characterized by an inflammatory reaction in and around pancreatic islets, followed by selective destruction of b-cells. Soluble mediators known as cytokines are believed to contribute to b-cell damage during this process. We have recently uncovered a number of protective responses that are activated by cytokines and the long range goals of this work are to identify potential thearputic potential of these b-cell protective pathways in an effort to treat or prevent autoimmune diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance  Project Narrative Driving under the influence of cannabis and related traffic fatalities have become a major public health concern, but little is known about how and when cannabis users decide whether to drive after using cannabis. The project will use mobile technology to assess immediate influences of “real life” contexts in a person’s daily life on the decision to drive after using cannabis. The project will provide information critical to the development of cannabis policy and prevention efforts to reduce the risk of driving under the influence of cannabis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal systemic inflammation during pregnancy represents a potential common pathway for effects of a diverse range of preconception and prenatal factors on the developing fetal brain with implications for long term neurodevelopmental outcomes and risk for psychiatric disorders. The current research and training plan addresses major limitations of the research in this area to date by implementing multivariate statistics and cross validation across three independent datasets to capture the complexity of effects of maternal psychosocial, life history and health factors on the maternal inflammatory milieu during pregnancy. Further, heterogeneity in the maternal inflammatory milieu (and specifically cytokine networks) is examined as a mechanism through which variability in prenatal conditions alter offspring neurodevelopment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although dietary lapses (i.e., instances of non-adherence to dietary goals) are a major cause of poor outcomes during behavioral obesity treatment, poorly understood variability in types of lapse behaviors and their mechanisms interferes with an ability to intervene on them. Therefore, we propose to use multimodal real-time assessment of behavioral, psychosocial, and contextual information to uncover and validate lapse phenotypes (i.e., meaningful clusters of lapse behaviors, such as lapsing via overeating vs. lapsing via eating an off-plan food), and then validate these emerging phenotypes by testing their associations with weight change and energy intake. By applying a multi-level analysis approach to phenotype specific lapse behaviors clustered within individuals over time, this project will: a) support the development of sophisticated theoretical models of adherence behaviors, b) inform precision tools that improve dietary adherence in behavioral treatments for obesity, and c) establish novel phenotyping methods that can be used to understand and intervene upon non- adherence across a myriad of other chronic health conditions (e.g., diabetes, renal disease).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression in the United States is one of the most common psychiatric disorders and can represent a significant cost to quality of life. Findings from the proposed research would enhance knowledge on the effects of neighborhood-level features such as residential segregation and neighborhood social cohesion on depression and the pathways leading to the association in Latino communities. This research would lay the foundation for the development of strengths-based interventions that may be leveraged to improve the mental health of Latinos and other underserved communities and in turn advance mental health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nervous system possesses unique immune response aspects that are altered in the context of neurological disorders, ranging from glioblastoma, the most common primary malignant brain tumor, to neuroinflammatory conditions and neurodegenerative disorders. Glioblastoma is highly infiltrated by myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) that drive tumor growth and reduce the efficacy of standard therapies, including checkpoint inhibitors. The objectives of this project are to use glioblastoma as a model for neurological disorders to identify the cellular and molecular basis for MDSC lineage commitment and plasticity, interrogate the response of MDSCs to microenvironmental cues, and evaluate pre-clinical MDSC targeting in combination with immune activating therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorders represent a major public health issue, and improved therapies are needed but pre- clinical models of addiction have not translated well into improved therapy options. An improved understanding of the clinical neurobiology of addictions may help refine preclinical models of addiction which may help inform the development of future therapies. The present study aims to further our understanding of the neurobiology of these disorders by assessing between-network functional connectivity and effective connectivity among three key brain networks (Salience Network, Default Mode Network, and Executive Control Network) in opioid and cocaine use disorder subjects compared to non-drug using controls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An effective immune response requires a fine balance between effector T cells that can eliminate pathogens and regulatory T cells that prevent autoimmunity. We hypothesize that a unique population of regulatory T cells recirculate back to the thymus (the site of all T cell development) and act as a rheostat to decrease the stringency of selection once peripheral regulatory T cell tolerance is established, thereby allowing for a more diverse and pathogen-reactive conventional immune system to emerge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been extremely successful in identifying genetic loci associated with complex diseases. This project aims to develop a statistical method to accurately infer the causal tissue and gene responsible for the functional consequences of each disease locus, thereby furthering our knowledge of disease biology. This project further aims to infer disease subtypes linked to specific tissues using polygenic risk scores, providing a new paradigm for inferring disease subtypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Bacteria have huge positive and negative impacts on human health, and we desperately need new strategies to combat pathogens and shape microbiome composition. We recently found that bacteria don't just affect us through chemicals, but also through their small RNAs (sRNAs). Building off our paradigm-shifting results, here we propose innovative new strategies to identify the sRNAs that “talk” to hosts from pathogens and the healthy microbiome, define how they function, and develop them as candidate immune-modulating therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need to better understand the geospatial and temporal dimensions of human mobility that lead to disparities in HIV outcomes, and for feasible and scalable interventions to improve HIV outcomes in mobile populations. Yet, research in these areas is nascent, and there is a great need for an expanded scientific workforce with training in human mobility and HIV to tackle these challenges. This application for the Midcareer Investigator Award in Patient-Oriented Research (K24) proposes a comprehensive mentoring, research and career development plan which will lay the groundwork for sustained, high impact research that is urgently needed to address the challenges posed by mobility to achieving HIV prevention and treatment goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This program trains post-doctoral fellows in clinical research to more effectively understand and manage the challenges of HIV and other infectious consequences of substance use. Incorporating expertise from multiple disciplines greatly enhances diagnosis, prevention and treatment research of HIV and other infectious diseases among people who use drugs and within communities that are heavily impacted by the substance use and overdose epidemics. Community engagement is emphasized to ensure that marginalized communities benefit from advances in biomedical science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Motivational interviewing (MI) is a leading evidence-based practice (EBP) for substance use disorder, but MI use and fidelity have been low in usual care. Strategies have been developed to support program leaders in improving EBP implementation climate, but it is not yet known whether these strategies work by improving alignment in perceived implementation climate between providers and leaders. The proposed project will leverage data from a cluster randomized trial of an organizational implementation strategy (LOCI) to: (1) measure vertical alignment of perceived implementation climate, (2) identify organizational factors associated with alignment, and (3) examine sensitivity to change, and explore associations with exposure to LOCI and provider MI implementation outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to investigate the mechanisms of in utero exposure to alcohol on mammary tumor development in MMTV-erbB2 transgenic mice. We will focus on in utero exposure to alcohol-induced estrogen receptor-erbB2 crosstalk in signal transduction and mammary stem cell reprogramming. The results from this project will have a profound impact on our understanding of the mechanisms that contribute to in utero exposure to alcohol- associated breast cancer risk later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Human neurological diseases associated with monoaminergic (e.g., serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine) dysfunction affect millions of individuals worldwide; however, treatments for these neurodevelopmental, neurodegenerative and/or psychiatric disorders remain inadequate. Here, employing a truly unique combination of biochemical, molecular, and behavioral approaches, we are examining novel, neurotransmission independent roles for serotonin in brain in the direct regulation of neuronal gene expression. The experiments in this proposal will leverage cutting-edge technologies to understand how alterations in histone serotonylation (i.e., the covalent addition of serotonin to histone proteins) directly modulate neurodevelopmental and early life neural plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative / Relevance Our proposed research is aimed at developing chemical probes and molecules that can measure and affect the biological activity of enzymes that repair damage in DNA. We will use our new compounds to test our hypotheses regarding how these enzymes might be targeted to prevent cancer in people who have a high risk of acquiring the disease. This work will provide valuable tools for cancer researchers, and may result in new and more effective strategies for cancer prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (Narrative) Schizophrenia is the 5th leading cause of disability in the world, affecting 51 million people in which patients suffer from cardinal deficits in self-agency (i.e., the fundamental experience of being the agent of one's own thoughts and actions). These deficits directly contribute to debilitating psychotic symptoms, and show limited response to pharmacological treatments with up to 40% of patients with schizophrenia (SZ) remaining symptomatic, thus compelling the need to identify the neurophysiology underlying self-agency deficits to guide new treatment development. Findings from this proof-of-concept study will delineate: (i) the underlying cognitive and neural cause of self-agency deficits in schizophrenia, (ii) responsiveness to new neurostimulation interventions targeting a novel neural target in the medial prefrontal cortex, and (iii) mechanisms of durability and generalizability, revealing how improvements in critical self-agency abilities can generalize to improvements in general cognition, symptoms and life quality in schizophrenia for future TMS treatment development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Obesity is the second most common cause of preventable death behind smoking, and is often associated with the risk of developing other comorbidities such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular disease, hyperlipidemia, among others. Our preliminary results suggest a potential intervention for obesity with the G protein-coupled estrogen receptor (GPER) contributing favorable outcomes, which may challenge the current insufficient therapeutic treatment options available to date. This proposal seeks to investigate the direct effects of GPER in adipocytes pertaining to lipid homeostasis, oxidative stress, inflammation, and mitochondrial function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Somatic mutations and modifiable factors interact to drive the development of clonal hematopoiesis (CH) and its transformation to hematologic malignancy. How to stratify risk for patients remains a significant open question, as not all patients with dominant clones go on to develop CH, and not all those with CH go on to develop cancer. In three synergistic mouse and human projects, our Program will identify how extrinsic stressors interact with specific genetic mutations to influence the clonal expansion and malignant transformation of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell clones in order to inform clinical guidance of individuals with CH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative By unveiling new molecular and pathogenic mechanisms that account for clonal hematopoiesis (CH) and hematologic malignancies, Project 1 of our Program is tightly aligned with the NCI mission. Our studies will provide important insights on how the modifiable stressors of infection and high-fat diet-induced obesity exert selective advantages on hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs) with CH-associated mutations and promote to their malignant transformation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Dengue and Zika are diseases of major importance worldwide, but surveillance, epidemic preparedness, and control are complicated by immunological cross-reactivity between dengue and Zika viruses (DENV and ZIKV), particularly in dengue-endemic Latin America after the explosive 2015-2016 Zika pandemic. It is critical for dengue and Zika vaccine evaluation and implementation, epidemic preparedness, and public health research to improve differential detection of prior infections by DENV and ZIKV and increase our understanding of how immunological cross-reactivity affects serological testing, seroprevalence estimation, viral transmission, and protection and/or enhancement of future flaviviral disease. Following upon our recent work showing that immunological asymmetries exist among the four DENV serotypes and ZIKV and that pre-existing immunity to ZIKV can enhance subsequent DENV2 infection and disease, this R01 will use new serological assays, diverse modeling approaches, and state-of-the-art methods for antibody analysis to study samples and data from the longest-running dengue/Zika cohort study and extend this unique Nicaraguan cohort into the next critical phase of flaviviral disease in the tropics and subtropics where infection and disease outcomes are modulated by widespread ZIKV immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Modifiable external stressors, including certain chemotherapies and exposure to cigarette smoke, increase the risk of hematologic malignancies through a poorly understood process. Our study will investigate how chemotherapies and cigarette smoke promote the expansion of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells carrying mutations in the DNA damage response pathway to cause clonal hematopoiesis (CH), and how CH progresses toward malignancy in this context. Results from this Project will not only unveil the mechanisms behind CH development and malignant transformation, but may also uncover potential interventions to prevent CH and its progression to hematologic malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative A decrease in skeletal muscle mass is of clinical importance because it is associated with increased morbidity and mortality, as well as a marked deterioration in the quality of life. A broad patient population is affected by significant losses in muscle mass including those afflicted by various systemic diseases, chronic physical inactivity and sarcopenia. The purpose of this grant is to better understand the role of skeletal muscle stem cells (satellite cells) in the blunted growth response to exercise in the elderly, thereby providing a foundation for their therapeutic use to prevent or restore losses in skeletal muscle mass during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Genetic variation contributes to the observable diversity in biological traits found within single species. High levels of genetic variation exist between strains of the most clinically relevant human fungal pathogen, Candida albicans, but the consequences of this variation on its ability to cause disease is significantly understudied. Understanding the genetic differences in C. albicans that lead to more or less severe clinical disease will help identify potential therapeutic targets to reduce the burden of C. albicans pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative As a complement to experimental mouse models in Projects 1 and 2, the human Project in the P01 Project 3 is designed to identify modifiable risk factors for clonal expansion and malignant transformation in an epidemiologic study. Identifying common, modifiable factors that drive clonal expansion and further transformation to hematologic malignancy is closely aligned with the mission of the NCI, as it will provide opportunities to intercept clonal expansion and malignant transformation and enable increased screening and early detection of clonal hematopoiesis in persons at higher risk of hematologic malignancy due to their combined genetic and modifiable risk factor profile.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Although we spend one third of our lives asleep, the molecular mechanisms that regulate sleep remain poorly understood. We will use the powerful and genetically accessible fruit fly to characterize several evolutionarily conserved genes that link brain development and the control of adult sleep-wake cycles. Because these genes are shared with humans, our studies may have broad implications for understanding normal sleep and for the diagnosis and treatment of sleep dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Neutrophils are circulating white cells and the recruitment of neutrophils to the sites of inflammation is a hallmark of the innate immune response. We have shown that neutrophils possess the ability to crawl against the direction of shear flow, and our goal is to identify the key receptors and signals that control upstream migration in neutrophils. We hypothesize that upstream migration helps neutrophils to reach the sites of inflammation faster, and manipulating the factors that aid upstream migration may lead to new ways of treating inflammatory disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired immune cell response leading to chronic inflammation is a major cause of non-healing diabetic wounds. We have identified that increased Notch signaling in diabetic wounds polarizes CD4+T cells in the wound towards an inflammatory TH17 phenotype. This proposal will seek to understand the mechanisms responsible for the altered Notch signaling and will test new cell-targeted nanotherapies to restore immune cell homeostasis and healing in wounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Single Cell Sequencing and Bioinformatics Core (Core A) will provide all Projects with technical and analytical platforms and bioinformatic support to enable lineage tracing and measure molecular responses of both human and murine mutant cells at single-cell resolution. In addition, this Core will use the large-scale epidemiologic data from Project 3 to develop a mathematical model to predict the risk that clonal hematopoiesis transforms into frank hematologic malignancy in older adults. This Core is critical to understanding how cells with specific mutations respond to various modifiable stressors and thus the overall mission of this Program.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This research program will delineate the structural and molecular mechanisms by which hormone-bound progesterone receptor regulates gene transcription that underpins female reproductive processes. Innovative cryo-electron microscopy and structural proteomic approaches, together with inventive in vitro and cell-based assays and state-of-the-art engineered mouse models will elucidate the unique structural importance of a defined functional domain in the progesterone receptor. Accordingly, research outcomes from these investigations will significantly advance our fundamental understanding not only of progesterone control of female reproductive biology but also gynecologic disorders that lead to infertility and other reproductive morbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Neuropsychiatric complications including depression and cognitive decline develop, persist, and even worsen in the years after traumatic brain injury (TBI), negatively affecting the quality of life and lifespan. Mounting evidence indicates that chronic inflammatory processes are active, but the mechanism that drives this response is unclear. Based on our collective data, we hypothesize that increased type I interferon signaling is critical in promoting microglial priming and the subsequent transition from acute inflammation to chronic neuroinflammation after TBI. Therefore, we will use strategies to characterize cell specific responses to TBI, attenuate interferon signaling, and force the turnover of microglia to protect against TBI-induced microglia priming, chronic neuroinflammation, and cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma is a lethal disease often preceded by premalignant lesions making it an ideal disease for screening initiatives. However, current methods cannot reliably differentiate between reactive/inflammatory and dysplastic lesions. Our overall goals are to establish molecular-based prognostic and screening tests to identify high-risk patients most likely to progress to cancer thereby providing lead-time for earlier and potentially more curative interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Project Narrative Intracellular transport of vesicular cargoes, such as insulin granules, by molecular motors along the cell’s cytoskeletal highway is an essential cellular process that is critical to human life. Understanding the molecular underpinnings of this transport process in cells is difficult, due to the investigator’s inability to control the inner workings of the cell. Therefore, this proposal will use an innovative combination of in vitro and in silico model systems in which teams of kinesin and myosin molecular motors navigate physiologically-relevant, lipid-bound cargoes through 3-dimensional cytoskeletal networks, in an effort to define Mother Nature’s design principles that govern intracellular cargo transport.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: There has been immense progress in HIV care and prevention – with more than 25 million people living with HIV receiving antiretroviral therapy, more robust antiretroviral drugs, pre-exposure prophylaxis, and differentiated models of care – yet the burden of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) and cancer is rapidly increasing. At the same time, the threat of antiretroviral and anti-tuberculosis (TB) drug resistance continues, and the COVID-19 pandemic illustrates the vulnerability of health services. This application addresses the emerging pertinent research questions with robust epidemiologic research and innovative implementation science to address the interacting burdens of HIV, TB, NCDs, including cancer and mental health and substance use disorders, and emerging diseases such as COVID-19 across the life course, so that the output from this program of work can translate into improved prevention and treatment programs in sub-Saharan Africa and beyond.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Millions of persons with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa are now surviving for decades on treatment but are devel- oping chronic non-communicable disease complications that require new science and new directions in pre- vention, detection, and treatment. The University of Zambia (UNZA)-Vanderbilt HIV Research Training Partner- ship (UVP) has been extremely successful, achieving all its aims including supporting 11 UNZA PhD students, evaluating and facilitating a new structure for the UNZA PhD Program, and hosting two UNZA Visiting Faculty Scholars at Vanderbilt. We will deepen and extend the impact of UVP in catalyzing UNZA's research capacity by shifting the grant's primary leadership to UNZA, training five UNZA PhD students and four postdoctoral sci- entists, implementating UNZA's new postdoctoral fellowship program, adding two South-South partnerships with the University of the Witwatersrand and the Consortium for Advanced Research Training in Africa (CARTA), and establishing a Biostatistics Support Core service at UNZA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical shortage of Academic Radiologists who are rigorously trained in Biomedical Imaging Research. These highly skilled and trained individuals are crucial to advance research in imaging and image-guided therapies, which will directly impact patient care. This new generation of Academic Radiologists will be essential to maximize the healthcare benefits that will come from interdisciplinary translational research linking advances in the sciences of genomics, proteomics and artificial intelligence with the ongoing technological evolution in Biomedical Imaging

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research to advance understanding of the development and progression of diseases and disabilities such as substance use and HIV that contribute to health disparities is a major goal of the National Institutes of Health's strategic research plan to reduce and ultimately eliminate health disparities. Innovative, evidence- based interventions that rely on well-researched and culturally-specific theories of human behavior are urgently needed to stem the rising tide of HIV and substance use. The Substance Use and HIV Prevention Research in Minority Communities research education and mentoring program aims to address this urgent research need through offering seed funding to promising clinical scientists to conduct applied research studies and a mentoring infrastructure to empower these scientists to successfully apply for and receive NIH funding to conduct rigorous, multiyear research projects in the communities most affected by the HIV and substance use epidemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The obesity epidemic presents an unprecedented challenge to the nation’s health systems, and existing gold standard behavioral weight loss treatments are highly expensive to implement due to their intensive, long-term nature and the highly trained clinicians required to deliver treatment. Approaches to decreasing costs (e.g., low intensity treatments, coaching by paraprofessionals rather than experts) have been implemented with moderate success, but weight losses are not consistent across different cost-saving approaches, suggesting that individuals may be best served when they are matched to the type of treatment they need, and when the resources matched to individuals are continuously adapted as their needs change. The primary goal of the proposed project is to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of an artificial intelligence (AI) system that continuously adjusts features of weight loss coaching including modality and coach skill level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This T35 program is designed to develop in future physicians - at the end of their first year of medical school - an interest in, and hands-on appreciation of, biomedical research as a career and as a critical basis for better understanding the science that constitutes much of the medical literature and medical practice. Under supervision of a selected faculty member, some students, we expect, will be inspired by this experience to pursue careers in biomedical research; virtually all will be enabled to make better-informed decisions with respect to the practical applications of basic and clinical biomedical research, and to identify clinical problems that might be susceptible to basic or clinical research approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants born preterm are exceptionally prone to life-threatening gut-associated pathology, most notably necrotizing enterocolitis. The neonatal gut presents unique challenges because mechanisms that shape mucosal immune development through host-microbe interactions are still largely unknown. I propose to fill the knowledge gaps regarding early life mucosal immune development and dysbiosis by addressing the relevance of sphingolipids, mainly sphingosine-1-phosphate, in directing this intricate relationship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MSTEM scientists are not representative of race, ethnicity, gender, disability or socioeconomic status demographics in the general population. In order to increase underrepresented and disadvantaged researchers in aging and to fully understand the complexities of aging among the growing minority population in the US, the proposed program, Investigators from Novices, a Transdisciplinary Research Education Program to Increase Diversity (INTREPID) in aging research, will provide MSTEM-students an environment that promotes student affinity toward older adults, opportunities for research experiences, and support for successful undergraduate completion, and pursuit of a graduate research degree. Having underrepresented and disadvantaged researchers in aging will have the potential to increase understanding of the relationship between health disparities and aging, and the development of interventions to improve the health of all older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Here, we seek to test a core mechanistic hypothesis: The impact of beta-amyloid (Aβ) burden on anxiety is orchestrated through Aβ-related impairment of NREM slow-wave sleep, which in turn, amplifies next-day anxiety through impaired mPFC-amygdala emotional brain regulation. If supportive, these studies would (i) advance our basic understanding of how Alzheimer’s disease-related pathology mechanistically impacts the core neuropsychiatric symptom of anxiety through impairment of NREM sleep, and (ii) establish sleep improvement as a novel modifiable therapeutic intervention target that may de- escalate anxiety linked with the Alzheimer’s disease state, and potentially the rate of longitudinal disease/cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The peptide neurotensin is known to play a critical role in modulating the activity of dopamine neurons in the brain, affecting reward-related behaviors and the response to drugs of abuse. However, much remains unknown regarding the specific circuits that release neurotensin and the interaction between neurotensin and other co-released neurotransmitters. This proposal utilizes advanced genetic and imaging techniques to address these questions, aiming to further our understanding of how neurotensin circuits govern motivated behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinitis pigmentosa is an inherited blinding condition that affects an estimated 1 out of 3,500 Americans and currently does not have any curative treatments. The project will also use mice with retinitis pigmentosa to evaluate new strategies for treating this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A defining requirement for life is the efficient and accurate copying of the cellular genome, and perturbations in single steps of this complex, multi-step process can destabilize a cell's genome and contribute to developmental disorders, stem-cell aging, or cancer. Genome duplication relies on specific proteins working precisely with each other and with the genome itself. The goal of this proposal is to understand how the conserved proteins that control the first step of genome duplication in eukaryotic cells are regulated in cells and interact with the genome to promote and maintain cell health and identity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Selfish meiotic drive loci are poorly-understood genetic elements with non- intuitive activities, and can gain unfair transmission into the next generation even though their activities can be deleterious. We discovered that quickly-evolving small interfering RNA loci defend against de novo meiotic drive loci in testis. Our proposed studies of these intragenomic battles, using invertebrate and vertebrate systems, will elucidate new concepts in the fields of small RNA biology, spermatogenesis, reproductive isolation and evolution.

PHR: Defects in cellular polarity are associated with numerous neurological disorders, kidney diseases, and cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement High salt consumption in the Western diet leads to inflammation and cardiovascular disease but the mechanisms are not known. A major problem with excess dietary intake is salt sensitivity of blood pressure, which is an increase or decrease in blood pressure when salt intake increases or decreases respectively, and is an independent predictor of death due to cardiovascular disease. Our proposed studies to determine the interplay between immune cell activation and tissue sodium accumulation in contributing to salt sensitivity of blood pressure may lead to better diagnosis and treatment of this important risk factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is a major risk factor for spinal disc degeneration and associated chronic back pain, a significant disease burden but with no effective treatments. Understanding the molecular and cellular basis of disc development and age-associated changes will help develop therapeutics for disc pathologies. The proposed study aims to understand the role of crucial developmental signaling pathways in postnatal disc growth and maintenance and test its beneficial potential in preventing and reversing age-associated degenerative changes in the disc.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a debilitating condition characterized by altered neural circuitry and it is twice as common among women compared to men. The current study will use high-density EEG to probe resting state and event-related neurophysiological deficits in PTSD, as well as estradiol and progesterone assays to determine the moderating effect of menstrual cycle phase on these phenomena. By leveraging advanced EEG techniques and hormone assay, this study will ultimately contribute to the personalization of PTSD treatments for women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA methylation regulates pluripotency, differentiation and tissue-specific gene expression thus playing a key role in normal development. Dnmt3b is a critical DNA methyltransferase involved in epigenome remodeling soon after conception. Understanding molecular mechanisms utilizing various Dnmt3b activities in embryogenesis, postnatal development and in assisted reproductive technologies will provide fundamental knowledge about processes governing mammalian development and may lead to new therapeutic strategies in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PUBLIC NARRATIVE Ribosomes are large cellular complexes that synthesize proteins. In addition, ribosomes regulate bacterial stress responses, and human neurodevelopment and synaptic plasticity. Dysregulation of these processes leads to disease. Understanding how ribosomes control gene expression requires high-resolution characterization of ribosome movements and interactions. We will use biochemical and cryo-EM methods to address the mechanisms of translation regulation, which may pave the way to development of therapeutics against bacterial and genetic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autophagy is a conserved process of cellular recycling that degrades surplus or damaged molecules and organelles, with profound impacts on several areas of human health, from tumorigenesis and cancer cell survival to neurodegeneration, inflammation and aging. Potential therapeutic approaches that involve inhibiting or potentiating autophagy require a greater understanding of the mechanisms by which this process is regulated. Studies outlined in this proposal use a Drosophila model system to identify these key control points, focusing on how the Target of Rapamycin (TOR) pathway is controlled by upstream and feedback signals, and how it controls the trafficking and degradation of autophagic cargo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This study focuses on the mechanisms of action of Aire, the protein encoded by the gene mutated in individuals with APECED (or APS-1), a primary immunodeficiency disease characterized by multi-organ autoimmunity. While APECED patients are rather rare, the Aire pathway – via polymorphisms in either Aire target-loci or in the gene encoding Aire itself – has been implicated in several of the more common autoimmune disorders, including type-1 diabetes, myasthenia gravis, vitiligo and pernicious anemia. Targeting of new cellular and molecular interactions and pathways highlighted in this study may have therapeutic potential; in addition, we should learn about the optimum points for intervening in autoimmune disease course.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria continually generate two types of energy, ATP (the chemical energy of the cell) and heat (called mitochondrial thermogenesis), and a fine balance of energy distribution between these two forms of energy defines metabolic cell homeostasis. Using the novel mitochondrial patch-clamp technique combined with modern cellular and molecular techniques, this project will provide new insights into the mechanisms that control mitochondrial thermogenesis to readjust cell metabolism for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite extensive advancements in the field of clinical and translational research, numerous roadblocks continue to stand in the way of delivering clinical interventions more efficiently, effectively, and equitably. In this application, Harvard Catalyst is proposed as a clinical and translational science laboratory that will work to develop, demonstrate, and disseminate innovations capable of overcoming these roadblocks and, ultimately, improving human health. Harvard Catalyst will leverage the unique expertise of 17 affiliated, but independent, institutions across the Boston biomedical ecosystem to address these challenges, placing particular emphasis on supporting early stage and underrepresented in medicine investigators and their teams.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The most common route of toxicologic exposures is via inhalation yet training in this discipline is lacking nation-wide and is absent in this Appalachian region where significant health disparities and systemic toxicities are rampant due to a plethora of environmental risks and socioeconomic disadvantages. The Center for Inhalation Toxicology and major inhalation exposure research infrastructure anchors and augments the impact of the unique triangulation of the West Virginia University Health Sciences Center, School of Engineering, Hospital, and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. The Predoctoral Training in Systems Toxicology Program will formalize and standardize our already strong training programs in the biomedical sciences and focus on inhalation toxicology research by creating a new generation of young scholars who can address the demand for innovative toxicology research for the greater health benefits of the citizens of West Virginia, Appalachia, and the nation.
PROJECT_TERMS: pre-doctoral;System;Toxicology;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Pre-doctoral Training in Systems Toxicology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease, affecting one in seven adults, is a major risk factor for adverse health outcomes. Measures of kidney function are currently limited in that they do not accurately represent kidney health or do not detect disease until irreversible damage has occurred. The proposed research introduces an MRI-based method for quantifying renal metabolic rate of oxygen, which is elevated during early diabetic kidney disease and a key cause of kidney hypoxia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Racial inequities in health are well-known. While their underlying causes are poorly understood, evidence indicates that our neighborhoods play an important role. We examine the ways in which historical and contemporary features of the neighborhood might change certain molecules related to our genes. It may be that these "epigenomic" changes are the mechanism that link racially unequal neighborhoods to health inequities.

ORG_NAME: CONFERENCE OF RADIATION CONTROL PROG DIR
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this cooperative agreement is to coordinate Federal, State, and Tribal activities to achieve effective solutions to both current and future radiation control challenges. The efforts of volunteers across the nation plus the adoption and implementation of the guidance, recommendations, and procedures provided under this project will provide for improved quality in radiation protection programs throughout the United States. The overall impact of these cooperative efforts will ultimately reduce the risk of illness and deaths associated with unnecessary radiation exposure from all sources and improve the quality of medical radiation imaging and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE . The proposed research serves public health with its novel focus to improve pediatric liver transplant outcomes by assessing and intervening on children’s underlying health-related social risks, e.g., material economic hardship, social isolation, caregiver mental health, health literacy, and neighborhood characteristics. Integrating a Health Advocate as a member of the post-transplant care team will support the delivery of interventions to overcome barriers interposed by these social risks, with clear potential to close disparities and significantly improve long-term outcomes for these children. The proposed research is directly relevant to NIDDK’s vision to seek insights and answers to bridge health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Recombineering-based no-cleavage gene-editing toolkit for large-scale genome engineering and functional screening As gene-editing tools help unravel mechanisms of biological process such as tissue development and human diseases such as cancer, a remaining challenge is that our current gene-editing tools are often limited to making small genome changes like single-nucleotide variants. The key bottleneck is the lack of efficient, safe, and robust tools to study large genome changes. Thus, it demands new modalities of genome engineering tools that we proposes to develop here, leveraging novel class of no-cleavage recombineering-based mechanisms, pushing our ability to engineer, track, and control cellular genomes and proteomes.

PHR: The goal of this project is to provide support for mentoring and research in the clinical epidemiology of cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes. Dr. Selvin has a strong track record of success in the field and in mentoring junior scientists. With support from this K24, Dr. Selvin will be able to continue her mentorship activities, strengthen her research portfolio, and recruit and train the next generation of leaders in the field.

PHR: Narrative Understanding the role of stromal-epithelial interactions in the etiology of BPH is key to the development of new therapeutics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative: Intrinsically disordered proteins are a recently recognized class of proteins that do not fit classical structure/function paradigms, but participate in fundamental physiological processes. The prevalence and role of such proteins in mediating and regulating critical membrane trafficking and organization pathways required for cell function and survival is only now becoming appreciated. This project aims to clarify mechanisms that link the structural and dynamical properties of disordered proteins to their ability to orchestrate membrane fusion reactions and to organize intracellular membranous compartments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neurons are continuously born in the hippocampal neurogenic niche in the brain, and how they mature and integrate into existing circuits can have a large impact on hippocampal dependent behaviors and learning and memory. We have found that kainate receptors (a family of glutamate receptors) regulate the maturation of newborn neurons, which could account for their roles in affective behaviors and memory processes. Understanding these mechanisms will potentially provide insight into developing new therapies for age related memory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address the urgent need for new therapies for glioma, the most common type of brain tumor, we tested hundreds of chemicals and discovered that drugs targeting a specific metabolic pathway preferentially kill brain tumor cells with a mutation in a gene called IDH1, which is a very common genetic alteration in this disease. In this proposal, we seek to understand why cells with IDH1 mutations die in response to inhibition of this metabolic pathway and to determine whether a newly developed drug that targets this metabolic pathway shows activity in preclinical models of glioma. Successful achievement of these research goals will lay the preclinical foundation necessary to advance this treatment strategy toward a clinical trial for brain tumor patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to a low but present risk of potentially life-threatening blood infection or bacterial meningitis, and a lack of evidence-based tools to help guide clinicians in their management, thousands of young infants 61 to 90 days old with fever undergo lumbar punctures and are hospitalized each year, with substantial differences in testing and hospitalization depending on the emergency department where the infant receives care. Because of this variability in care and the many unnecessary lumbar punctures and hospitalizations of these infants, there is a pressing need to derive a clinical prediction rule that can guide the management of infants 61 to 90 days old evaluated for fever in the emergency department. The objective of this project is to develop a clinical prediction rule that will allow clinicians to identify infants 61 to 90 days old with fever at low versus non-negligible risk of blood infection and bacterial meningitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The failure to form proper physical connections with chromosomes during mitosis can result in errors in chromosome numbers or cause chromosome rearrangements. In both cases, these defects are thought to contribute to tumor progression and birth defects. Understanding the means by which these units of DNA, and the genetic information that they contain, are properly distributed to new cells is critical for the diagnosis and treatment of disease. This proposed work will analyze the mechanisms by which a key cell division structure (termed the kinetochore) associates with both DNA and the rod-like microtubule polymers from the mitotic spindle that provides the structure and force to segregate the chromosomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The underlying gene regulatory networks and genome architecture of muscle stem (satellite) cells are largely unexplored. In this proposal, we will explore epigenome regulatory mechanisms that establish myogenic precursor identity, setting the stage for myogenic differentiation. Our findings will shed important light on the satellite cell epigenome and its three dimensional architecture, provide a deeper understanding of the ability of these cells to regenerate, and provide insights into new avenues for treatment of age-and disease-associated muscle wasting.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the sexual phenotype –or gender -has far reaching implications for human health and well-being. Trainee research on steroid hormones, maternal stress, changing environments, maternal and infant health, and healthy sexual behavior and reproduction, using human, non- human model systems, and evolutionarily diverse non-model systems will lead to insights into the basic mechanisms of reproduction and development and to understanding of the physiological differences between the sexes and their influence on illness and health outcomes, all of which will be valuable to policy makers, medical research, and health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative: This training grant aims to continue to develop research scientists that are well versed in physics, biology, mathematics, chemistry, engineering and computer science, and who also understand the application of these disciplines to the instruments and techniques used in the diagnosis, monitoring and treatment of disease as well as research fields that help us understand basic mechanisms of disease. These scientists will become actively involved in research into new methods that seek earlier diagnosis of disease as well as more specific (patient specific, disease specific) treatments of disease in many clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is relevant to public health in that it addresses a rapidly growing group of patients with cancer, older adults (≥70 years), with the goal of delivering psychotherapy (i.e., the CARE intervention) to older adults with limited access to mental health services. Research indicates that older adults with medical illnesses and depression have difficulty adhering to aftercare, are not typically connected to mental health services, and are at high risk for completing suicide, yet they continue to be overlooked in routine clinical encounters; these risks are elevated among individuals living in rural areas. Thus, this study is aligned with the NCI’s goals of improving the reach and quality of cancer care for older adults, with an emphasis on rural populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Our work explores the ways in which diverse bacteria create cellular compartments to store iron and produce highly ordered magnetic nanoparticles. These particles have many potential biomedical applications including their potential use as MRI contrast agents, as vehicles for targeted delivery of drugs and as a medium to kill tumors using heat. By understanding the molecular details of these naturally occurring processes, we hope to identify new drug targets for combatting bacterial pathogens and to facilitate a more rational design of next generation biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Treatment advances in psychosis may be limited by the use of phenomenology-defined diagnoses based on symptomatic outcomes, rather than by neurobiological constructs monitored by quantitative characteristics. The Bipolar-Schizophrenia Network for Intermediate Phenotypes (B-SNIP) uses biomarkers to define psychosis subgroups with the goal of testing the advantages of B-SNIP biomarkers for diagnostic and therapeutic decisions, consistent with principles in the NIMH Strategic Plan. We propose to test Biotype1 psychosis subgroup with clozapine, and predict a differential clinical response to clozapine compared with Biotype2, marked by normalization of IEA, cortical attractor network activity and an advantage over usual antipsychotic drugs, establishing low IEA in Biotype1 as a predictive biomarker for clozapine efficacy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delirium is a devasting acute confusional state that is common in older adults after surgery or in the hospital, especially with Alzheimer's disease. This project investigates the molecular mechanisms that link inflammation to impaired metabolism in delirium and Alzheimer's disease, and how small molecule metabolites with roles in aging might lead to metabolic therapies for delirium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The penicillin binding protein-targeting β-lactams have been a mainstay therapeutic option for infections caused by enteric gram negative bacteria for more than 50 years. Efficacy of these agents is threatened by the continued expansion of β-lactamases (e.g., NDM) that contribute to carbapenem resistance in Enterobacterales including subtypes that are refractory to clinically available β-lactams or β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combinations. This application focuses on the development of a cyclic boronate PBP inhibitor that circumvents class-specific resistance to β-lactams, resets the resistance clock and offers a new intravenous therapeutic option for the treatment of infections caused by carbapenem-resistant Enterobacterales (CRE).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Treatment advances in psychosis are limited by the use of phenomenology-defined diagnoses based on symptomatic outcomes, rather than by neurobiological constructs monitored by quantitative characteristics. The Bipolar-Schizophrenia Network for Intermediate Phenotypes (B-SNIP) uses biomarkers to define psychosis subgroups with the goal of testing the advantages of B-SNIP biomarkers for diagnostic and therapeutic decisions, consistent with principles in the NIMH Strategic Plan. We propose to test Biotype1 psychosis subgroup with clozapine, and predict a differential clinical response to clozapine compared with Biotype2, marked by normalization of IEA, cortical attractor network activity and an advantage over usual antipsychotic drugs, establishing low IEA in Biotype1 as a predictive biomarker for clozapine efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Retinal neurons exhibit either excitation or inhibition to light inputs. In the dim light ambient conditions, two kinds of photoreceptors may interrupt each other, inducing mixed excitatory and inhibitory responses in the downstream neurons. We will investigate the cellular light responses and the mechanisms because both rod and cone dysfunction cause reduced vision in the mesopic vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In this proposal, we will perform a comprehensive study to identify the germline genetic variations that predispose individuals to development of MGUS and those that contribute to increased risk of progression to MM among those that have MGUS. We also will examine how these genetic findings differ based on race and how they compare to existing clinical factors, in order to develop a targeted screening approach that in the long run will allow earlier intervention and eventual prevention of active MM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop a comprehensive set of computational methods for advanced analytics in genome-wide association studies. These new methods will facilitate integrative analysis of genome-wide association studies with gene expression mapping studies, investigation of causal relationship among complex traits, and genetic prediction of phenotypes with polygenic risk scores. These methods are essential for understanding the transcriptomic and causal mechanism underlying common diseases, enabling accurate and robust genetic prediction of disease risks, and facilitating biological discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As of 2015, 30 million Americans (9.4% of the US population) had diabetes and it was the seventh leading cause of death based on 79,535 death certificates. Despite a $327 billion investment in diabetes care in 2017, 31% of those with diabetes have a hemoglobin A1c >9%, well above goal and greatly increasing the risk for diabetes related complications. Recent innovations in diabetes technology may finally allow implanted, fully autonomous, insulin delivery; the purpose of the present study is to evaluate the features of intraperitoneal insulin and its potential for future use in a full closed-loop implanted insulin delivery system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-translational modifications of histones and transcription factors are critical to gene function and misregulated in several diseases. We are developing chemical strategies to investigate the biophysical and biochemical effects of histone sumoylation and p53 methylation in human chromatin. Our studies will reveal new mechanisms underlying chromatin regulation and provide new therapeutic targets in diseases arising from its misregulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the Crumbs homologue-1 (CRB1) gene lead to severe blinding disorders including retinitis pigmentosa and Leber congenital amaurosis. To date, there is no treatment for CRB1-mediated retinal diseases, and classical gene augmentation techniques are complicated by the expression of multiple CRB1 isoforms in cell-type-distinct localizations within the retina. This project will develop a CRB1 isoform-independent prime editing approach by establishing retinal organoid disease models and preclinical vectors in order to establish proof-of-concept for CRB1 prime editing therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Proteins at the cell surface can be transported into the cell and then returned to the cell surface. This process, known as endocytic recycling, regulates the function of many proteins. We are proposing studies to elucidate in mechanistic detail how endocytic recycling occurs. This understanding will also shed insights into disease mechanisms, as endocytic recycling plays many important physiologic roles.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: After a brain bleeding, hematoma mass and blood components from the clot can cause blood-brain barrier disruption, brain edema formation, brain cell death and neurological deficits. The purposes of this project are to investigate the mechanisms of brain injury after hemorrhage and to develop effective therapies. The long-term goal of our studies is to limit brain damage following brain hemorrhage.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many neurological disorders such as stroke, spinal cord injury, Parkinson’s disease, and cerebral palsy manifest in a class of motor impairments called hyper-resistance characterized by increased joint resistance to passive motion that encompasses spasticity, rigidity, and dystonia. This project will identify poorly understood neural mechanisms of hyper-resistance, demonstrate how they may be identified through clinically feasible assessments, and develop predictive computational models to identify rational, individual-specific targets for novel treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to fill important gaps of knowledge in cell migration, which is essential for many physiological and pathological processes such as embryonic development, wound healing, and cancerous invasion. We will use a top-down approach that treats migrating cells as an integrated mechanical system, and we are developing technologies such as 3D printing and artificial intelligence for fabricating experimental environments, following cell movements, and imaging interactions in 3D scaffolds. Knowledge in how migrating cells interact with the environment and with each other is expected to further our abilities to counter diseases and restore body functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of the proposed renewal of this cancer education training project is to train oncology care providers to implement tobacco use assessment and treatment (TUAT) in their cancer care settings. This goal remains important because approximately 10-30% of cancer patients are smokers when diagnosed, and approximately 70% of patients will continue to smoke after their diagnosis. Building on the successful educational accomplishments of the past funding period, this project will implement and evaluate a TUAT skills development course and collaborative training initiative that will train and provide technical assistance to oncology care professionals to implement TUAT at their respective institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Utilizing data from three longitudinal birth cohorts, we will examine the impact of air pollution on the epigenome and the onset of childhood anxiety and depression symptoms. We will investigate DNA methylation biomarkers using an unbiased epigenome-wide approach to advance our understanding of potential molecular pathways involved in air pollution neurotoxicity and/or anxiety and depression pathophysiology. The findings of this study will help identify not only key molecular pathways but also significant markers and modifiable predictors of anxiety and depression which could be used to identify at-risk youth for anxiety and depression and better inform timed-interventions focused on reducing exposure to air pollution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Injury to the cochlea results in activation and infiltration of immune cells into the cochlea, where these cells play beneficial roles via fractalkine signaling in repairing damaged hair cell synapses and promoting long-term survival of spiral ganglion neurons (SGNs) that carry sound information to the brain. Our goal is to understand the mechanisms of fractalkine-mediated neuroprotection in the injured cochlea and to define the relationship between genetic mutations in human fractalkine signaling and noise-induced hearing loss. Knowledge gained from these studies will advance prevention of SGN loss and identify novel treatment strategies for successful cochlear implantation and help in identification of individuals who are at greater risk of hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS), a withdrawal condition due to in utero drug exposure, affects over 32,000 newborns in the U.S annually, and its incidence continues to grow concurrent with the opioid crisis. The association between NAS and long-term neurodevelopment is largely unknown. This project will examine the relationship between NAS and longitudinal academic performance and explore targets for future interventions aimed at improving educational outcomes in children with a history of NAS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study aims to answer the fundamental questions of how bacteria utilize a compendium of signaling nucleotides to adapt to their specific environmental niches and to survive fluctuating environments. We combine metabolomics and proteomics with genetic, biochemical and biophysical approaches to study how stress-signaling nucleotides (p)ppGpp, pGpp, (p)ppApp and AppppA regulate cellular processes including metabolism and development in response to nutritional, temperature and antibiotic stresses. Our goal is to establish fundamental principles using model organisms such as the Gram-positive bacterium Bacillus subtilis and apply our research to pathogenic bacteria to solve global issues including widespread antibiotic resistance in pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Increasing physical activity is critical to improving health, but the efficacy of physical activity interventions may be influenced by the context in which individuals are trying to increase this healthy behavior. Robust examination of pooled data from physical activity intervention trials across the U.S. will allow for a better understanding of how built and social environment factors affect physical activity outcomes and also how critical individual demographics impact these effects. Findings could rapidly and efficiently identify who will be responsive to existing physical activity interventions in what contexts and encourage innovation in changing interventions to better match environmental contexts of individuals seeking to increase physical activity.

PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): We are examining the role of the myosin molecular motor during aging of healthy and diseased muscles and are attempting to ameliorate muscle degeneration. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: Relevance Repetitive visual stimulation (RVS) is a powerful driver of plasticity; just a few minutes of exposure can lead to a long lasting strengthening of neural responses. This could be beneficial to improve vision in amblyopia, in neuropsychiatric patients with reduced brain responses, or even in healthy subjects as a way to improve visual cognition. This project investigates a newly developed, improved method of RVS that has the potential to generate widespread behavioral improvements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative One repeated feature of a number of longevity-extending interventions in animal models is that they result in reduced body size; in addition, a similar pattern in seen in natural genetic variation of wild type animals where small mice and dogs are longer lived than their larger counterparts. One pathway that has been found to be associated with age and body size is tryptophan metabolism to kynurenine; however, the direct of effects of tryptophan metabolism manipulation on aging and longevity are unknown. Here, I attempt to discover the metabolic changes that are associated with size and lifespan with specific focus on tryptophan degradation to kynurenine with the goal of developing a potential new target for lifespan and healthspan interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Narrative Candida albicans is a fungus that causes oropharyngeal candidiasis (thrush) in some people but is tolerated without symptoms in the mouth and gut in most individuals. We will use a mouse model to study host factors that lead to tolerance or disease including expression of enzymes (arginase and kallikreins) in the oral epithelium, and the recruitment of inflammatory cells including neutrophils and myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSC) that may help clear or dampen host response to fungal infection. We propose that MDSCs are a novel and unexplored arm of oral epithelial immunity that contribute to oral and gut tolerance, therefore understanding their function will guide future strategies to reduce the immune escape of C. albicans and add to our understanding of host tolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Ulcerative colitis patients have an increased risk of dysplasia and colon cancer because the constant inflammation of the colon causes damage to the intestinal lining. We believe that the bacteria in the colon and the immune system feed off each other to cause inflammation and more damage. We will use the most up to date methods and human specimens to tease apart how the immune system and the gut bacteria conspire to cause pre-cancerous lesions in colitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rapid expansion of the aging ethnic/racial and linguistic minority population is outstripping the capacity to offer disability prevention services necessary to respond to their needs. PHR: Project Narrative This project will assess whether cells within the liver serve as viral reservoirs in HIV- infected individuals. This information will provide a fuller understanding of how HIV is able to persist under antiretroviral therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Approximately one fourth of the adults in the U.S. suffer from multi-morbidity, experiencing two or more chronic cardio-metabolic diseases. For interventions to interrupt the progression to having multiple chronic conditions and disparities in multi-morbidity, it is necessary to understand how these unfold across adulthood. In this study, we will provide national estimates of the burden of multi-morbidity across adulthood, of the progression from one chronic disease to multi-morbidity, and of how trajectories of multi-morbidity contribute to health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The cellular mechanisms of fibrotic tendon healing are not well-defined, leading to a critical lack of therapeutic targets. Persistence of matrix-producing myofibroblasts is the dominant driver of tissue fibrosis and there is clear evidence that myofibroblast function depends on the fibroblast-lineage from which it is derived. In this proposal we will define lineage-specific contributions to myofibroblast fate and establish that disruption of NFB-mediated myofibroblast survival and persistence promotes regenerative tendon healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Congenital heart defects (CHD) are the most common birth defects, impacting ~1 in every 100 births and while patient outcomes have improved over time, morbidity and mortality remain high for some children, and significant variation exists across the ~120 U.S. congenital heart hospitals. Using a clinical registry containing detailed clinical data from virtually all U.S. congenital heart hospitals, we will apply Bayesian machine learning within a causal inference framework to best utilize the diversity of the data to improve CHD surgical quality assessments. Our proposed research will support national initiatives to improve quality and outcomes for children and families impacted in CHD and will also provide a framework that can be applied broadly to improve quality assessments across other fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The American Burn Association estimates that ~450,000 people in the United States will suffer burn injury each year, resulting in ~3,500 deaths with concomitant inhalation injury increasing the morbidity and mortality. We have discovered that the transcription factor Nuclear Factor-Erythroid-2-Related Factor (NRF2) is essential for controlling the morbidity and mortality associated with burn injury but is not robust enough to control the immune dysfunction promoting long-term susceptibility to infection. Using animal models and clinical specimens, we will elucidate NRF2-driven cell specific mechanisms, test whether the activation state of NRF2 can predict patient outcome, and evaluate whether pharmacological activation of NRF2-driven pathways using novel microparticle formulations represent a viable therapeutic approach for the treatment of burn-injury induced immune dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it fills a gap in our understanding of modifiable determinants of acquired hearing loss. This work will characterize Black-White differences in cochleopathy associated with Stage 2 Hypertension, a chronic condition that is most prevalent in the Black population. This research will produce a positive impact through providing reliable data regarding the link between HTN and cochlear vulnerability and will support future development of timely audiological assessment and responsive interventions, especially in underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Rijo-Ferreira, Filipa Project Narrative Malaria parasites invade, replicate and burst host’s red blood cells in a synchronized manner, leading to rhythmic fevers. The proposed research will investigate how malaria parasites process daily rhythms within their hosts to regulate the synchronized development. When parasite and host rhythms are mismatched, infection is disturbed, therefore, uncovering the mechanism by which malaria coordinate their 24h periodicity will have an impact on understanding and treating this deadly infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rehabilitation and recovery from neuropsychiatric illness depends on engaging mechanisms of neuroplasticity (the changes in synaptic connections between neurons in the brain), and a major regulator of neuroplasticity is the moment-to moment-state of the brain (attention, emotions, arousal, etc.), but this is poorly understood, especially in humans, and may be particularly important for plasticity-induction brain stimulation therapies like repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS), although this is rarely considered in practice. The goal of this research is to measure how attention (an experimentally tractable, well-understood, and disease- relevant brain state) regulates rTMS-induced neuroplasticity in two different parts of the human visual spatial attention circuit: visual cortex (the target of visual attention) and frontal eye fields (the cortical source of visual attention). These experiments will produce fundamental knowledge to augment the efficacy of rehabilitative neuromodulation therapies for visual disorders including hemineglect, scotoma, and amblyopia as well as sa range of other neuropsychiatric disorders (depression, addiction, attention deficit disorder, stroke, traumatic brain injury, chronic pain syndrome, and others).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Voice disorders resulting from aberrant scar formation in the vocal folds are challenging to treat and result in long term dysfunction for patients. This project aims to quantify improvements in wound healing and tissue biomechanics for vocal fold scar using a novel dose- controllable, injectable therapeutic delivery loaded with corticosteroid. Long-term goals of this line of research are to develop a platform to optimize wound healing of the voice box through novel drug delivery approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: High-risk medications for anesthesia, sedation and pain are frequently prescribed and administered by dentists to children and have resulted in serious unintended consequences, but unique challenges with prescribing high-risk medications to pediatric dental patients are not well understood. Understanding patterns of dental prescribing and factors associated with adverse safety outcomes can inform training models and interventions to improve evidence-based practice, ultimately decreasing risks of serious adverse events and mortality among children. Thus, this project is relevant to the NICHD high research priority to improve systems of care which can mitigate medical errors and advance child health.
