IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Balancing stem cell renewal and progenitor differentiation in the intestine is critical for maintaining a robust epithelial lining with replete with highly specialized absorptive and secretory cells. We have discovered that the nuclear receptor Liver Receptor Homolog-1 (LRH-1, NR5A2) mediates stem cell survival while also driving differentiation of hormone producing enteroendocrine cells. This proposal investigates the mechanisms controlling the separate functional roles of LRH-1 in stem and differentiating cells, highlighting how unique cellular contexts can modulate nuclear receptor activity in healthy and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cocaine addiction is a chronic, progressive, and compulsive disorder with cycles of craving and relapse to drug seeking, which are driven by powerful cue-drug memories. The proposed research will use neurobiological techniques to reduce the ability of cocaine-cue memories to induce relapse by altering memory reconsolidation processes. Novel behavioral methods combined with pharmacological and optogenetic tools will be used in rat models to destabilize cocaine-cue memories to subsequently reduce the ability of cocaine cues to induce relapse-like behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Significant progress in detection and treatment has reduced cancer mortality rates; however, with over 1.7 million new cases and 600,000 deaths from cancer reported in 2019, it remains a major health concern in the US. Advances in our understanding of fundamental biological mechanisms that promote oncogenesis have progressed at an unparalleled rate and provide a seedbed for the novel therapeutic interventions. The current challenge is to close this widening gap between laboratory discoveries and their clinical applications in the fight against cancer. Inspiring and training the next generation of cancer researchers and oncologists is central to accelerate the translation of research breakthroughs into new diagnostics and therapeutics. Towards this goal, the Nathan Schnaper Intern Program in Translational Research at the University of Maryland Greenebaum Comprehensive Cancer Center integrates research, educational and clinical training components that build on its strong history to train the next generation of cancer researchers and oncologists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is focused on discovering new therapies for kidney diseases affecting how much water is in the body. Sometimes this process is not balanced, leading to diseases such as hypertension (too much fluid in the body) and dehydration (too much urine production). Our work is aimed at identifying basic mechanism in kidney cells that cause these diseases in order to develop drugs to cure them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite recent gains in overall life expectancy in the US, racial/ethnic health disparities in older adults persist and are widening. The Affordable Care Act insurance coverage expansions have shown promise for reducing disparities in access and health, but the impact on middle-aged and older adults is less clear. The study will investigate whether the Affordable Care Act coverage expansions were associated with reduced racial/ethnic disparities in coverage, access to care, medical costs, use of care, and overall health for middle-aged and older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Histone deacetylases (HDACs), a family of epigenetic enzymes that regulate gene expression by chemically modifying chromatin, are altered in Parkinson disease and dementia with Lewy bodies and may contribute to their development and their course. Employing [11C]Martinostat, the first radiotracer that labels HDACs in living humans, the overall goals of this proposal are (1) to evaluate brain HDAC levels and regional distribution with [11C]Martinostat in patients with Parkinson disease, Parkinson disease dementia, and dementia with Lewy bodies, compared to Alzheimer’s disease and normal control subjects; and (2) to determine how regional [11C]Martinostat binding at baseline and over time relates to motor, cognitive, and behavioral features and their progression as well as to amyloid burden in these diseases. Together, these efforts will clarify the contribution of regional brain dysregulation of HDAC epigenetic control of gene expression during life to Parkinson disease, Parkinson disease dementia, and dementia with Lewy bodies and their clinical features.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent work from our groups and others has shown that cancer cells bearing mutations in genes controlling a process known as RNA splicing are exquisitely sensitive to drugs that block the machinery that carries out RNA splicing. Because the safety and efficacy of this specific class of drugs is not yet known, here we propose to study an additional means to target RNA splicing by inhibiting a process known as protein arginine methylation. This study may have great therapeutic potential because a number of drugs targeting protein arginine methylation are entering early phase clinical trials now.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. Current tick identification methods are highly resource and labor intensive, requiring physical collection of specimens and subsequent identification of species, sex, life stage, and engorgement by an acarologist based on visual morphological inspection. Here we propose to advance a prototype deep learning system capable of instantaneously and accurately identifying twelve medically-relevant adult tick species with 98% accuracy for practical deployment in professional public health and the general public. The resulting products developed through this proposal will ultimately expand tick surveillance capability and capacity, and strengthen public health response to tick-borne diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older individuals with chronic musculoskeletal disorders face challenges in arranging in-person visits for their care due to the scarcity of resources or fear of viral transmission during the current global pandemic. While telehealth visits have become increasingly available through various video conferencing apps, existing technologies fail to provide the quantitative outcomes necessary for evidence-based practice. To overcome this shortcoming, we are developing an augmented reality (AR) platform for telehealth rehabilitation that uses depth-sensing camera technology available in consumer devices (e.g., a smartphone, laptop, or PC-based camera) and body-tracking algorithms integrated within a telehealth video-conferencing platform to deliver real-time measures of joint mobility, alignment, posture, balance, strength, and function that supports the mandate for more effective delivery of evidence-based telehealth rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year, over 100,000 patients require an endoscopic (i.e. minimally invasive) surgery for kidney stone disease in the United States. Approximately 25% of these patients require a repeat surgery for residual stone fragments, which can lead to obstruction, pain, kidney injury and urinary tract infections. This proposal creates a navigational system for use during endoscopic stone surgery with the potential to improve stone-free rates and prevent recurrent stone surgeries or stone complications for many patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Juvenile justice officers experience exceptionally high levels of chronic workplace stress, leading to costly outcomes including depression, anxiety, and burnout. Mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) improve each of these outcomes, and can be tailored and delivered to employees during their workdays via smartphone app. By adapting an existing MBI app for JJOs and conducting a feasibility clinical trial, this study will develop building blocks for high-impact, large-scale studies that systematically address the need for sustainable and scalable programming to improve health trajectories among the justice system’s frontline workers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Celiac disease is a gluten-induced inflammatory disorder of the small intestine for which no non-dietary therapy exists at present. Recent clinical and nonclinical studies have identified transglutaminase 2 (TG2) as a promising drug target for celiac disease therapy, but critical gaps remain in our understanding of how TG2 interacts with gluten peptides as well as other proteins in the body. We will fill these knowledge gaps.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation during pregnancy is one pathway leading to adverse pregnancy outcomes, including preterm birth. Psychosocial stress during pregnancy is an important contributor to maternal inflammation levels; however, we have a limited understanding of how prenatal stress influences fetal inflammation and if fetal inflammation is reflective of maternal inflammation during mid-gestation. We will examine four prenatal stressors in relation to biomarkers of inflammation, measured in banked maternal serum, cord serum, and placentas collected during mid-gestation, and assess for quantitative relationships across the three matrices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Upon aging, nearly all the alpha-crystallins in the human eye lens eventually bind to the cell membrane leading to opacity and cataract formation. Age-related cataract has no cure at present. We subscribe to the hypothesis that primarily, alphaA-crystallin binds to the membrane. Using lens membrane mimics, we propose to examine the nature of this binding. We will also test the membrane-binding characteristics of age-related alphaA-crystallin modifications to understand how the binding process can be controlled to delay or mitigate lens opacity and age-related cataract.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The role of cannabinoid/endocannabinoid signaling in placentation to support pregnancy is critical to the well-being of the newborn and mother. The study proposes to test that well-coordinated endocannabinoid signaling in cooperation with the cell polarity signaling is critical to normal placentation and any disturbances in this process, due to aberration of endocannabinoid signaling, may cause preeclampsia and/or preterm birth. The results may help draw public attention to potential adverse effects of excessive consumption of cannabis products during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because the development of novel imaging tools and models that reveal how cancer cells hijack (i.e. co-opt) pre-existing blood vessels in the brain will yield invaluable insight into brain cancer progression, tumor spread, and development of drug resistance. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission because the mechanism of vascular co-option in brain cancer remains poorly understood, and studying it in clinically relevant brain tumor models would help us understand how resistance to antiangiogenic therapies develops, and enable the identification of new biomarkers and treatment strategies for patients with brain cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The successful moment-to-moment control of movement is contingent upon the function of complex neural microcircuits that reside outside the brain; understanding how these circuits function is critical to being able to treat age-related and developmental diseases in which these circuits are impaired. This proposal will leverage advantages of a highly tractable model system—the fruit fly—to determine how reflex circuits outside the brain enable successful movement and balance. Ultimately, elucidating the computational principles underlying these circuits will help inform our understanding of human circuits that must perform similar functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative AAV therapy has shown tremendous success as a DNA delivery vector to treat and potentially cure many serious single gene disorders. To reduce the cost and increase the efficiency of manufacturing AAV vectors, we need to better understand the differences between viral capsids with and without genomes. This project will determine the structural changes in AAV capsids with and without genomes that could lead to improved production, quality control and safety of AAV therapy and help bring more lifesaving AAV therapies to market.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA methylation is known to change with age, and may be associated with declining ovarian reserve and oocyte function that occurs as women approach menopause. A better understanding of the genes and processes involved in reproductive aging would provide insight into the underlying etiology of reproductive aging and may allow for the development of treatments to slow or reverse aging. This project will provide focused training opportunities including in aging biology and mechanisms, reproductive aging, aging epigenetics, clinical and translational research, and career development that will help me achieve my goal of becoming an independent, NIH-funded investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Heavy drinking and alcohol use disorder (AUD) are common, serious public health problems, both of which have a large genetic component. This project will integrate data from multiple genome-wide association studies of alcohol consumption and AUD with novel laboratory-based 3D Genomics-based methods to implicate effector genes contributing to these alcohol-related traits, and then validate them using a Drosophila model system and electronic health record data from existing biobanks. Using these innovative methods, the project will increase our understanding of the molecular genetics of alcohol-related traits and further prevention, diagnostic, and therapeutic efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Intervertebral disc degeneration is strongly associated with low back pain, but the role of the intervertebral disc as the pain generator is not clear. We aim to investigate the role of vascular endothelial growth factor A in regulating the pathological in-growth of blood vessels and nerves in intervertebral discs during low back pain, and the molecular factors that govern the pathoanatomy. The improved understanding of these molecular events will help to develop therapies for treating low back pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed EMPATHIE system is an innovative educational game environment that leads students through lesson modules to introduce science concepts using an immersive and engaging platform. The EMPATHIE system will enhance STEM education by: (1) providing novel and exciting STEM content through science lessons and a unique electromyography game interface; (2) ensuring lessons are engaging and relevant to students from under-represented groups by including them in game development through a participatory design process; and (3) incorporating design thinking concepts with a focus on developing empathy by placing students in the role of a patient dealing with daily challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Innate defense responses to pathogens must be tightly regulated to avoid the tissue damage caused by their overactivation. In this study, we will investigate the role of proteolytic processing in innate defense regulation. Consistent with the NIH mission, this research will 1) generate new insights into the regulation of defense mechanisms and 2) reveal proteases that could serve as both potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets for diseases involving dysregulated innate defense responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The perception of our surrounding environment depends on proper sensory organ function. Mutations in Pcdh15 affect the function of hair cells and photoreceptors resulting in deafness and progressive retinitis pigmentosa. The involvement of an integrin in the formation of a functional complex with Pcdh15 in hair cells has never been described. This proposal tests the hypothesis of a key role for Pcdh15-Itga8 complex in inner ear development and function, through Yap/ERM proteins activation and cytoskeletal dynamics. This work will define a common mechanism for Pcdh15-Itga8 complex in ear with the corresponding implications for Usher syndrome pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The resistance to current AR targeted therapies is one of the biggest challenges when treating advanced prostate cancer and largely hinders the clinical outcome of patients with this deadly disease. This study aims to determine the molecular role of a new potential tumor suppressor in prostate cancer, SYNCRIP, in suppressing APOBEC- mediating mutagenesis and resistance to AR targeted therapies. Elucidating the role of this protein and the molecular mechanism of the resistance may identify new actionable targets and establish a pathway for the development of therapeutic approaches to overcome the resistance and ultimately benefit patients.

PHR: Project Narrative This training program comes from MIT researchers working at the interface of science and engineering. Using and developing state-of-the-art technology, the trainees address cutting edge problems in environmental health. Our approaches involve measurement of risk, mining of complex biological data, modeling of systems exposed to environmental agents, and manipulation of systems to modulate risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ocular HSV-1 infection results in establishment of latent HSV infection and subsequent reactivation. Because recurrent virus reactivation remains a significant health concern, control of reactivation is an important goal in reducing HSV-associated eye disease. We will (i) test a highly innovative model based on our identification of two novel regions that upregulate HSV HVEM receptor and promote reactivation; and (ii) test strategies to block these interactions and reduce eye disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of the proposed project is to enable new research into human neuromotor control, adaptation, and learning by providing an accessible, effective vehicle for the study and rehabilitation of balance and gait through the development of portable robotic footwear, which can modify foot-ground stiffness during locomotion. This research is critically relevant to public health because it is expected to yield new technology and evidence-based research to improve the diagnosis, assistance, and retraining of gait and balance impairments in real-world contexts, addressing persistent shortcomings in current methodologies. As such, this research is relevant to the National Institutes of Health and National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering mission of accelerating development of new biomedical technologies to advance basic research and medical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) is an aggressive blood cancer with limited treatment options. This project focuses on “proliferative” CMML variants, an aggressive CMML subtype, testing the safety and efficacy of Onvansertib, a novel and oral PLK1 inhibitor in relapsed refractory patients. The Phase 1 clinical trial Is accompanied with detailed laboratory work identifying predictors of response and resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Red blood cells, the most numerous cell in the body, need to be replenished throughout life. We recently discovered that the hormone erythropoietin, which is essential for the process of red blood cell formation, induces extremely fast rates of protein synthesis during a specific stage of red blood cell formation. This proposal investigates the fundamental pathways that allow erythropoietin signaling to induce such a fast rate in protein synthesis, and may have implications for our understanding of cancer and for diseases with ribosomal protein mutations (ribosomopathies).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative / Relevance A majority of human spinal cord injury (SCI) cases occur in the cervical region, resulting in persistent respiratory dysfunction that is associated with mortality, morbidities such as respiratory infections, and greatly reduced quality of life. Cervical SCI disrupts the neural circuitry that controls the diaphragm (the major muscle of inspiratory breathing); however, axon regeneration and consequent restoration of this critical circuitry do not occur following SCI, resulting in persistent respiratory compromise. In animal models of cervical SCI, we will evaluate strategies aimed at promoting reconnection of this highly-important neural circuitry for restoring diaphragmatic respiratory function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Approximately 25 to 50% of persons with schizophrenia are “treatment-resistant” failing treatment with adequate trials of 2+ antipsychotics plus clozapine and have persistent hallucinations that have been related to suicide, aggressive behaviors and poor functioning. The proposal seeks to use deep brain stimulation or DBS to treat hallucinations in schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is a deadly malignancy, with poor prognosis for patients at all stages of diagnosis. In this proposal, we will investigate novel roles for GLI transcription factors, the effectors of the Hedgehog signaling pathway, as key regulators of the pancreatic cancer microenvironment. Specifically, we will: 1) employ novel genetic approaches to assess the contribution of GLI transcription factors to pancreatic cancer progression, 2) elucidate GLI-dependent fibroblast-immune crosstalk and 3) define GLI transcriptional targets in pancreatic fibroblasts to positively impact the treatment of pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Low health literacy patients are a vulnerable population at high-risk for surgical disparities including longer hospital stays, more complications, and more readmissions. This study will adapt enhanced recovery programs (ERPs) to low health literacy patients with a multilevel, health literacy-based implementation strategy (VISACT) to improve ERP fidelity and thereby outcomes. Findings from this study will lay the foundation for a multi- institutional stepped-wedge trial and establish key principles for adapting interventions to eliminate disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Wnts are a large family of signaling molecules with potent and widespread biological effects in the skeleton as well as development in general, stem cell maintenance, tissue homeostasis and cancer. This project will not only unravel how the structure of Wnt5a protein impacts signaling at the molecular and genetic levels, it will also shed light on the actions of other Wnt family members in diverse biological and disease processes. The fundamental knowledge gained from this project will help to elucidate pathogenic mechanisms in ADRS and provide crucial insight into the design of therapeutic interventions to treat skeletal disorders related to perturbation of Wnt/PCP signaling and be used to harness the power of Wnts for regenerative medicine.

PHR: Project Narrative  Mitochondrial dysfunction and failure of mitochondrial degradation pathways (mitophagy) are observed in Alzheimer’s diseases (AD) and likely contribute to pathogenesis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Schizophrenia involves dysconnection of separate brain areas, manifest in poor information transfer between cortical areas involved in complex processing of sensory information and construction of representations of the environment, important for successfully navigating the real world. Detection of novel sounds in the environment is critical for orienting and alerting, and is severely impaired in schizophrenia, but less so at disease onset. Examination of the distributed frontal lobe executive and temporal lobe auditory cortices and the interactions between bottom-up and top-down cortical processes shows great promise for understanding the basic molecular mechanisms of predictive coding, learning, memory, attention, and other key brain functions that are compromised by schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF SCIENCES, TECH & TECH OF BAMAKO
PHR: Malaria and neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) remain significant causes of morbidity and mortality throughout Guinea and Mali, despite substantial progress achieved through implementation at large scale of prevention and control interventions. Improved in-country expertise in implementation research is critical to address major challenges that limit the translation of high-quality evidence into effective health programs. This Mali-Guinea research training program will strengthen the capacity of doctoral-level public health training programs and professional development to train the next generation of leadership in implementation research to ensure sustained, high performance of the local health systems, surveillance, monitoring and evaluation and timely scale up efforts of malaria and NTD control interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Obesity is a major risk factor for a number of chronic diseases, including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer, yet the cause of this is not fully understood. Our preliminary data indicate that the inhibition of hypothalamic Rho-kinase expression leads to a significant increase in appetite, causing obesity. The goal of the study is to understand the new function of Rho-kinase in energy metabolism in the context of obesity, and the proposed experiments could lead to the identification of a potential target for new obesity-associated metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims at developing treatment-predictive brain biomarkers jointly from fMRI and EEG for treatment selection in major depression. We will develop data-driven analytics to identify moderators and brain signatures predictive for antidepressant treatment response. The successful outcome of this project will promote the development of multimodal brain biomarkers that have been missed by existing approaches, leading to more effective interventions in depression, and laying the groundwork for a significant translational impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Although menthol cigarette smoking has been suggested to contribute to the disproportionate burden of lung cancer among African Americans, epidemiological evidence on this issue remains scarce, especially for its biological mechanism underlying lung carcinogenesis. The overarching goal of this proposed study is to identify menthol cigarette smoking-related blood metabolites and evaluate their associations with lung cancer risk by leveraging pre-diagnostic blood samples, rich epidemiologic data, and recently generated metabolomics data in a prospective cohort of primarily low-income African Americans. Findings from this proposed study will enhance our understanding of the biological role/harms of menthol cigarette smoking in lung cancer etiology, especially among African American men who suffer the highest burden of lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Problems in scientific practice have generated widespread concern about the reliability of findings in behavioral and social science research, including work related to aging, presenting risks to the effectiveness of policy and practice, as well as public trust in science. Led by the Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences (BITSS), five annual Research Transparency and Reproducibility Training (RT2) short courses will provide critical training to equip behavioral and social scientists to conduct credible research, and strengthen a growing community of researchers committed to changing norms in their own networks. Access to these short courses and the open science community will empower early career researchers to conduct credible research on aging, extend their teaching to others, and help level the playing field in terms of who participates in ongoing transformations in the scientific ecosystem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance:  Early life stress (ELS) is a significant risk factor for the development of psychopathology from childhood to  young adulthood; in this project we will augment our existing rich longitudinal dataset by conducting an  additional assessment of our participants at age 20 to examine the effects of ELS on trajectories of  neurodevelopment and clinical outcomes from childhood to young adulthood, as well as the persistence of  COVID-19 pandemic-related difficulties in mental health, stress, and brain metrics. We will also extend and  replicate our findings in a larger, younger, non-Western sample of youth, in whom we will also examine the  effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on young people’s health. Findings from this project will inform efforts to  generate personalized targets in order to tailor prevention and treatment programs for adolescents who are at  high risk for the onset of depression, for other forms of psychopathology, and for engaging in suicidal  behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative Although a large proportion of individuals living in rural Appalachia and the Mississippi Delta (AMD) experience strikingly high rates of heart and lung disease (hot spots), some other communities in the same region seem to be relatively spared (cold spots). To study this regional variation in disease risk and the potential basis of resilience of `cold spots', we will recruit and study 4000 young-to-middle aged men and women from different race/ethnicity groups living in six high risk and four lower risk poor rural counties in four Southern states. We will reach these communities using a mobile van, and measure levels of both protective and harmful influences in the people and their neighborhoods, hoping to understand what causes the high burden of heart and lung disease in these rural Southern regions and how to improve and prevent it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TBI is associated with significant morbidity, including cognitive impairment and dementia, but the mechanisms linking TBI to dementia remain poorly understood. The central hypothesis of this proposal is that TBI is associated with cognitive decline and dementia risk in part via vascular pathways which accelerate neurodegeneration for years post-TBI. The overall scientific objective of this proposal is to use blood-based and neuroimaging biomarkers of vascular injury and dysfunction to investigate mechanisms linking TBI and neurocognitive outcomes and to identify time-periods during which future interventions may be effective at preventing TBI-related dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator: Peterson, Craig, Lewis NARRATIVE STATEMENT Chromosome structure plays a central role in regulating the the expression of genes, the repair of DNA, and the faithful copying of DNA during cell division. The studies described here will investigate the role of key enzymes that remodel chromosome structure and regulate these events. In mammals, these factors are essential for development and stem cell identity, and their inactivation can lead to tumorogenesis and other diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Interrogating the cholinergic basis of opioid use disorder Here, we propose to develop, characterize, and deploy a comprehensive toolset focused on opioid neuropharmacology. We will test the hypothesis that μORs on cholinergic interneurons mediate harmful effects of opioids, independent of therapeutic analgesic effects. The proposed technologies will offer the unprecedented opportunity to establish causal behavioral roles of opioid neuropharmaceuticals mediated by defined cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Conduct disorder (CD) is one of the most prevalent and impairing psychiatric disorders among youth, yet, treatment options are limited and those treatments that do exist largely focus on behavior management rather than targeting the mechanisms that contribute to the development and stability of CD. This project aims to evaluate a new and innovative treatment for CD, called Impact VR, a Virtual Reality emotion recognition and regulation training program, specifically designed to target the developmental mechanisms of CD. Our goal is to assess its acceptability among youth with CD, and its feasibility for deployment across settings (e.g., schools, hospitals), as well as conduct a randomized control trial to assess its preliminary effectiveness for reducing CD and callous-unemotional traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance Alcohol use and sexual assault are significant, co-occurring problems on college campuses. Women with a history of sexual victimization are at increased risk for revictimization when they drink to cope with sex-related distress; a common aftereffect of trauma. This treatment development study will develop and pilot an integrated intervention that targets alcohol use, sex-related distress, and sexual revictimization among college women with a history of severe sexual victimization who report past month heavy drinking, sexual activity, and sexual distress; a particularly high-risk group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Elucidating how genetic and environmental factors interact has potential to improve our currently limited understanding of the etiology, phenotypic heterogeneity, and rising prevalence of Autism Spectrum Disorder. The proposed research applies novel analytic methodologies to understand the interrelationships between endocrine-disrupting chemicals, genetics, and immune dysregulation, and their role in ASD development. This knowledge will ultimately lead to better identification of high-risk mothers and children and guide development of strategies to protect vulnerable subgroups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Huntington’s disease is a devastating and fatal neurodegenerative disorder for which there is no cure or effective treatment. The combination of emotional, cognitive and motor symptoms, leading to long-term care needs results in an extremely high healthcare cost, estimated at 25 billion dollars a year. This study is aimed at identifying early modifiers of disease with the potential of discovering novel targets for therapeutic intervention prior to disease onset.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The Center for Demography of Health and Aging at the University of Wisconsin-Madison offers outstanding research training in the demography of health and aging, enriched by several locally-designed large-scale surveys that combine innovative biological and social measurement and provide opportunities for training at multiple forefronts of research on population, aging, and health across the life course. Our trainees receive interdisciplinary training in the social and health sciences and enter research careers in academic institutions and governmental health and statistical agencies. Their research and public service increases the understanding of complex biosocial determinants of health in aging populations and influences national policies that affect the health and well-being of all Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Work in my laboratory is focused on understanding how genomic DNA is maintained in eukaryotes and prokaryotes, and on exploring how genome maintenance machines have adopted new roles throughout evolution. Our particular areas of interest are in how chromosomes are organized, recombined, and segregated in eukaryotic meiosis; how viral RNAs are recognized by mammalian innate-immune proteins; and how bacteria have adapted canonical genome maintenance machinery to new defensive roles against viruses and pathogenic DNA molecules. Taken together, our research will provide fundamental knowledge about how organisms maintain and defend their genomes in the face of internal and external threats, and reveal how the molecular machinery underlying genome maintenance has evolved to meet these diverse threats.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: NARRATIVE Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), which impacts approximately 10% to 15% of adults in the United States, is a chronic, oftentimes disabling gastrointestinal (GI) disorder characterized by recurrent abdominal pain associated with alterations in bowel habits (diarrhea and/or constipation). The need for better endpoint measures in IBS drug development that would enable a more comprehensive and detailed assessment of abdominal and bowel-movement- related symptom severity for its main subtypes—IBS with predominant diarrhea (IBS-D), IBS with predominant constipation (IBS-C), and alternating or mixed IBS (IBS-M)—has been clearly identified. To address this unmet measurement need, the overall objective of this project is to develop a Full Qualification Package to support the qualification of the Diary for Irritable Bowel Syndrome Symptoms–Diarrhea (DIBSS-D) with the resulting impact being the advancement of a publicly available, psychometrically sound, fit-for-purpose patient-reported outcome measure that will facilitate the assessment of clinical benefit in IBS-D treatment trials.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Preparation and Submission Support of a Full Qualification Package (FQP) for the Diary for Irritable Bowel Syndrome Symptoms—Diarrhea (DIBSS-D) (DDT #000148)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cause of multiple system atrophy (MSA), a fatally progressive adult-onset neurodegenerative disease, is the abnormal accumulation of the protein alpha-synuclein, a mechanism that can be targeted by drug therapy. This trial readiness proposal addresses current critical obstacles for clinical trials of MSA by validating novel tools that accurately measure patient’s worsening, including clinical scales, neuroimaging and biochemical measures of disease progression. The timing is excellent, with therapeutic targets for MSA already identified, exceptional network of collaboration among researchers, pharmaceutical industry, and patient advocacy groups, and several drugs in the pipeline ready for clinical testing within the next five years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Narrative To realize the goals of the federal Overdose Prevention Plan, it is necessary to identify strategies to address the impact of polydrug use and the multiple intersecting determinants of PDU and overdose mortality over time. The proposed research will address CDC primary objectives to inform overdose prevention through in-depth understanding of PDU combinations and trajectories most likely to result in overdose. This interdisciplinary project will provide a foundation for applied intervention approaches that build on a rich understanding PDU patterns, trajectories, and life course risk and protective factors.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-22-011: Mixed methods study of polysubstance use to optimize overdose prevention

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: We propose to conduct an exploratory sequential mixed methods evaluation of drug use behaviors, patterns, trajectories, and risk factors in a sample of King County, WA residents who initiated use within the past three years of a high-risk drug class. The quantitative and qualitative results from our study will inform development of novel early intervention strategies and development of methods to reach a currently hidden population with overdose prevention programs and related evaluations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-22-011 -Understanding Polydrug Use Risk and Protective Factors, Patterns, and Trajectories to Prevent Drug Overdose - 2022

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hydrocephalus affects 1/1,000 live births and is a major cause of morbidity and mortality. We propose to use a functional genomics approach that combines next-generation DNA sequencing and a high-throughout functional screening platform to discover, validate, and gain mechanistic insight into novel gene mutations associated with human congenital hydrocephalus. Results could lead to fundamental new insights into human brain development and serve as the basis for improved clinical decision-making, prognostication, and novel biology-based treatments for congenital hydrocephalus patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Results from recent TCGA and pathological studies imply the oncogenic role for KLF4 in breast carcinogenesis, although the underlying molecular mechanisms by which dysregulation of KLF4 contributes to breast tumor initiation, progression and metastasis remain unknown. This proposal will determine the impact of interplay between KLF4 and PARP1 in breast tumor progression and metastasis, and further develop a small molecule inhibitor of KLF4 that synergizes with PARP inhibitors for anti-breast cancer treatment, especially for triple negative type breast cancers. Completion of this project will uncover the mitogenic role of KLF4 in breast cancer development, and could provide a new strategy for breast cancer therapy by synergism PARP1 and KLF4.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: A disturbing number of Veterans suffer from cognitive dysfunction due to dementia that has a high likelihood of progressing into Alzheimer's disease. Neurodegeneration is a complex process, involving synaptic dysfunction and memory loss. We aim to examine the signaling molecule Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF), considered particularly important for neural health and synaptic plasticity in the context of Alzheimer's disease, by assessing its role in magnetic brain stimulation. Transcranial magnetic brain stimulation has been shown to increase BDNF and thus potentially improve cognitive performance in dementia. Information gained from this proposal will enhance our knowledge of both cognitive decline and treatment options. Given that Veterans with cognitive impairment create a huge burden on themselves and others, it is critical to focus research on this eff ort.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) and X-linked protoporphyria (XLP) are a genetic defects of heme biosynthesis that cause life-long, painful cutaneous sensitivity to light. The objective of this study is to determine the efficacy and safety of oral cimetidine administration for treatment of the protoporphyrias. Efficacy will be based on protoporphyrin levels, photosensitivity, and quality of life questionnaires.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Trauma is the leading cause of death in people from 1-44 years and the leading cause of life years lost. The proposed renewal T32 program will provide support for postgraduate research training in injury and critical illness in the Department of Surgery at McGovern Medical School at The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston. The goal of this training program is to provide a cohort of future clinical and translational scientists to increase basic and clinical understanding of trauma-related illness and improve the outcomes of injured patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The US Preventative Services Task Force (USPSTF) concluded that current evidence is insufficient to assess the balance of benefits vs harms of screening for mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and early Alzheimer's disease and related disorders (ADRD). The overarching GOAL of the current proposed investigation is to build upon our previous work and to further address the major challenges to improve the detection of MCI and early ADRD. Our long-term goal is to increase “real world” early MCI and ADRD detection, diagnosis, and treatment; address USPSTF Key Questions; and reduce disparities in health outcomes. This resonates strongly with the three guiding principles of the National Alzheimer's Project Act (NAPA), especially its third principle: “Transform the way we approach Alzheimer's disease and related dementias.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Opioids are powerful analgesics, but their harmful side effects have led to a nationwide opioid epidemic. Neurons in the periaqueductal gray (PAG) contribute to the pain-relieving and rewarding effects of opioids, but the organization of these circuits and how they contribute to opioid-induced behaviors remains unclear. To elucidate how opioids affect PAG neurons, I will characterize the organization of PAG neural circuits and investigate how they contribute to opioid-induced behaviors using input-output circuit mapping, single-cell transcriptomics, and circuit-specific neuromodulation experiments in freely moving animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic total occlusions (CTOs) are lesions comprised of hard fibro-calcific material that completely stop blood flow in a coronary artery and are traditionally treated with either medical therapy or bypass surgery. Percutaneous Coronary Interventional (PCI) procedures can be performed, but are technically difficult, and often pass the CTO by traversing inside the vessel wall, leading to higher complication rates. We are developing and testing an optoacoustic- ultrasound image-guided cold-laser-wire which can provide any interventional cardiologist a much simplified single-operator approach to stay true-lumen while traversing a coronary CTO and reducing rate of patient complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to create a novel microfluidic lung-on-a-chip device that utilizes the unique properties of porous silicon and leverages precision biomaterials and biomanufacturing techniques to better mimic the structural composition of the lung in vitro. The proposed research is relevant to public health because the development of a fully organic lung-on-a-chip device will have positive translational outcomes in the prevention and treatment of a wide range of inflammatory and fibrotic pulmonary diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Insufficient sleep is a major global public health concern that places people at increased risk for negative health, including cardiovascular disease; unfortunately, many individuals and occupations at heightened risk for sleep disturbance, like firefighters, are limited in their ability to identify and access evidence-based intervention. This project aims to increase access to sleep health intervention by testing and implementing an evidence-based sleep health coaching program within the fire service. The results of this study will identify factors that are key in the adoption of sleep health intervention to inform the implementation and dissemination of sleep health workplace wellness programs nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to improve the diagnosis and treatment of pain that is associated with bladder disease, including referred pain that is common amongst patients yet poorly understood. The proposed research will provide a necessary understanding of the peripheral molecular and neurophysiologic mechanisms underlying referred pain by identifying how neighboring uninjured sensory neurons housed within the same sensory ganglion, yet innervating distant organs, are altered in mouse models of bladder inflammation and nerve injury. Findings from this research will demonstrate peripheral novel mechanism for referred pain with specific molecular targets outside of the blood-brain-barrier that can be exploited to develop more suitable therapies for patients with referred pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physiological aging and age-related diseases are highly associated with protein aggregation, but the causal relationship between protein aggregation and aging remains unknown. This proposal utilizes novel and complementary approaches to directly test the hypothesis that aging at the cellular level is ultimately driven by irreversible conformational transitions in physiologically supersaturated proteins (i.e. proteins existing at concentrations exceeding their solubility limits). The insights generated from this research will be the first to directly test a thermodynamic explanation for aging in humans - potentially providing new opportunities to decelerate the onset of age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cells must constantly reprogram mitochondrial function to adapt to changing cellular environments and support cell homeostasis. This project aims to elucidate how movement of the mitochondrial network and mitochondrial signaling pathways contribute to cellular fitness. Because mitochondria are key organelles that maintain cellular homeostasis, and mitochondrial dysfunction are associated with neurological and metabolic diseases, cancer and aging, our advances have the potential to inform how to exploit these mechanisms for practical applications in medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Rett syndrome (RTT) is a severe neurodevelopmental disorder that is notable for its postnatal onset: after 12- 18 months of apparently normal development and reaching the expected milestones, females with mutations in the X-linked MECP2 gene lose their acquired skills and develop a host of neurological symptoms. Mecp2- deficient mice faithfully reproduce this pattern, even when Mecp2 is suppressed in adult mice: it takes weeks for them to develop symptoms. This lag between loss of MeCP2 function and the onset of symptoms allows us to track the molecular changes that follow Mecp2 depletion in mice so that we better understand the pathways involved, and also provides a window of opportunity for interventions that can delay or prevent the onset of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project will determine how plants uses salicylic acid to control cell death and survival to combat infection while avoiding conflict with growth-related activities. Results from the study will lead to development of new strategies of engineering crop varieties with enhanced broad-spectrum resistance to reduce the use of pesticides which are major health and environmental hazards. Moreover, studying salicylic acid’s broad physiological functions in plants may also shed light on its medicinal effects in animals because salicylic acid is the oldest herbal medicine known to mankind used in fever reduction and pain relief and in recent years, aspirin (acetylated salicylic acid) has been repurposed in treating cardiovascular diseases and certain types of cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Preterm birth (PTB) affects 1 in 7 Black babies born in the US. This would be the first large-scale prospective birth cohort study to address critical questions regarding the preterm origin of cardiometabolic risk in a sample of a predominantly US urban, low-income, Black participants who are disproportionally affected by both PTB and cardiometabolic diseases. Successful completion of this study will help identify novel predictive biomarkers and therapeutic targets so that high-risk newborns can be identified, and effective interventions can be initiated during the earliest developmental windows when they may have the greatest life-long benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We see the world with our retinas, which send visual signals to many parts of the brain including the superior colliculus, a major locus for attention and decision-making. Analyzing the direct connection from retina to superior colliculus is critical for understanding vision and attentional disorders such as ADHD. We will apply new approaches that combine genetic targeting of retinal cells that project to the superior colliculus along with high- density recording and manipulation of those cells to provide a full accounting of the signaling and functionality of this circuit in rat and primate animal models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Pregnancy represents a unique physiological situation in which there the fetus is tolerated by the maternal immune system despite its expression of not only foreign, paternally inherited antigens, but also tissue specific antigens. Immune tolerance to many tissue specific antigens is established in the thymus by the process of central tolerance; however, almost nothing is known about the role of central tolerance in maternal tolerance to the fetus. Understanding this process will lead us to novel insights into how diseases of pregnancy can be alleviated and will have far-reaching implications for women’s wellbeing in the fields of pregnancy, reproductive health, autoimmune disease, transplantation, and cancer immunology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transport proteins in the liver are critical determinants of drug disposition, efficacy, and toxicity, but factors that alter hepatic transporter function are poorly understood, and more efficient and robust predictive tools are needed. These studies will answer fundamental questions related to hepatic transport mechanisms and transporter-mediated drug interactions, and advance innovative strategies to assess interindividual variability in transporter function. Data generated will inform the development of in silico models to predict drug disposition more accurately and improve therapeutic outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE By providing robust and durable responses, a novel radiotherapeutic agent called [225Ac]-PSMA- 617 has the potential to change the treatment landscape for end-stage prostate cancer patients, and has delivered impressive results in clinical trials, including some complete responses. Treatment with [225Ac]-PSMA-617, however, is severely limited by salivary gland toxicity. In response, we are proposing aclinically translatable method to refine treatment with [225Ac]-PSMA- 617 and other PSMA-TRT agents by reducing toxicity to salivary glands and kidneys without compromising treatment efficacy, helpingto extend the lives of mCRPC patients while maintaining their quality of lif e.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is critical for public health as the practice of providing external chest compressions in newborn when their heart rate is low at birth lacks evidence and could influence the outcome of neonatal resuscitation. Exploring the current and alternate strategies to improve oxygenated blood flow to brain & heart, and provide optimal support while limiting injury during external chest compressions may provide evidence that can improve newborn care. The current proposal is extremely relevant to current NIH/NICHD’s mission of protecting and enhancing the lives of newborn/children by optimizing the current practice of performing external chest compressions during neonatal resuscitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Restoration of dental, oral, and craniofacial (DOC) tissues lost to disease, injury or congenital disorders is a major objective of oral reconstructive therapy. The goal of the Michigan-Pittsburgh-Wyss Regenerative Medicine Resource Center is to translate tissue engineering and regenerative medicine innovations that address the ongoing clinical need to restore or create healthy, functional DOC tissues. The vision of this Resource Center is that the most promising technologies will be catalyzed by novel academic partnerships to safely and effectively regenerate, reconstruct and restore functional DOC tissues, leading to a transformation of patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) family of inductive growth factors acts in a reiterative signal specific manner to direct neural progenitor cells in the dorsal spinal cord to proliferate and then differentiate into the distinct classes of interneurons (dIs) that integrate and relay sensory information from the periphery. We are examining the extrinsic and intrinsic mechanisms that translate the activity of the BMPs into specific populations of dIs. These studies will shed light both on our ability to rebuild damaged spinal cords, as well as understanding the basis of the congenital diseases that result from altered BMP signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NAACCR Annual Scientific Conference Project Narrative R13 20-207 For more than 30 years, NAACCR has hosted the most influential and informative annual scientific conference for cancer surveillance professionals. Drawing from every state and province in the US and Canada, as well as international colleagues, the NAACCR Annual Conference is attended by over 400 researchers, epidemiologists, and cancer surveillance scientists annually. Developed by and for cancer surveillance professionals, it is the largest meeting of its kind to share research findings, develop innovative methodologies, support cancer research, and ensure a community that is well-informed on advances in cancer care, data sources, technology, and research interests.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek funding for our new program, Advancing Native American Diversity in Aging Research through Undergraduate Education, within the NIA’s ADAR R25 program (PAR-17-290). This week-long annually offered class concentrates on recruiting undergraduates, especially from Native American backgrounds, and offers exciting and relevant opportunities for training, including virtual options in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the goal of launching research careers in the investigation of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias and the biology of aging. This is achieved through scientific education, mentored projects, and retention of the participants in the NIH research workforce via ongoing career counseling and personal advice, along with annual updates and refresher programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This research program aims to answer fundamental questions about the control and selectivity of iron-dependent dioxygenase enzymes that remove methyl modifications on cellular mRNA. These methyl ‘eraser’ enzymes are overexpressed in difficult to treat human cancers such as glioblastoma, where their demethylation activity is tied to cancer progression and tumor growth. Successful completion of these projects will show how this class of enzymes is regulated to control mRNA demethylation and inform new approaches for the treatment of human cancers like glioblastoma, where reversible RNA methylation impacts disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Blood flow is essential for the production of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) during embryonic development; successful harnessing of the regulatory program initiated or maintained by this extrinsic regulatory factor may facilitate growth and expansion of HSCs for therapeutic use. I propose to use zebrafish as an in vivo platform to dissect the physical, cellular and molecular mechanisms by which hemodynamic forces intersect with YAP transcriptional regulation to drive HSC production. Translation of this work to in vitro human hematopoietic differentiation has potential to facilitate generation of clinically useful HSCs for the treatment of blood diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminant potential (CHIP) is thought to occur in >10% of individuals over the age of 70 and has been associated with an increased risk of hematologic malignancy and cardiovascular disease. At present, it is unclear which individuals with CHIP will progress to malignancy and how inflammation contributes to this process. The proposed research will assess the impact of CHIP-associated mutations on hematopoietic stem cell clonal output and immune cell development and differentiation with the goal of identifying relevant cells and pathways that may be clinically targeted to prevent or delay leukemic transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Personalized medicine will greatly improve the effectiveness of cancer care. This study explores a unique personalized medicine opportunity for B cell hematologic malignancies by time-efficient and cost-effective generation of nucleic acid aptamers to target cell-based markers that are specific to the tumor and unique to the patient. These aptamers will be used to enable personalized disease monitoring and precision therapy, potentially initiating a transformative change in the care of patients with B cell hematologic malignancies.

PHR: NARRATIVE Social cognition is among the most complex and poorly understood aspects of human behavior. It is a core milestone in human ontogeny and broadly involves psychosocial conditions such as autism spectrum disorder, bipolar affective disorder and schizophrenia. Here, we aim to provide the first direct comprehensive single- neuronal, population-, time-causal and local network-based investigation of social cognition in the human prefrontal cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Changes in cannabis and alcohol use, driven by cannabis legalization policies, may be important but underappreciated contributors to self-directed and interpersonal violence. We need to better understand how combinations of local cannabis and alcohol policies lead to high densities of both alcohol and cannabis outlets in low-socioeconomic status communities and resulting impacts on violence for community residents. This information is critical for local policymakers seeking to make informed decisions about regulating intoxicants in diverse communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Over 300 different inherited mutations have been found in IKs channels that decrease the activity of IKs channels and cause a prolonged cardiac action potential (i.e. Long QT Syndrome), which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias in patients. We have identified a family of compounds that activate IKs channels, shorten the cardiac action potential, and are antiarrhythmic when applied to cardiomyocytes. We will here test variants of these compounds in order to develop a drug that will shorten the cardiac action potential to prevent cardiac arrhythmias and sudden cardiac deaths in Long QT Syndrome patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 90% of pancreatic cancer patients die within 5 years of diagnosis because we currently lack effective treatments. We recently discovered a specific protein, Krüppel-like factor 5 (KLF5), is selectively essential for pancreatic cancer cell growth, and may therefore be a compelling target. In this project, we will combine innovative models and approaches to determine how KLF5 functions in pancreatic cancer and to evaluate if targeting KLF5 represents a promising therapeutic opportunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The influenza vaccine needs to be improved since the current vaccine is only 40-60% effective, must be received annually, and provides limited protection against new, potentially pandemic strains of influenza. CD8+ T cells that reside in the lung can protect against current and potentially emerging strains of influenza and could increase the effectiveness of the flu vaccine. This project aims to improve our understanding of the duration and function of lung CD8+ resident memory cells in humans to determine their potential utility in a vaccine strategy for influenza or other respiratory pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT SUMMARY In this Program Project renewal, we bring together investigators with very different expertise and approaches from structural biology, proteomics, immunology, biophysics and computational biology to understand T cell antigen receptor (TCR) signaling. We will study the distinct features of the T cell-expressed tyrosine kinase enzymes that make these most suitable for TCR signaling, how the biochemical features and assembly of particular molecules are used to amplify signals, how distinct signaling pathways coordinate different cellular responses and how signaling circuitry generated enables the T cell to discriminate and respond to signals generated from self-antigens versus pathogen or tumor antigens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Rates of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) among Mexican older adults are projected to grow sharply with the estimated threefold increase of the older adult population by 2030, but the underlying genetic and environmental risk factors for ADRD in this population are not well understood. The proposed study will examine the effects of environmental risk factors, including education, socioeconomic status, literacy, rurality, and migration, on ADRD risk among Mexican older adults, as well as the extent to which these environmental risk factors moderate genetic effects of APOE and a polygenic ADRD risk score recently developed for Mexican ancestral populations. Project findings will identify the role of genetic and environmental influences on ADRD risk among Mexican older adults and facilitate development of targeted intervention strategies that mitigate ADRD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas are understudied cancers with no reliable predictors of penetrance for the SDHx hereditary forms and no predictors or curative treatments for metastatic disease. The goals of this proposal are to determine inherited genetic risk loci for sporadic and SDHx-associated tumors in order to identify those at highest risk for screening and surveillance and to identify targets for cancer prevention and therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The growing incidence of eating disorders and obesity, and their associated health costs have led to intensive research efforts directed at understanding the mechanisms and signaling pathways that control and regulate food intake. This competitive renewal grant application aims at developing innovative mass spectrometry- based technologies and strategies in combination with physiological approaches to characterize neuropeptides and biogenic amines involved in feeding with increased sensitivity, accuracy and throughput. The molecular insights gained from this research promise to increase our knowledge about peptidergic signaling and neuromodulation in the regulation of this essential physiological process, which could ultimately lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for obesity and eating disorders that have become a big concern of modern societies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Center for Dental, Oral, & Craniofacial Tissue & Organ Regeneration (C-DOCTOR) a public-private consortium focused on accelerating promising tissue engineering/regenerative medicine therapies for dental, oral, and craniofacial tissue and organ regeneration to human clinical trials. Our overall vision for C-DOCTOR is to be a comprehensive national resource center for the clinical translation of innovative regenerative technologies to replace DOC tissues or organs lost to congenital disorders, traumatic injuries, diseases, and medical procedures. In Stage 3, we will continue to provide interdisciplinary translational project teams with fully customized support from expert scientists, clinicians, commercialization strategists and regulatory advisors as the teams refine their products, complete their IND/IDE-enabling studies, transition to current good laboratory/manufacturing practices methods for scale-up, form strategic partnerships, and interact with the FDA ahead of Phase I clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Higher order organization of membrane proteins and lipids is pivotal to various cellular signaling pathways. Combining lipid vesicle technology with native mass spectrometry, the project aims to develop a novel experimental platform that can provide a quantitative molecular view of organization of membrane proteins and lipids in the bilayer. With membrane proteins being targets of more than 60% marketed drugs, the transformative potential of this approach lies in its broad impact in understanding various membrane associated pathological states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Scientific fields such as astronomy and particle physics have had tremendous success using an “observatory” based approach to data collection, in which researchers propose experiments to be carried out in centralized facilities too complex and expensive to be operated by individual laboratories. We will apply this model to neuroscience by opening the Allen Institute Brain Observatory’s state-of-the-art optical and electrophysiological data collection pipelines to the entire neuroscience community. This will lower barriers to testing new hypotheses about brain function, bring in new computational and theoretical talents into the field, and enhance the reproducibility of results in brain research, thereby accelerating progress toward an integrated understanding of neural activity in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The enormous complexity of brain interactions makes understanding brain diseases such as stroke, autism, and Alzheimer disease extremely difficult. Part of this complexity lies in the need to understand how the chemicals that underlie learning and memory, and brain energy, interact with the electrical signals that travel along nerve fibers. We are extending NEURON, one of the most widely used nerve and brain computer simulators, to simulate chemical reactions both inside and outside of cells. This will allow us to better understand the roles of oxygen, toxins and drugs in brain dysfunctions of neurological and psychiatric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative We use a natural host colonization model system to study how competitive interactions between bacterial populations impact which populations can infect and persist inside a host. We found that bacterial colonizers use a type VI secretion system (T6SS) to kill competing strains for access to host colonization sites. We will determine how these bacteria target other cells for killing, as well as the extent to which competition influences the spatial arrangements of members comprising a natural host-associated microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Elevated mental health problems have been documented in children of divorced families – over 8.1 million in the US – and in their parents. While behavioral parent training interventions, including digital interventions, have demonstrated success to reduce children’s mental health problems, they have shown weaker effects in divorced parents with elevated psychological distress, and digital fully self-administered interventions have shown no effects to reduce the distress of divorced parents. By developing digital mindfulness training components and adding them to an existing evidence-based parenting intervention, as a combined, web- based, self-administered intervention, this project has great potential to maximize its reach and impact, reducing mental health problems in high-risk divorced families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several psychiatric disorders including post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and alcohol use disorder (AUD) are characterized by excessive and persistent emotional responses to conditioned cues. Exposure therapy, where these cues are repeatedly presented without the expected threatening or rewarding outcome, helps diminish the conditioned response to these cues, but they often return in a subset of patients. This research could open the possibility for the use of CO2 reactivity as a transdiagnostic screening tool to determine whether an individual with addiction or a trauma/anxiety disorder would maintain their response to exposure therapy and thus be a good candidate for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The HIV epidemic in many global settings is highly concentrated among people who inject drugs (PWID), and efforts to scale up HIV treatment have largely failed to reach this population. The proposed research utilizes a mixed methods, implementation science-focused approach to explore the understudied relationship between clinic characteristics (which can act as significant barriers or facilitators to intervention implementation) and the scale-up, adaptation, and sustainment of an evidence-based systems navigation and psychosocial counseling intervention for PWID with HIV in Vietnam. Findings can inform governments globally on how to distribute limited resources, based on clinic characteristics, to scale up and sustain effective HIV interventions for PWID, ultimately reducing mortality and improving wellbeing for PWID with HIV across low and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: With increased market demand for medicinal plant products comes a greater risk for adulteration of botanicals, posing a large health risk to consumers. The innate complexity of herbal products makes authentication and identification of bioactive compounds challenging. Thus, this proposal aims to combine advanced metabolomic (UPLC-HRMS), DNA barcoding, and bioactivity data with multivariate statistical models and machine learning algorithms for improved authentication schemes and bioactive compound discovery, using Ocimum (basil) as a model species, to develop novel approaches with application to a range of botanical products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Difficulty initiating or executing appropriate movement is characteristic of neurological disorders including Parkinson’s disease and ataxias, while abnormally repetitive movements are characteristic of neurological disorders such as Tourette Syndrome and neuropsychiatric disorders such as OCD and ASD. This research is aimed at understanding the neuronal mechanisms by which C. elegans nematodes initiate, execute and stabilize appropriate motor actions, in order to make predictions about how dysregulation of motor action patterns arise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dogs are outbred companion animals that develop spontaneous cancers in the setting of an intact immune system, allowing for the study of complex immune interactions during cancer therapies while also addressing endpoints of efficacy and toxicity. This proposal seeks to capitalize on the dog model to speed the translation of novel immunotherapy approaches with the goal of enhancing and building on readily available and commonly utilized immunotherapies in human cancer patients while at the same time helping to train the next generation of translational comparative oncologists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE V(D)J recombination stand at the basis of our immune system, and its dysfunction causes severe human immunodeficiency syndromes, genomic instability and cancer. The goal of this study is to define the molecular events that govern this intricate process under normal and aberrant conditions using innovative technology. Furthering our understanding of the mechanisms of V(D)J recombination and related disease would bring us closer to mechanism-based therapeutics.
