IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Insomnia is a serious health problem in Veterans suffering from chronic Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) and often associated with extensive prescription of sleeping medications. Although safer, even the latest “sleeping pills” can lead to daytime impairment and risk of abuse. Thus non-pharmacological treatments for insomnia have been pursued as alternatives to medications. Cognitive Behavior Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is the term widely used to describe therapies that combine behavioral and cognitive therapies for insomnia. The combined CBT-I approach has well-documented efficacy. Between 2012 and 2014 over 650 VA mental health clinicians have received extensive training in CBT-I. Although CBT-I has been suggested to be a good treatment alternative to pharmacological approaches its efficacy has not yet been sufficiently demonstrated in TBI associated insomnia. We propose to address this gap in our knowledge with a carefully designed clinical trial comparing the benefits of CBT-I with an active control/placebo condition in Veterans with TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE  Alcohol Use Disorders (AUDs) are a significant public health problem which contribute to high levels of mortality, morbidity and healthcare costs, and while safe and effective medications are available for treating AUDs, there is reluctance to prescribe and they are underused, particularly in primary care. There is little research on interventions to improve primary care-based AUD medication delivery and addiction treatment initiation; to address this gap, this pragmatic, cluster-randomized trial in adult primary care clinics in a healthcare system with a diverse membership will examine the effectiveness of an innovative, multi-faceted intervention, the Addiction Telemedicine Consultant (ATC) service. The ATC will provide a centralized, flexible, expert addiction medicine consultation to primary care physicians (PCPs) and their patients with AUDs, via video, telephone or email consultation, and findings from this study could spur wider adoption of ATC in health systems as a standard practice in primary care settings, and profoundly affect how we treat and investigate the full spectrum of unhealthy alcohol use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cytochromes c play an essential role in bioenergetics, functioning in diverse electron transport chains for aerobic/anaerobic respiration, photosynthesis and detoxification, which are critical for bacterial survival. The proposed studies strive to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of cytochrome c biogenesis, specifically heme delivery, trafficking and attachment. Investigation of these pathways will provide insights into two fundamental, yet poorly understood, biological processes, cytochrome c biogenesis and heme trafficking, laying the foundation for future studies on other heme transporters.

PROJECT_TITLE: Heme trafficking in prokaryotic cytochrome c biogenesis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The subfamily of the tandem Coronins forms a structurally unique class among the extensive family of the Coronins, however to date their actin- regulatory functions remain completely unknown. Using a combination of single molecule techniques, protein crystallography, and cell biology, we will investigate how the mammalian tandem Coronin, Coro7, structurally and mechanistically inhibits Arp2/3-mediated nucleation induced by nucleation promoting factors (N- WASP, WHAMM, and JMY), and other Arp2/3 regulators, including GMF, and SPIN90. In addition, we will elucidate how these actin-regulatory activities of Coro7 work in concert with Arp2/3 and its various interactors in intracellular membrane transport and autophagy. Altogether, this proposal will shed light on the enigmatic actin-regulatory functions of the class of the tandem Coronins in vitro, and in cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Esthesioneuroblastoma is a rare tumor that arises in the nasal cavity and frequently causes patients to permanently lose their sense of smell. The biological pathways driving esthesioneuroblastoma growth remain poorly understood, and treatment options for patients have not improved for decades. This proposal aims to define mechanisms regulating proliferating cells in esthesioneuroblastoma and normal olfactory progenitors, with a goal of improving treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to train the next generation of addiction scientists to become rigorous and creative investigators to understand, treat and prevent drug abuse. Our goal is to provide pre- and post-doctoral trainees with both specialized research training in their chosen discipline, and also give them an appreciation for the broader issues related to addiction and addiction-related research, from molecular to policy. We have an experienced and dedicated team of researchers, in a rich and collaborative academic environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who enter pregnancy with obesity are more likely to experience pregnancy complications, such as gestational diabetes, hypertension, and babies born with obesity. Currently, weight management programs during pregnancy focus on helping women with obesity gain between 5 and 9 kg. However, these programs have not prevented many adverse health outcomes. This research project will determine the health effects and safety of a program to promote weight maintenance during pregnancy in women with severe obesity. If effective, the program has the potential to prevent many health problems in women who enter pregnancy with severe obesity and may also improve the health of their children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Our proposal centers on the discovery and analysis of previously unrecognized nanovesicle subpopulations that are produced by placental cells and are released to the maternal-fetal circulation. By studying these nanovesicle subpopulations in health and diseases of human pregnancy and by innovating new technologies to efficiently, rapidly, and reproducibly purify these nanovesicles from the blood and other biological media, we enable pioneering tools to interrogate the placenta in real time and improve clinical care during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Habituation is a simple form of learning that is disrupted in a wide diversity of heritable brain disorders. Habituation provides a disease-relevant, and accessible model for examining how proteins, synapses, and circuits change in real time to modify behavior. Here, I propose to establish a system that unifies molecular genetic, circuit-level, and behavioral approaches to understand how post-translational palmitoylation influences learning in vivo.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Repeated exposure to abuse and neglect substantially increases the likelihood of poor child and adult life outcomes, yet current Child Welfare (CW) family preservation services do not reduce maltreatment recidivism. We propose to determine whether our Parenting Skills Training in Affect and Interpersonal Regulation (P- STAIR), an intervention targeting maternal PTSD-related parenting deficits, would reduce recidivism. If demonstrated efficacious, P-STAIR will reduce maltreatment recidivism among high-risk CW involved mothers, thus ameliorating lives of children and families and reducing maternal stigma, while offering an intervention that is ready for CW dissemination to alter real-world clinical practice.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, social distancing guidelines have recommended that individuals stay at home and limit noncritical social contact, which has led to increased feelings of loneliness and social isolation—especially amongst older Veterans. Importantly, social isolation is considered a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease dementia and may carry consequences for cognitive function. The goal of this grant is to analyze how the pandemic has and continues to engender social and emotional factors that contribute to cognitive decline over time to better understand the long-term effects of the COVID-19 pandemic in older Veterans with and without Alzheimer’s disease, as well as techniques that can be leveraged to correct misconceptions related to social isolation and health. Understanding these complex relationships represents the first step in designing effective interventions to improve the lives of our older Veterans, including those with Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Poor muscle recovery following disuse is frequent amongst older adults leading to low muscle mass, weakness and increased disability. We have proposed to test specific mechanisms of a disrupted macrophage metabolic state during recovery from disuse in aged mice and humans. These findings will produce new knowledge of macrophage metabolism that will aid in the development of therapeutic strategies to promote muscle recovery in aged individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Personalized medicine based on patients' genomic information holds incredible promise for selecting less toxic and more effective cancer treatment. However, there are significant limitations with existing approaches to analyzing the large volume of complex and changing genomic data over the course of disease progression. The goal of this research is to develop and validate a mathematical theory and geometrical method to interpret changes in multidimensional genomic data over time that may eventually be used to predict cancer evolution and response to therapy in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT MDS-associated RNA splicing perturbations cause aberrant accumulation of R-loops, a group of transcription intermediates consisting of RNA:DNA hybrids and displaced single-stranded DNA. In this proposal, we will investigate how PARP1 senses R-loops in the genome, how it suppresses R-loop-associated DNA damage, and whether the aberrant R-loop accumulation caused by MDS-associated splicing factor mutants can be targeted by PARP inhibition. Successful completion of our studies will provide the mechanistic basis to potentially repurpose PARP inhibitors as targeted therapy for MDS patients harboring splicing factor mutations.

PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this training grant is to continue to educate the future generation of researchers who will concentrate on elucidating the actions of abused substances, understand the behavioral causes and consequences of addiction, and contribute to the development of medications for the prevention and treatment of this disease. Progress in this area requires a work force of researchers with a solid knowledge of the biological processes affected by these substances and by this disease. Those who complete this program will be prepared to have an impact on the health of millions of individuals affected by this disease, their families and all society who currently spend billions of dollars a year on this medical and social problem.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The rapid rise in prenatal exposure to prescription and other opioids over the last decade mirrors dramatic trends in opioid use across the general population of the US and in some states nearly one in four pregnancies are exposed to prescription opioids. However, the impact of prenatal opioid exposure on pregnancy and child outcomes, independent of co-occurring factors, remains unclear. This study will support a multilevel examination of individual factors, and the influence of health care and community characteristics, needed to better understand and address the effects of the opioid epidemic on women and their children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of Parkinson's disease patients in the USA is increasing at an alarming rate that necessitates the discovery of a more effective treatment that slows the progression of this debilitating disease and replaces currently used symptomatic treatments (e.g., L-DOPA supplement). In this proposal, we are initiating a continuum of research that likely to lead to the development of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors positive allosteric modulators that possess neuroprotective, anti-inflammatory, and precognitive properties that counteract the underlying pathologies of Parkinson's disease. In addition, the proposed research project will also optimize a zebrafish model for screening novel compounds for the above-mentioned therapeutic benefits and thus facilitate the development of novel therapeutics for the treatment of motor symptoms and cognitive decline associated with Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular dysfunction can result from the pathophysiology of and therapies used for pediatric acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), a common and deadly syndrome in critically ill children. Morbidity and mortality from pediatric ARDS is primarily driven by cardiovascular failure which can be a direct result of pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular dysfunction. Through serial echocardiographic and plasma biomarker assessments, the goal of this research is to determine the roles of pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular dysfunction in pediatric ARDS outcomes and to identify high risk patients that may benefit from targeted interventions to treat different types of ARDS-associated cardiovascular failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative 3q29 deletion syndrome is associated with a high risk for schizophrenia and other neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders, but the reasons for this heterogeneity are not well understood. We will evaluate these phenotypes in 200 individuals with 3q29 deletion syndrome, and assess how sex and background genetic factors may influence the phenotype. We will also compare our data with >2,000 samples from other genomic disorders, to understand how the 3q29 deletion compares to the broader landscape of rare genetic disorders associated with developmental brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Engagement in HIV medical care and adherence to HIV medications are both essential in improving health outcomes among people living with HIV (PLH), but PLH living in rural areas—who suffer higher mortality rates than their urban counterparts—can confront multiple barriers to care engagement and adherence, especially as they face the logistical, medical, and social challenges associated with aging. This project will test the efficacy of two interventions—supportive-expressive peer social support groups and strengths-based case management—to determine their impact on health outcomes and quality of life among rural older PLH in the Southern U.S. If efficacious, these interventions could be disseminated by organizations serving rural PLH throughout the U.S. and result in improved health outcomes and quality of life in this population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Over 700,000 Veterans are regularly admitted to one of over 120 VHA hospitals providing inpatient acute medical-surgical, psychiatric and long-term care. Staffing by over 98,000 nursing personnel is a vital part of inpatient services. A significant body of literature demonstrates that both the amount of nurse staffing and the characteristics of the nurses available to provide care effects patient outcomes. The study we propose fills a gap in our understanding of system level decisions on patient outcomes, specifically this will be the first large- scale study that matches nurses to the patients that they care for each shift, allowing for more precise estimates of the effects of nurse staffing on patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL - PROJECT NARRATIVE We are all familiar with some of the components of biological systems – DNA, proteins, cells, organs, individuals – but understanding biological systems involves more than just cataloging its component parts. It is critical to understand the many interactions of these parts within systems, and how these systems give rise to biological functions and responses and determine states of health and disease. The National Resource for Network Biology provides the scientific community with a broad platform of computational tools for the study of biological networks and for incorporating network knowledge in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative Respiratory problems are a common cause pain, disability and death of US military veterans and soldiers. Since there are no long-term effective treatments to restore airway function when long segments of the trachea are damaged, we propose to engineer a functional neotrachea using autologously sourced individual cell-only bioinks within a three-dimensional printing platform. The engineered neotrachea will be comprised of cartilaginous, vascular and epithelial tissue that will provide mechanical rigidity, the ability to anastomosis with the native vasculature, and protection from outside exposure, respectively, to support airway function. This new strategy to create functional trachea tissue through a scaffold-free cell printing platform may represent a therapeutic advance to treat veterans and soldiers suffering from airway damage.

PHR: Valium and related drugs, referred to as “benzodiazepines” are prescribed widely for the treatment of anxiety disorders, one of the most common psychiatric disorders in the U.S. Benzodiazepines are considered to be among the safest prescription drugs in modern medicine, but they unfortunately are also drugs of abuse. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to rapidly and selectively prepare targeted chemical structures is vital for the discovery and production of new medicines. The aim of this project is to provide chemists with new synthetic capabilities that improve access to compounds highly desired in the pharmaceutical industry. Specifically, inexpensive bases are used to promote reactions that streamline the synthesis of functionalized arenes and difluorobenzylic compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. Narrative Scientific advances in genetics require complex and novel methods and their application in the complex setting of psychiatric disorders. To reduce the suffering and disability related to mental illness in society, clinical research needs to translate findings from genetics and ongoing developments in the neurosciences into better treatment, prevention, and healthcare strategies. Both psychiatric genetics and translational research need to address underrepresented populations and the impact of health disparities in order to improve population mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The surge of targeted therapies into the treatment of metastatic cancer has, in part, been fueled by growing enthusiasm among medical oncologists regarding their potential impact on survival for patients with very poor prognosis. Because of the potential for variations and disparities in access to and use of these high-cost, high stakes therapies, there is a critical and urgent need for population-level research about variations in use and the drivers of these variations. This study uses registry-based clinical, sociodemographic, and treatment data from a large population-based sample of diverse patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer, genitourinary cancer, and melanoma, as well as interviews and surveys of their treating medical oncologists, to examine potential variations and disparities in patient use of targeted therapies and to understand the contribution of clinician-level factors to these variations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Existing behavioral weight loss programs focus almost exclusively on individuals and self-regulation, even though it is well established that weight management is a dyadic issue in married and cohabitating couples. The proposed study seeks to identify the optimal components of an innovative mHealth weight management approach for couples. Four dyadic intervention components (dyadic action planning, joint feedback on goal progress, autonomy support training, and home environment modifications) will be tested to determine which components contribute significantly to weight loss.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: ASSOCIATION OF FOOD AND DRUG OFFICIALS
PHR: RFA-FD-22-021 AFDO’s System for Agriculture, Food, Health, E-Inspections and Registration (SAFHER): Project Narrative The Association of Food and Drug Officials’ (AFDO) efforts under this cooperative agreement are intended to support the planning, development, implementation, operation, and maintenance of data management system to be utilized by State, Local, Tribal, and Territorial (SLTT) partners in both human and animal food programs. AFDO will build on an already established user community of stakeholders to enhance FDA’s ORA Data Exchange capabilities by utilizing software development methodologies (i.e. Agile) to ensure a long-term sustainable data management system that is easy to use and maintain by state regulatory partners during and after this cooperative agreement. Through effective governance, vendor procurement, and resource management, this project will deliver a national regulatory data repository that will work towards achieving a national Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS) while promoting One Health and supporting domestic mutual reliance initiatives to protect the food supply and advance public health.

PHR: The goal of this work is to apply new approaches my lab has developed for remote control of synaptic function to understand how different forms of neural plasticity relate to cognitive functions like learning and memory. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that is the most common cause of dementia, and a significant healthcare burden worldwide. This condition results in progressive memory loss and cognitive decline, which lead to dramatic repercussions for affected individuals and their families. Many genetic studies have identified sex differences to be a critical factor in AD risk, progression, and severity across individuals, but precisely which sex-related mechanisms are responsible for these differences remain unknown. These studies systematically dissect the mechanisms underlying these observed differences using cutting-edge experimental and computational methods to predict sex-specific causal variants, regulatory regions, genes, and pathways; and systematic experimental characterization of predicted drivers using mouse models to better understand the mechanistic basis of sex-related differences in AD. These results will form the foundation for a deeper understanding of AD and new therapeutic development against this devastating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE End-stage liver disease places a disproportionately large burden on the healthcare system with certain individuals experiencing frequent repeat hospitalization and emergency room visits. Healthcare reform can improve outcomes for these individuals if targeted to their needs. The studies proposed will lead to accurate prediction of this vulnerable group by using multi-dimensional data and will establish the feasibility of using novel mobile phone program to improve healthcare use in liver disease. The proposed studies will bring the field closer to providing care that is (1) more aligned to patient goals, (2) adheres to current guidelines, (3) equitable and (4) at a lower cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired artery function is a major risk factor for cardiovascular diseases in later middle-aged and older (MA/O; ³50 years) men and women. In the proposed project, I will investigate the effectiveness and underlying molecular mechanisms of oral supplementation with acetate, a molecule derived from the digestion of dietary fiber, to improve artery function with aging in both preclinical mouse models and in humans by conducting a clinical trial in MA/O adults. Overall, the findings of this project have the potential to identify acetate as a new therapy for treating impaired artery function with aging and thereby reducing risk of cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This program provides a unique interdisciplinary training opportunity for scientists interested in the study of emotion and its relation to mental health and mental illness. Virtually every psychiatric disorder, and many physical disorders, involves a disorder of emotion and we seek to train the next generation of scientists who can make fundamental discoveries in this area and with this new knowledge, develop new empirically validated treatments. Understanding how emotion contributes to these disorders, the mechanisms by which the relevant brain circuits impact peripheral biology and organ systems, will be essential in the development of treatments that include the mind, brain and body and that are essential for optimal health.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Emotion Research

PHR: By 2030, it is estimated that around 76 million people will have osteoporosis in the U.S. This holds significant implications for Veteran healthcare because nearly three-quarters (72.3%) of the patients served by the VA are over 50 years old, while at the same time, the size of the VA population over the age of 65 is projected to double in size over the next 30 years. The purpose of this renewal application is to address whether replenishing the matricellular protein Cyr61/CCN1Cyr61 to the aging bone matrix will restore the ability of the MSC microenvironment (niche) to rejuvenate old MSC self-renewal, differentiation, and bone formation capacity. The information gained from the proposed studies will provide great benefit to both the veteran and general population by developing a new approach for treating osteoporosis that focuses on restoring the aging stem cell niche.

PROJECT_TITLE: Reversing Age-related Bone Loss by Administration of the Matricellular Protein Cyr61/CCN1

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: This project will address the need for improved therapies for advanced well differentiated/dedifferentiated liposarcoma (DDLS), a rare cancer that generally does not respond to chemotherapy. We will evaluate the effectiveness of the combination of palbociclib, a drug that targets a genetic change characteristic of DDLS, with INCMGA0012, an investigational drug that de-inhibits immune responses against the tumor. We will also search for molecular indicators (biomarkers) of benefit from this combination to select the best patients to receive this treatment in the future, and, to better understand how the drugs interact, investigate the relationship between palbociclib induced growth arrest and antitumor immune responses.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Identifying senescence and immune biomarkers predictive of benefit to combined CDK4 and checkpoint blockade inhibition in patients with dedifferentiated liposarcoma

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative . Nanoscale organization of proteins is emerging as a critical process controlling cell function in health and disease. The long-term goal of this study is to examine mechanisms underlying the spatial nano-organization and activity of a key protein involved in the regulation of smooth muscle cells that make up the arterial wall during physiological conditions and during elevations in extracellular glucose and diabetes. The study fulfills relevant public health goals and NIH mission by generating fundamental basic knowledge that could help identify and develop novel treatment strategies to address vascular complications during diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuropsychiatric manifestations are common in Rare Genetic Disorders (RGDs), affecting brain development and functioning throughout the lifespan; copy number variants (CNVs) at 22q11.2 and 16p11.2 loci are among the most common RGDs impacting developmental psychopathology. We propose to capitalize on highly informative samples and integrate prospective dimensional and categorical phenotyping with whole genome sequencing across these reciprocal CNVs. This work will identify convergent risk mechanisms for developmental neuropsychiatric disorders that have relevance to the broader population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed studies address a gap in understanding of how an emerging class of resistance enzymes, identi- fied in a growing number of human-associated settings, have the potential to severely compromise treatment of bacterial pathogens. The proposed research will identify new avenues for detection and intervention which are relevant to public health, because current treatment options for increasingly drug resistant bacteria are failing. This project is relevant to the NIH's mission of developing fundamental knowledge that may reduce the burden of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Functional intrinsic optical signal (IOS) imaging, also termed as optoretinography (ORG) or optophysiology, promises a high-resolution method for noninvasive, objective assessment of retinal physiology. This study is to validate functional IOS imaging of stimulus-evoked light changes correlated with the activation phase of phototransduction, which can advance early disease diagnosis and prompt treatment evaluation of age- related macular degeneration (AMD), retinitis pigmentosa (RP) and other eye conditions that are known to cause photoreceptor dysfunctions. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is prevalent in humans and has been implicated in the malignant brain tumor glioblastoma (GBM) and other cancers. We have developed a novel murine model of CMV in GBM and identified for the first time potential molecular and cellular mechanisms by which CMV can accelerate tumor growth and alter responses to therapy. Therefore, in this project we will use this model alongside human GBM samples from patients with known CMV status to further understand the biology of CMV in GBM and assess new approaches to improve GBM treatment with the goal of rapid translation to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed program is to prepare MDs, PhDs and PharmDs for a career in translational research in mental health with a focus on schizophrenia and psychosis-related disorders. MPRC research engages a broad range of integrated and translational science including; neurophysiology, neuroimaging, basic neurochemistry, circuitry modeling in rodents and miniature pigs, disease etiology, domains of psychopathology and endophenotypes, neurocognition, experimental therapeutics and clinical trials. This competitive five-year renewal application proposes to leverage our previous success and continue to improve our training approach to produce productive, well-rounded, translationally-focused scientists.
PI_NAMEs: CARPENTER, WILLIAM T.;ELMER, GREGORY I (contact);KELLY, DEANNA L

PROJECT_TITLE: Multidisciplinary Schizophrenia Research Training

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative To better understand the causes of complex neurological birth defects and disorders in humans, there is a need to resolve the effects of key signaling pathways on system-wide stem cell interactions and neuronal differentiation in vivo over broad segments of a neuronal population’s developmental timeline. We will directly analyze in vivo data at high spatiotemporal resolution, without reducing biological complexity, to understand and predict multicellular behavior in the developing vertebrate olfactory epithelium. Our work will determine broadly applicable mechanisms of stem cell migration and neurogenesis, including how two progenitor cell types interact with each other and other cell types to coordinate the assembly of a diverse neuronal population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use and addiction persist as systemic public health problems; preventing them will improve the nation’s health, yet successful prevention is complex. The proposed interdisciplinary training program will produce a new generation of behavioral scientists who are experts in conducting rigorous, responsible, innovative research on the prevention of substance use and addiction. By integrating prevention science and innovative methods, these prevention scientists will be leaders in preventing harmful substance use and reducing social, disease, and economic burdens.
PROJECT_TERMS: Methodology;Prevention;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Prevention and Methodology Training

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In a previously performed study, healthy persons were randomly assigned to two years of reducing calorie intake or continuing eating as usual. Results showed the low calorie group had superior benefits in multiple areas of aging-related health. Samples and data from this project remain available for additional studies to better understand calorie reduction effects. This proposal describes a plan to make the best possible use of these samples and data and also develop new investigators and projects in the area of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of disability and death among U.S. older adults and represents an enormous public health burden. Although CVD risk assessment is recommended as the foundation to primary prevention and guiding treatment decisions, the current tool for risk assessment performs poorly in older adults and among disadvantaged population groups. We propose to address these limitations by incorporating changes in risk factors over time and integrating social determinants of health to improve CVD risk-prediction and its translation to disease prevention in U.S. older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional alterations in the endothelial cells lining the vessel wall represent an important step in atherosclerotic initiation, progression, and clinical complications. Our research identifies Nck1 and IRAK1 as novel players in this process, regulating proinflammatory gene expression in response to changes in the local microenvironment. Understanding the molecular mechanisms controlling endothelial cell function by the microenvironment may provide novel therapeutic targets to limit chronic inflammatory diseases, such as atherosclerosis and arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many people suffer from Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF), but unfortunately, we do not have any drug treatments that consistently improve the disability and reduced quality of life caused by this syndrome. The goal of this proposal is to test whether new drugs and drug combinations can increase exercise tolerance in HFpEF patients by improving how the skeletal muscle gets blood and generates energy. We hope that this proposal will identify new ways to treat HFpEF patients, allowing these individuals, who are currently very limited in what they can do and how they feel, to enjoy life more.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ion channels and transporters regulate the movement of ions and small molecules across biological membranes. We use NMR spectroscopy together with biochemical and functional assays to decipher the molecular mechanism of these integral membrane proteins. We use this knowledge both to gain insight into fundamental biological processes and to assess how we might target bacterial transporters to develop new antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of patients suffer from life-threatening accidents and sudden medical emergencies every year, and the technologies used to diagnose, monitor, and treat these patients have special engineering requirements compared to technologies for any other health condition. Given the abruptness and urgency of acute illnesses and injuries, technologies must work very rapidly, be highly accurate, and be easy to use by various medical personnel both in and outside the hospital (e.g., in ambulances), yet students are rarely taught how to address these unique design issues. The new Acute and Critical Care Engineering (ACCE) Training Program will provide Engineering pre-doctoral students with interdisciplinary mentorship, specialized curriculum tracks, clinical immersion, focused design training, and entrepreneurial workshops, equipping them to address these engineering challenges and collaboratively develop, test, and commercialize new life-saving technologies.

PROJECT_TITLE: Acute and Critical Care Engineering (ACCE) Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative In order to discover and generate new pharmacogenetic hypotheses from drug interaction evidences published in the scientific literature, we will develop novel machine learning methods, including active learning allowing human involvement and knowledge base reasoning. These new pharmacogenetics hypotheses will be tested in a biobank. These pharmacogenetics findings will contribute significantly towards precision medicine and improve clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The effectiveness of treating substance use disorders is based on our understanding of drug addiction and the currently available intervention approaches. The proposed training program addresses this need by providing young basic and clinical scientists with the knowledge base and the research skills to investigate the neurobiology of substance use disorders and develop therapeutic strategies to treat addiction.
PROJECT_TERMS: Drug abuse;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Drug Abuse Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since its discovery, adult mammalian hippocampal neurogenesis—particularly human—has attracted attention and controversy, as examining it directly has been hindered by the lack of an in vivo measure that can be performed in the human (post mortem studies using immunostaining are quite limiting). Our group has identified the first and only in vivo, non-invasive, magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS)-based biomarker of neurogenesis: a lipid-based signal resonating at 1.28ppm. Here, we propose to develop data acquisition and processing techniques to significantly enhance biomarker detection and quantification in vivo so that it might become a widely-adopted measure of adult human neurogenesis that will inform a wide range of studies on memory, aging, AD/ADRD, depression, and a range of other conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fecal incontinence (FI) is a common, yet debilitating gastrointestinal disorder impacting 1 in 10 people and associated with significant healthcare costs. In this proposal, we will comprehensively investigate the role of both dietary and supplemental fiber in relation to risk and progression of FI and examine the interplay between fiber, symptoms, hormones, and the gut microbiome. Our study has the potential to lead to clinical recommendations regarding the use of dietary fiber among people at-risk for FI or with established FI and will offer new insights into FI etiopathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Mitophagy removes damaged mitochondria inside the cell and the accumulation of dysfunctional mitochondria impacts the ability for the cell to make energy. Our proposed studies will reveal how mitophagy impacts and influences other cellular processes such as cell division and inflammation in different cell types. The information gained will inform us on how mutations in mitophagy genes contribute to a complex, diverse array of diseases such as cancer, encephalitis, and neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to develop new protocols for the early detection of pancreatic cancer, using a novel strategy for combining human-expert knowledge with deep neural networks. Our study will systematically derive feature grouping strategies from clinical workflows using Electronic Health Records (EHR) to develop predictive and potentially insightful deep learning models. As a result, we will be able to propose new predictors associated with pancreatic cancer represented by single or composite variables according to the grouping strategies and their causal relationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although metabolic demand from neuronal function has been shown to regulate angiogenesis in the retina, a thorough mechanistic understanding of how neuronal activity regulates retinal angiogenesis and blood-retinal barrier maturation remains unknown. Using genetic models to modulate cholinergic and glutamatergic neuronal activities, this project will explore how these two types of neuronal activities (separately or in combination) regulate retinal angiogenesis and blood-retinal barrier maturation. The knowledge gathered from this project may be of critical importance to develop novel therapeutic interventions for degenerative diseases and ischemic retinopathies of the eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to combine novel cellular quantification experimental technologies with multiscale mathematical approaches in order to gain a deeper, more robust understanding of tumor-immune dynamics and to harness this knowledge for human benefit. Using bladder cancer as our platform, we will develop a comprehensive and predictive 3D computational framework that will be used to optimize combination immunotherapy and receptor kinase targeted therapy. Our experimentally- driven multiscale approach is poised to significantly enhance the current understanding of differential cell-kill mechanisms on tumor-immune outcomes and to improve the ability to combine promising drugs for clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Individuals who have developed rheumatoid arthritis (RA) demonstrate several unique types of inflammatory and autoimmune cell patterns in the inflamed synovium. Molecular dissection of the synovial tissue in patients with RA has identified a number of new features with pathogenic, personalized therapeutic and prognostic importance. Using a pipeline of synovial samples obtained from patients with RA, this group will advance the field by increasing our understanding of the three-dimensional architecture and mechanisms by which cell populations interact both with each other and the systemic immune system, as well as interlink these phenotypes to patient characteristics and response to specific therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) has a grim prognosis with median survival of approximately 14-16 months which hasn't changed in over 15 years. Machine learning has offered great promise in a number of areas in which complex information is to be synthesized for decision making. The current project proposes to refine quantitative imaging methods leveraging machine learning (QIML), with emphasis on a) obtaining rich imaging phenotypes relying on multi-parametric signals, textures, shape properties, spatial patterns derived from atlas registration, and biophysical models of tumor growth, and b) integrating such imaging signatures using machine learning into predictors of clinical outcome, as well as of early recurrence from peri-tumoral infiltration. A unique consortium of 14 leading institutions internationally and over 4,500 patients/MRIs will be leveraged for training and testing these QIMLs. This unique software and data resource will likely further mobilize a broad community of quantitative imaging researchers of GB around the world and provide precision diagnostics and personalized AI-guided treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative. Stress is commonly experienced in daily life. However, excessive activation of the stress system can result in reduced resilience and predisposes to alcohol and drug abuse as well as a variety of illnesses. This Phase II SBIR proposal seeks to develop a novel therapeutic to reduce the detrimental consequences of hyperactivity of the hypothalamic pituitary adrenal axis (HPA), which characterizes alcohol use disorder (AUD) as well as other conditions including drug abuse, depression, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases, among others.

PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE The overall goal of this post-doctoral training program in genomic medicine is to provide clinical/translational scientists with a multiyear training program comprised of didactic, research, clinical genomic medicine, and leadership training. At the end of their training period, trainees possess knowledge and skills that will enable them to manage the challenges of evidence generation and clinical use of genomic medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative  Chemicals produced by living organisms, or natural products, serve as the basis for a large number of pharmaceuticals on the market today. As genome sequencing has become more accessible, it has become apparent that the number of natural products that have been characterized is dwarfed by the number of biological pathways that exist in nature that can produce them, suggesting there are many more compounds to be discovered. To efficiently explore the compounds that could be produced by some of these pathways we are studying the enzymes that biosynthesize a class of natural products, and through these studies will develop an approach to produce millions of natural product-like compounds and test them for biological activity useful for the treatment of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/HEALTH RELEVANCE The major health problems in the US result from brain diseases, including Alzheimer's, schizophrenia, alcoholism, drug addiction, depression and bipolar disorders. Incomplete understanding of the neuroscience of these conditions accounts for the limited number of effective treatments. The goal of this proposal is to provide state-of-the-art training for the next generation of neuroscientists who are equipped to solve these health problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The proposed research has significant public health relevancy because improved alcohol screening in HIV care settings in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) has the potential to improve rates of referral to evidence-based services, reduce the alcohol treatment gap, and therefore reduce the deleterious impacts of alcohol on HIV prevention and treatment outcomes. This study will describe test characteristics of UEtG in a novel population of HIV-affected adolescents and young adults in SSA and will inform the development of implementation strategies to enhance the adoption and uptake of alcohol biomarkers in HIV clinics. Given the lack of alcohol biomarker studies among adolescents in HIV programs worldwide, this study will provide knowledge cross-over to high-income countries to improve quality of care among minority, and other underserved populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumors that express estrogen receptor-α (ER+) make up the largest subclass of breast tumors, and account for most breast cancer mortalities. This proposal focuses on the control of ER activity, leveraging receptor post-translational regulation as a means to better define and ultimately control ER function in ER+ therapy-resistant breast cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Functional recovery from stroke determines the patients’ quality of life. The goal of the proposed project is to unravel the cortical circuit mechanisms underlying functional recovery after stroke. We will employ innovative approaches using state-of-the-art two-photon imaging techniques combined with optogenetic stimulation in mice. Our proposed study will provide pivotal information on how we can manipulate cortical circuits to maximize functional recovery following stroke.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The principal aims of the Training Program in Demography at the University of Pennsylvania accord with the NICHD Population Dynamics Branch’s (PDB) mission to support research and research training in demography, reproductive health, and population health. In particular, training in demography as proposed in this application is essential for research on morbidity and mortality, COVID-19, HIV/AIDS, fertility, families, population movement, and population composition that is central to the PDB mission. The Training Program in Demography at Penn builds on a strong faculty, dedicated students, and an impressive group of alumni to maintain its ongoing relevance to the mission of NICHD, which is “to understand human development, improve reproductive health, enhance the lives of children and adolescents, and optimize abilities for all.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Narrowing or leakage of the valves in the heart is common and can be addressed by repairing or replacing the valve. However, the optimal timing of these procedures is difficult to determine, and if performed too late then the heart may be irreversibly damaged. In this proposal we will develop new imaging techniques to detect very subtle changes in the heart muscle and determine whether they can be used to better understand when to replace/repair damaged heart valves.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE My lab studies circadian-regulated processes and their contributions to health and disease; circadian regulation refers to daily oscillations in biological functions (e.g., metabolism, sleep) and is a universal, evolutionarily conserved feature from bacteria to humans. Proper circadian regulation is important for human health; despite the profound effects of circadian regulation on human health and physiology, it remains unclear how loss of circadian regulation contributes to the progression of disease (i.e., metabolic disorders, bacterial infection). In this proposal, we focus on circadian-regulated metabolism in Drosophila and its role in sensitivity to oxidative stress due to chronic short sleep (Project 1) and regulation of host tolerance of bacterial infection (Project 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While there have been major biomedical science discoveries over the last two decades, we still face a steady decline in our collective ability to translate these remarkable basic science discoveries into new drugs and treatments for patients. In this training program, we address this challenge directly with a creative approach to training early career physicians and basic scientists in the essential tools for translational patient-oriented research, drug development, and commercialization of basic discoveries. We implement this training in the scientific context of the study of high blood pressure in the lungs, an important and common complication of many heart and lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Severe spinal cord injury (SCI) remains incurable as there are no medications that can reverse the injury- related nerve tissue damage through a sustained program of neuroregeneration. We have identified several small molecule compounds able to promote the regrowth of damaged nerve cells in a tissue culture model. The mechanism of action of these nonpeptide neurotrophic compounds appears to be novel and as such we plan to elucidate the mechanism and subsequently apply the knowledge gained toward repurposing existing drugs or designing new compounds for regenerative treatment of SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Unscheduled whole-genome doubling events give rise to genetically unstable polyploid cells that can promote disease. The aims of this proposal are designed to identify unique the genetic adaptations acquired by polyploid cells that enable their sustained proliferation and survival. Successful completion of these aims will provide significant insight into the genesis and evolution of whole genome-doubled cells in vivo, as well as reveal innovative therapeutic avenues to selectively kill pathological polyploid cells while sparing the normal cells that comprise human tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The soil-dwelling bacteria Streptomyces make numerous molecules that humans use as medicines. Analysis of the DNA of these bacteria suggests they have the potential to make many more useful molecules, but they do not make them under standard laboratory conditions. The objectives of this proposal are to 1) discover chemical elicitors that induce the production of these molecules, to understand their mechanisms of induction, and to use these elicitors to identify novel bioactive natural products and 2) to use organic synthesis to access bioinformatically predicted natural products that are currently inaccessible using other means.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project investigates the effects of minimum wage increases in the U.S. on maternal health outcomes. It explores potential intermediary pathways through which minimum wage policies may affect maternal health and health care costs associated with pregnancy, as well as disparities in these outcomes. Findings provide causal evidence on the potential for economic policies – such as raising the minimum wage – to address the current maternal health crisis in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance V(D)J recombination is essential for the development of a functional adaptive immune system. Failure of V(D)J recombination can cause immunodeficiency and dysregulated V(D)J recombination can result in autoimmunity or chromosomal translocations that contribute to tumorigenesis. These studies will elucidate basic mechanisms that contribute to normal immune system development as well as pathologies such as immunodeficiency, autoimmunity and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite significant advances in the development of nanobiomaterials for controlled drug delivery, substantial difficulties remain for the scalable nanofabrication and encapsulation of therapeutics. In particular, the encapsulation and intracellular delivery of water-soluble payloads, like proteins and nucleic acids, still present difficulties for reproducibility, especially when co-loading multiple drugs that each possess distinct physicochemical properties. To address these issues, we will model, optimize and validate a novel scalable means of supramolecular homopolymer self-assembly that achieves >90% encapsulation efficiency universally for multiple hydrophilic and hydrophobic small molecules and biologics simultaneously.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The muscarinic acetylcholine receptor 1 (CHRM1, M1) is critical for cholinergic neurotransmission and the subject of multiple drug discovery programs, as well as an ongoing clinical trial for cognition in Alzheimer’s disease. Using 44 temporal cortex samples, we have established that CHRM1 expression is significantly decreased in the brains of defined subpopulations of patients with the neurodevelopmental disorder Rett syndrome (RTT), and that positive allosteric modulation of the M1 receptor improves multiple symptom domains of RTT model mice. Here we propose to 1) test the effects of M1 potentiation against a battery of RTT phenotypes 2) establish a paradigm to use mutation type to drive precision medicine therapeutics in RTT and 3) define the mechanism of action of M1 PAMs on RTT respiratory phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite remarkable advances in the immunopathogenesis of autoimmune and immune mediated diseases (AIMDs), the environmental factors that orchestrate the initiation and perpetuation of these disorders or determine therapeutic responses remain to be fully elucidated. Chief among them is the human microbiome, which has long been shown to contribute to inflammatory diseases. Successful completion of our proposed studies will provide key insights into the pathogenesis of AIMDs by interrogating (a) if the gut, skin and oral microbiome contribute to the initial inflammatory events in AIMDs, and (b) whether the gut microbiome can serve as a modulator of therapeutic responses to currently available drugs, ultimately identifying patients that are more likely to experience clinical improvement prior to treatment initiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African Americans experience the highest levels of tobacco-related disease and death, despite smoking fewer cigarettes per day than Whites, and have relatively low quit rates when stopping smoking. Finding new approaches to enhancing treatment for African American smokers is a critical public health priority, and identifying methods of improving treatment outcomes from existing pharmacotherapy is central to this goal. This study will evaluate the efficacy of extended varenicline treatment to improve quit rates in African American daily smokers of all smoking levels, with the goal of reducing tobacco-related health disparities, and thereby reducing morbidity and mortality in this high-risk group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Diabetes is a disorder of high blood glucose, that tends to get worse; over time, patients need more and more drugs. This pattern is caused by overwork of the body's insulin-producing β-cells, because patients' glucose levels are typically above normal; if we kept glucose levels normal – reducing β-cell work – we might be able to keep the disease from getting worse. Our trial is aimed to show that adjusting the drugs to keep glucose levels normal, can help to preserve β-cell function compared to usual diabetes care, possibly reduce the tendency to develop the eye and kidney complications of diabetes, and might also be more cost-effective than usual care.

PHR: Project Narrative  We propose to test Black Girls Move, a school-linked daughter/mother physical activity and dietary behavior program, with 9th and 10th grade students. This program is designed to prevent obesity in Black adolescent females and thus aligns with the NIH mission to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability. This project is relevant to public health because it holds the potential to reduce population health disparities impacted by structural racism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Mutations in genes GUCY2D and GUCA1A cause retinal degeneration by deregulating cGMP production in photoreceptors. We propose to explore versatile molecular mechanisms capable of averting the adverse biochemical process causing death of photoreceptors and thus rescue them. This knowledge can become useful in developing treatment for the presently incurable GUCY2D and GUCA1A dominant retinopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to continue an impactful biomedical research center to foster investigations applying cutting-edge innovations to illuminate the causes of human disease occurrence and progression. As such, our Center has the potential to change policy and practice and to reduce disease burden throughout the life course. Our COBRE Center for Molecular Epidemiology provides a unique and critical resource from which to grow the next generation of scientists as well as advance more senior investigators within Dartmouth, with regional partners, and across molecular epidemiology more broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The vital single-cell lining (epithelium) of digestive organs is sustained by cells that lie beneath it (mesenchyme) and provide known and unknown signals. This proposal aims to provide new insights into the mesenchymal compartment’s role during fetal development and restoration of intestinal stem cells after lethal cell injury. The studies will improve understanding of how interactions between the epithelium and mesenchyme may be harnessed in the future to develop new treatment approaches toward inflammatory bowel disorders and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative It is well established that fasting glucose levels increase with aging, and that impaired glucose metabolism is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s Disease. Heat therapy has been independently shown to improve blood glucose regulation, insulin resistance, and inflammation. This project will provide a comprehensive understanding of the impact of heat therapy on glucose homeostasis and brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Prion diseases are rapidly progressive, fatal neurodegenerative disorders caused by aggregated prion protein. We have found that shortening extracellular glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) in the brain can enhance prion clearance and prolong survival. The proposed studies are expected to reveal mechanisms underlying how prions form plaques in the brain parenchyma and vasculature as well as test strategies to promote clearance, towards a goal of reducing plaque burden and slowing disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: HIV-ME R01 Study Narrative Great strides have been made in the technology that allows us to use HIV genetic sequence information to analyze and track how HIV is transmitted within populations and between individuals. More accurate information about HIV transmission may help efforts to reduce the spread of HIV but may also increase the risk to participants involved in the research. This project will measure both the risks and benefits of using this technology for HIV prevention research and then gauge the acceptability of these approaches in key stakeholder groups living with HIV and at risk for HIV infection across the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial and ethnic minority young adults in the U.S. are at increased risk for premature discontinuation of treatment for serious mental illness. Despite the significant public health impact of untreated mental illness, there are no evidence-based treatment engagement interventions explicitly designed to be culturally- responsive to this population. The proposed study partners with racial and ethnic minority young adults with serious mental illness to adapt and test a brief intervention that incorporates their unique developmental and cultural preferences to improve their engagement in treatment and decrease mental health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research study aims to use recent advances in causal machine learning methods to determine the influence of e-cigarettes (EC) use on subsequent combustible cigarette smoking in the overall US youth and adult populations and in vulnerable subgroups, and to evaluate methods for generalizable EC exposure effects. Study findings will inform tobacco product regulators whether and among whom EC use has an impact on cigarette smoking. This effort may lead to a better understanding of the causal processes underlying EC use, and ultimately, inform evidence-based regulation and policy making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies from the last several years have highlighted the importance of long noncoding RNAs in human development, health, and diseases such as cancer and atherosclerosis, but the mechanisms by which RNAs effect epigenetic change remain largely unknown. X-chromosome inactivation serves as an excellent model to study RNA regulation because this process is controlled by a series of RNA-based switches. Our proposed research will dissect mechanisms of RNA regulation by investigating its role in chromosome pairing, gene silencing, and imprinting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Currently, the most effective therapy for head and neck cancer and prostate cancer is X-ray (photon) or proton- based radiotherapy, given at conventional dose rates with or without systematic therapy, but this therapy comes at the cost of both acute and late toxicity that worsen quality of life and can contribute to mortality and high treatment cost. We propose that ultrahigh dose rate “FLASH” delivery of X-ray or proton irradiation (dose rate ≥40 Gy/s vs ~0.1 Gy/s) can deliver curative doses to tumors in milliseconds while mitigating normal tissue damage, and subsequently reducing the cost. Our long-term objective is to establish a foundation for the clinical use of FLASH radiation to improve tumor and normal tissue outcomes in head and neck and prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While a large body of research has demonstrated high risk patterns of prescription opioid use predicts overdose, the role of prescription stimulants on the drug overdose epidemic is understudied. Using novel comprehensive state-wide datasets from Oregon and Massachusetts, the proposed research will fill a critical gap by assessing the impact of prescription stimulant use on drug overdoses. By identifying prescribing patterns with protective or harmful effects on rates of drug overdoses, evidence generated from these studies could lead to changes in policy, early intervention with patients at risk of overdose, and public health initiatives such as continuing medical education activities or updated clinical guidelines that promote safe prescribing of stimulants with goal of mitigating stimulant-related overdose.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) In spite of the essential role of NPR1 (NONEXPRESSOR OF PATHOGENSIS-RELATED GENES 1) as a master regulator of the salicylic acid (SA)-mediated immune response in plants, the molecular mechanism of its function has remained poorly understood. Genetically engineered crops through enhancement of the NPR1-mediated innate immunity display broad-spectrum disease resistance without compromising plant fitness, leading to a decreased usage of pesticides and reduction of the selective pressure for pesticide-resistant pathogens. As SA and derivatives, such as aspirin (acetylsalicylate), have numerous health benefits in humans, including fever reduction and pain relief, as well as decreased death tolls from cardiovascular diseases and cancers, a thorough understanding the SA-NPR1 signaling pathway in plants may also bear significant implications in understanding the medicinal consequence of these molecules against a variety of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it the first preclinical model of Pulmonary Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (PLCH). This project will address the function and significance of myelo-monocytic cells and their expression of both soluble and cell surface ligands responsible for the generation of inflammatory lesions in PLCH patients The successful completion of this project is expected to reveal novel insight into disease development and progression, identify new targets aimed at decreasing morbidity and mortality, and test the potential possibility of immune function inhibition as a possible treatment for PLCH patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research directly addresses the current limitations of stem cell-based ocular surface therapies and the lack of viable inventions for restoring the limbal niche environment in patients with limbal stem cell deficiency. Results from this study will help drive new clinical applications for Descemet’s membrane on the ocular surface, as a novel limbal niche surrogate for supporting cultured limbal stem cell transplantation. Short-term, this will help improve therapeutic outcomes for patient’s blinded by limbal stem cell deficiency; long-term, this will help inform future research into alternative limbal niche surrogates for ocular surface reconstruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While there are effective treatments for prediabetes including the intensive lifestyle program, Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP), enrollment and uptake of these programs are low. Research from our team and others has shown that patient barriers to addressing prediabetes include inadequate knowledge, difficulty with maintaining discipline and motivation, and psychosocial stressors, all of which lead to lower patient activation, a key driver of positive health outcomes. With this proposal, we will develop a prediabetes digital patient activation tool that aims to increase patient activation and thereby uptake of treatments like the DPP which have been shown to decrease the risk of progression to diabetes.

PHR: Project Narrative Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most prevalent form of liver disease worldwide and is estimated to affect nearly a third of the population. Although its underlying mechanisms remain incompletely understood, aging is known to play a major role in the development of NAFLD. The proposed research will investigate the mechanism of age-associated NAFLD using mouse models. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: There is a critical shortage of physician-scientists to address the significant problems caused by child and adolescent mental health illness. This proposed research program will fill a critical gap in training and a national need. Our program will pair substantial dedicated research time with excellent clinical training in our child and adolescent psychiatry fellowship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) is a substantial and rapidly-growing public health burden, with no available disease-modifying treatments. Well-being is an understudied but important protective factor against ADRD risk and progression, given that it has been associated with ADRD risk and is amenable to intervention. The planned research will examine multiple types of well-being as predictors of cognitive resilience to ADRD neuropathology as well as bidirectional associations between well-being and cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma (ARMS) is a cancer of the soft tissues. This disease often responds to chemotherapy, but in many patients the available treatments fail --a deadly outcome. We identified how a cancer- causing fused gene called PAX3:FOXO1 leads to treatment failure. We have recently published that, remarkably, PAX3:FOXO1 can be silenced by entinostat, a drug recently granted FDA breakthrough designation for breast cancer. We find entinostat dramatically improves response to frontline chemotherapy in human tumors implanted in mice – which has led directly to a Children's Oncology Group Phase I clinical safety trial (now complete) and a phase II clinical trial concept for rhabdomyosarcoma patients. In considering the more expansive Phase II clinical trial, we ask: can we get insight into sensitivity or resistance by knowing more precisely how entinostat works, and can a chemotherapy effectively be combined with entinostat? Answering these questions will pave the way for an evidence-based clinical trial that could save lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: The goal of this K01 proposal is to provide critical training in integrative oncology research methods, implementation science, and medical informatics, and to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a chaplain-delivered meditation program for patients receiving hematopoietic stem cell transplant. The proposed research will accelerate progress toward evidence-based intervention strategies embedded in clinical settings to address depression and pain distress during cancer treatment and to improve long-term quality of life for cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The ability to predict protein-peptide complex structures will have a far-reaching impact on understanding important biological processes and on designing therapeutic interventions. We propose to tackle the challenge of protein- peptide structure prediction, including developing the first in silico peptide screening method to dramatically save cost and time. We will screen for peptide inhibitors by targeting β-lactamase to combat antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical need to develop accurate genetic risk prediction models for non-European populations because most studies to date have focused on individuals of European ancestry. This project will propose novel statistical methods to integrate data from diverse populations for more accurate risk prediction models in the underrepresented populations. Our developed tools, their applications to many diseases, and the associated dissemination platform will facilitate the translation of genome wide association study results into clinically useful disease risk prediction models in these populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Lung cancer screening (LCS) with low-dose computed tomography has significant potential to reduce overall lung cancer mortality and also mitigate long-standing racial/ethnic disparities in lung cancer mortality. However, LCS utilization has been limited, notably among Black individuals. The proposed study aims to provide a solid knowledge base about the multilevel factors that influence racial/ethnic disparities in LCS utilization, which will facilitate developing interventions that ensure the maximal benefits afforded by LCS are achieved and extended equitably in practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative A challenge facing understanding pathogenesis of SCA1, and neurodegenerative diseases in general, is elucidating the relative contribution of each molecular pathway altered has in pathogenesis in the different regions of the brain affected. We will - 1) Perform a molecular characterization of ATXN1[154Q] knockin induced pathogenesis  downstream of nuclear entry in regions/cell types other than cerebellar Purkinje cells. 2) Use a recently developed floxed ATXN1[146Q] mouse model to determine the  regional/tissue contributions to SCA1-ilke phenotypes. 3) Examine the extent to which manipulation of the Cholecystokinin - Cholecystokinin  1 Recptor pathway is a potential therapeutic target for treatment of SCA1, other  SCAs that involve Purkinje neuron degeneration and perhaps neurons in other  SCAs affected brain regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: This Genome Characterization Center (GCC) will use state-of-the-art and novel procedures to discover and characterize somatic variation in 750 of the proposed 2,250 SmaHT tissues samples. The GCC will work closely with the SMaHT network to benchmark methods, develop standards and to harmonize data structures. A period of standardization and calibration will be followed by sustained production. Local analyses will enhance the value of the data and suggest models for the mutagenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CULLIN-RING E3 ubiquitin ligases (CRLs) represent the largest class of ubiquitin ligases and use more than 200 adaptor proteins to specific substrates. However, numerous gaps exist in our understanding of what determines the identity of targets of CRLs. We will employ powerful genetic and biochemical methods to reveal the architecture of the CRL system, including the identification of dozens of E3-target pairs and will elucidate how one subfamily of CRLs controls proteome remodeling during conversion of human ES cells to germ cell lineages

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The treatment of human disease, from viral infections to neurodegenerative conditions such as Alzheimer's disease, relies in large part on the discovery and development of new medicines for therapeutic intervention. This proposal seeks to develop new catalytic reactions to access known pharmacophores, diversify these scaffolds to make new derivatives for testing, and synthesize natural product families that exhibit significant neuroprotective effects to study them in greater detail. These methods will provide an increase in efficiency and generality for the synthesis of established drug molecules and promising new targets.

PHR: As patients with sickle cell disease live to adulthood, they are developing heart and lung disease that leads to  early death. Blood and heart ultrasound tests can identify patients at risk.
