IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of our research is to discover the mechanisms of visual computation in the retina. This proposal studies a novel circuit in two different types of retinal ganglion cells are electrically coupled. Our discovery of heterotypic coupling in retinal ganglion cells, the output cells of the retina, challenges a long-standing principle of functional parallelism, requiring new ideas about early stages of visual computation. This research will have impacts beyond the retina in revealing fundamental principles of neural circuit architecture and mechanism in line with the goals of the BRAIN initiative.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Research into human development requires the use of animal model systems that share many of the same developmental pathways as Homo sapiens. One important model system is Xenopus, the African clawed frog, which has been extensively used in developmental biology, cell biology, genetics, toxicology, and small molecule screens. The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory short course on the Cell & Developmental Biology of Xenopus is an intensive two-week experience that provides up-to-the minute training in conceptual approaches and technologies using Xenopus as a model system. The course enables participants to immediately apply advanced techniques in Xenopus to their own research projects, to network with their research peers, and to learn through hands-on access to the latest available equipment and reagents.

PHR: NARRATIVE As a vascular neurologist and translational scientist, I am committed to advancing cardiovascular health for both men and women. My research has focused on elucidating the fundamental mechanisms responsible for sex and age differences in cell death, inflammatory responses, and neural repair throughout the lifespan. The goal of my program is to translate these findings into novel, targeted therapies for use in patients of both sexes, and the R35 funding mechanism will allow me to pursue innovative research by providing stable funding over the next eight years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To enable safe and efficient advancement of genome editing therapeutics to the human clinical setting, it is essential to obtain preclinical data supporting safety and efficiency, but simple cell cultures and animal models have substantial limitations in predicting outcome in human tissues. Human organoids are 'mini-organ'-like structures grown in lab dishes that possess many key features of tissues, including diverse cell types in sophisticated arrangements specific to different organs, and disease phenotypes specific to individuals from whom they are derived. The objective of these studies is to blueprint a new predictive approach for genome editing efficiency and safety in human organoids, which can be used to de-risk strategies for regulatory consideration relevant to a wide variety of genome editing therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: While precise tuning of gene expression levels is critical for most developmental pathways, the mechanisms by which the transcriptional output of dosage-sensitive molecules is established remain poorly understood. Experiments outlined in this proposal aim to combine the genetic tractability of C. elegans and a novel imaging approach to directly determine how transcriptional dynamics are tuned to generate precise phenotypic outcomes. Specifically, these studies will determine the molecular mechanisms by which two transcription factors, BLMP-1 and LIN-42, modulate aspects of transcriptional bursting to determine the expression levels of key miRNAs that dictate temporal cell fate specification during post-embryonic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The studies proposed herein are designed to investigate how pre-surgical/neoadjuvant immunotherapy may alter the systemic immune response and modify the tumor immune microenvironment in recurrent glioblastoma patients. We will take advantage of our unique access to biological samples, clinical data, and imaging data from an ongoing investigator-initiated clinical trial with Bristol Myers Squibb testing PD-1 (nivolumab) with or without CTLA-4 (ipilimumab) antibody blockade in the neoadjuvant setting and following a planned surgical resection. This project could potentially be transformative, as a better understanding of how neoadjuvant immunotherapy alters immune responses within the tumor could teach us important lessons about the critical requirements for productive anti-tumor responses in glioblastoma and how adaptive resistance occurs in this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This R01 application involves an intervention approach that combines telehealth physical exercise training with telehealth cognitive training to increase neurotrophins and enhance the impact of cognitive training on cognitive deficits in schizophrenia. Both cognitive training and exercise address the NIMH strategic research priorities for creating innovative interventions that can be “disseminated broadly” and “readily taught to the existing workforce with minimal cost”. The future portability of this combined intervention outside of academic research programs will be evaluated by providing the interventions via videoconferencing. Cognitive deficits in persons with schizophrenia present an enormous challenge to successful return to functioning in the community, so this research has potential to be of major public health significance for community functioning of individuals with schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Narrative  Bacteria contain unique wobble uridine modifications and writer enzymes, and these epitranscriptomic systems have been linked to stress responses. In this application we will use chemical biology approaches to synthesize and characterize wobble uridine modifications and define the roles of these RNA modifications and their writers in gene regulation. We will also exploit the bacterial wobble uridine writer MnmH (SelU) by developing clickable ligands that will be used to identify RNA modifications in yeast and human cancer cells. Ultimately our studies will develop a unified understanding of the 12 different wobble uridines in bacterial tRNA and provide new tools for epitranscriptomic research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Developing a kit-based research use only (RUO) translocation assay for deployment as a lab developed test (LDT) toward changing outcomes for patients with driver-negative tumors (RFA sub-section: Technology platform for Cancer Diagnostics) PROJECT NARRATIVE The advent of personalized medicine, whereby a patient is treated based on the genetic aberrations driving their tumor, has transformed cancer by matching patients with targeted therapies tailored to their tumors. Despite this transformation, approximately 50% of advanced stage tumors have no genetic driver that can be detected using existing technologies, precluding access to targeted therapies and worsening their prognosis. Arima Genomics aims to tackle this critical unmet by developing and commercializing the T-Seq kit, which detects clinically actionable genetic drivers in otherwise driver-negative tumors, enabling patients to benefit from the promise of precision medicine and targeted therapies. Based on foundational product development and clinical study data, Arima is now proposing the necessary next steps to become a technology provider to CLIA labs, where CLIA labs will validate the deploy T-Seq kits as LDTs to guide clinical care of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Studying the functional role of various classes of RNAs can lead to better handling of the downstream pathologic events to control the ischemic brain damage. The present project is an effort to study the interaction of noncoding RNAs, epigenetics and epitranscriptomics in modulating secondary brain damage after stroke. The long-term goal is to identify novel targets amenable for therapeutic development to promote recovery after stroke

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The human genome is epigenetically regulated through protein-DNA interactions, histone modifications, and DNA methylation. However, current methods for measuring these regulatory elements, cannot map the epigenetic landscape in the ~8% of the genome that contains highly-repetitive sequences, nor do they have the sensitivity to measure epigenetic variation between single cells. The goal of this research program is to develop new tools for mapping protein-DNA interactions in long single molecules and in single cells, allowing complete profiling of epigenetic regulation in the human genome from telomere to telomere and with enough sensitivity to shed light on cell-to-cell epigenetic variability in developing or diseased tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research aims to examine whether sub-optimal DNA repair activity directed to oxidative DNA damage is involved in lung cancer etiology, and can aid prediction of the development of lung cancer. This is expected to lead to clinically-validated DNA repair-based biomarkers for risk assessment of lung cancer, which will improve risk estimates, and provide better selection criteria for early detection of lung cancer by methods such as low-dose CT. It may also be used for predicting lung cancer risk of individuals with indeterminate pulmonary nodules, aiding clinician’s in the decisiosn making on further diagnostic steps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black emerging adults (ages 18-28 years) have the highest risks of insufficient sleep and obesity, but little is known about how and why these disparities exist. Our project will examine the impacts of insufficient sleep, race- related stress and living in more disadvantaged home and neighborhood environments on weight-related mechanisms and obesity markers in Black emerging adults over a 12-month period. By focusing on emerging adulthood – when many individuals establish and solidify lifelong sleep and health behaviors – this project will take an essential first step toward identifying lifestyle intervention targets rooted within Black cultural strengths and values to mitigate disparities in sleep and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The goal of this project is to investigate how cholinergic and noradrenergic circuits contribute to perceptual decision-making. Decision-making, is critical in environments where performance depends on detecting and responding appropriately to near threshold stimuli. In this project, we will investigate how cholinergic and noradrenergic neuromodulators contribute to immediate and long-term behavioral performance using laminar electrophysiology and fiber photometry with GRAB-Ach and GRAB-NE neurotransmitter reporters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Cellular senescence contributes to age-related tissue and organ dysfunction and various age-related diseases. Senescent cells arise in response to DNA damage, including aneuploidy (i.e. the gain or loss of entire chromosomes) and accumulate with age. Preventing their accumulation delays age-related diseases. This project explores how aneuploid cells may be recognized and eliminated by cell competition using mice as experimental animals. Understanding of this process may help recognize how senescent cells accumulate during aging in tissues and could help develop means to delay the emergence of aging phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This is a collaborative project bringing together several leading muscle research labs with complementary expertise in structural biophysics, physiology, animal models, and medicinal chemistry. Our goal is to develop and apply technology for drug discovery, targeting calcium transport regulation in skeletal muscle, with direct relevance to skeletal myopathies, as well as numerous other disorders for which improved therapies are urgently needed.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - NEW YORK GENOME CHARACTERIZATION CENTER The New York Genome Characterization Center (NYGCC) aims to contribute to the creation of a comprehensive catalog of somatic variation in tissues from healthy individuals by applying three state-of-the-art core sequencing assays: deep, duplex short read whole genome sequencing, RNA sequencing, and deep long read genome sequencing. In addition, we will perform two other assays: single cell amplification-free whole genome sequencing and targeted single cell somatic variant genotyping of transcriptomes together with single cell gene expression. We believe the three core assays will provide an unprecedented and comprehensive view of somatic mutations across a variety of healthy tissues, while the two additional assays will allow us to explore the cellular contexts and effects of the somatic variants in these tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Lower respiratory tract infection (LRTI) affects patients more often in ICUs, especially patients with mechanical ventilators. We propose to determine whether truncated proteoforms in human exhaled air can be used as a noninvasive method for LRTI diagnosis and early prediction of LRTI in mechanically ventilated patients. Our work would largely assist decision-making for clinicians regarding antibiotic treatment and dramatically improve patients' clinical outcomes by limiting antibiotic requirements and minimizing harmful exposure to unnecessary antibiotic treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Our investigation of the crosstalk between ferroptosis and polyunsaturated fatty acid metabolism will lead to a better understanding of the role of polyunsaturated fatty acid metabolites in programmed cell death that will have huge implications on human physiology and may identify novel treatments for many diseases. Specifically, we will combine synthetic metabolites and mimics as powerful chemical probes, state-of-the-art analytical tools, genetic tools, and a novel model organism to delineate how polyunsaturated fatty acid metabolites regulate ferroptosis. Our preliminary data and data from others suggest that specific polyunsaturated fatty acids trigger ferroptosis and inhibition of polyunsaturated fatty acid metabolism rescues ferroptosis triggered by specific polyunsaturated fatty acids illustrating that particular polyunsaturated fatty acids or their metabolites could have a major role in ferroptosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Short sleep duration and sleep-wake irregularity are significantly associated with adolescent depression and are considered key mechanisms of disease; thus, these sleep parameters are critical intervention targets for depressed youth. Efficacious behavioral strategies for disturbed adolescent sleep lead to improved sleep and depression, but little work has aimed to translate evidence-based sleep and rhythm strategies from the research environment for use in pediatric primary care. In this R34 we will involve stakeholders in translating a sleep promotion program (SPP) for implementation in pediatric primary care and in the development of feasible and acceptable provider training, and in evaluating the effectiveness and implementation of the SPP program and provider training via pilot randomized control trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Brain metastasis (BM), frequently arising in patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer and melanoma, is the most common cause of cancer-related deaths in the US, yet our molecular understanding of human BM is rudimentary. Here, we employ several innovations to dissect cellular, molecular and microenvironmental mechanisms that drive metastasis. These will reveal novel vulnerabilities that may be therapeutically targeted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Shorter, well-tolerated, and efficacious rifamycin-free regimens for the treatment of drug-susceptible tuberculosis (TB) are critically needed to attain the World Health Organization targets towards TB elimination. Using a novel artificial-intelligence-enabled parabolic response surface platform, we identified an experimental regimen comprising bedaquiline, clofazimine, pyrazinamide, and delamanid (BCZD), which achieved relapse- free cure in 3 weeks in mouse models. Based on this compelling pre-clinical data, and established safety profile of constituent drugs, we propose a Phase IIc, open-label, randomized controlled trial to investigate the efficacy and safety of an 8-week regimen of BCZD compared to standard therapy for drug-sensitive TB, paving the way for a definitive treatment-shortening trial and potentially shifting clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative  As a worldwide healthcare burden, alcohol consumption ranks as the 7th leading risk factor of death, accounting for 6.8% and 2.2% of deaths in men and women, which resulted in 3 million deaths in 2016 as estimated by WHO and cost 249 billion dollars in United States in 2010. Alcohol, as a leading cause of liver disease, is associated with a wide spectrum of hepatic diseases, such as alcohol-associated steatosis, steatohepatitis, fibrosis, cirrhosis, alcoholic hepatitis, and triggers weakening of the immune system escalating the susceptibility of bacterial and viral infections. Understanding the intestinal immune system to regulate systemic inflammation and infection is critical to design preventive and interventional therapies to counteract alcohol-associated liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Air pollution remains a ubiquitous exposure worldwide and is an important potential risk for coronary heart disease, the leading cause of death worldwide, through which atherosclerosis is the most common pathway. The precise consequences of exposure to air pollution on coronary heart disease remain uncertain, the responsible air pollutants, and the mechanisms underlying the effects are largely unknown: long-term exposure to outdoor and indoor air pollutants may make susceptible patients with atherosclerosis more likely to develop and promote coronary atherosclerosis with thickening and calcification and cause rupture and thrombosis of vulnerable plaques, leading to coronary events. This project holds the promise to generate new knowledge about modifiable environmental factors that may contribute new approaches to developing effective prevention modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to improve the delivery of agents (anti-sense oligonucleotides), which are capable to silencing neurogenerative disease-specific genes, to neurons without the need for invasive methods of administration. This research will involve conjugating anti-sense oligonucleotides to antibodies that penetrate the intact blood-brain barrier, target cell-surface neuronal proteins, and release their conjugated agents after antibody cellular internalization. Successful completion of this research would accelerate the development of therapeutics for treating diverse neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Epilepsy affects up to 1% of the population, causing disruptions in quality of life and even mortality due to sudden death. In pediatric epilepsy especially, changes in a single gene of an ion channel are recognized as a major contributor to infantile-onset seizures that can be very difficult to control with medications. This proposal will provide new insight into the way single gene changes lead to recurrent seizures by examining single neurons and animal models, allowing for new approaches to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Blood flow is reduced in small brain blood vessels in patients and mouse models of Alzheimer’s disease, in part due to capillary obstruction that disrupts blood flow dynamics. We discovered that blood flow dynamics are normally sensed by force sensors such as Piezo1, but it is unknown whether these sensors are impaired during Alzheimer's disease. Here, we will use advanced imaging and electrophysiological techniques to study whether Piezo1 function changes during Alzheimer’s Disease and whether restoring its function reduces capillary obstructions and improves blood flow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (2-3 sentences) This proposal will test a hypothesis that communication between immune cell populations and pancreatic islets (the producers of insulin) is mediated by extracellular vesicles (EVs). EVs are known to mediate signals between cells and tissue in several diseases, however their role in type 1 diabetes (T1D) is still largely unknown. Here, we will examine the role of EVs from islet-infiltrating T cells and islets and evaluate their role in the T1D pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE: (max 3 sentences) Individual cells of the human body continuously experience DNA damage and accumulate somatic mutations throughout life, and specific mutations may alter the phenotype of a cell through diverse mechanisms. Characterization of somatic mutations across diverse tissues from many individuals will immensely enhance our ability to understand the impact of somatic mutations and discover novel aspects of human biology. As a Genome Characterization Center (GCC) for the SMaHT program, we will contribute to the characterization, and creation of a resource catalog of somatic variation across human tissues at scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Mood and anxiety disorders are highly prevalent, debilitating psychopathologies that commonly emerge in young adulthood, which in turn is a developmental period characterized by increased exposure to stressors related to the transition to independence. The proposed study takes a longitudinal, mechanistic approach to understand how distinct profiles of cognitive functioning (related to executive functioning and responsiveness to reward or threat) interact to confer general or specific vulnerability for internalizing symptoms (anhedonia, anxious arousal, and mania). By testing new interdisciplinary tools for predicting future psychiatric health, this research aims to provide information that may be translated to inform the delivery of preventive interventions to young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Emerging evidence from recent genome-wide studies has revealed that promoters across eukaryotes are commonly paired to drive bidirectional transcription. Work in yeast suggests bidirectional transcription could be the naïve or innate state of transcription initiation with directionality evolving due to the action of diverse pathways. Building on our initial success in developing a highly efficient in vitro reconstitution system of transcription initiation from highly purified yeast factors, we set out to further develop this system to solve the mechanism of divergent transcription through structural and biochemical dissection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public Health Relevance Excessive alcohol use is a leading preventable cause of death and disability, with an average of 95,158 alcohol- attributable deaths in the United States each year. Despite the high demands for a wearable sensor that can continuously monitor alcohol consumption in real-time, current devices lack the desired workability. In this SBIR Fast-Track application, we propose further development of ActioX, LLC biosensor system, a discreet, non- obtrusive, and calibration-free wearable integrated device capable of continuously measuring alcohol consumption in real-time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Current antiretroviral therapies dramatically reduced mortality in persons living with HIV (PWH), yet immune activation, inflammation and hypercoagulability persist in this population and are responsible for comorbidities, such as cardiovascular disease. Here we propose that excessive NETosis, a neutrophil dysfunction is a key determinant of persistent inflammation and of the hypercoagulation status in SIV/HIV infected individuals. We will directly target the neutrophil dysfunction through administration of an inhibitor of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs). This project will improve our understanding of SIV/HIV pathogenesis, response to treatment and the mechanisms of SIV/HIV-related comorbidities, and thus may have a major impact on the clinical management and survival of the PWH. Our study may validate a drug that can be used to inhibit excessive NETosis. This approach could benefit multiple diseases, including infections with pandemic potential, such as COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precision genomic medicine depends on a complete understanding of genetic variation in normal individuals, but current approaches fail to capture all the types of genetic variation, because they 1) do not measure genetic variation in so-called “unmappable” regions of the genome, and 2) assume the genomes of every cell in a single multicellular human are identical. The goal of our proposal “Mosaicism in Human Tissues, from Telomere to Telomere” is to characterize multiple types of human somatic variation across the entire human genome in a set of 10 tissues from 50 donors, and to work with other members of the network towards producing a framework for understanding somatic variation in post-mortem, non-pathological human tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The overall goal of this proposal is to develop a mechanistic, transcriptome-wide understanding of translation regulation during osmoadaptation. We will generate the first predictive “code” for translation regulation with multiple parameters for any stress response. Our predicted models will provide molecular targets and biomarkers for therapeutics for diseases involving loss of osmotolerance such as dry eye syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The BRAIN initiative has enabled the development of approaches for modulating specific microcircuits through genetically targeting discrete types of neurons; however, their application to disease models is lagging. In this collaboration between Huntington’s disease (HD) researchers and BRAIN tool developers we will utilize novel interventional tools for changing neural circuit dynamics at the early, pre-symptomatic stage for preventing or delaying and mitigating the behavioral deficits in a transgenic mouse model of HD. Our project will drive translational progress toward potential novel therapeutic purposes for HD as well as other neurodegenerative diseases that show circuit imbalances, while at the same time addressing basic questions of neural circuit function underlying behavior relevant to both NINDS and NIMH.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative While the immune system is the body’s first line of defense against cancer, tumor cells are known to develop mechanisms to alter the immune system’s response to support their growth and progression. In this proposal, I will establish animal models to 1) understand how tumors can exploit the immune response and 2) establish therapeutic strategies to reverse this process by focusing on the interaction between immune cells and tumor cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE To date, the use of HIV molecular surveillance has not been linked to a reduction in HIV incidence. The proposed project will perform secondary analyses of coded and de-identified public health HIV surveillance data from the Los Angeles County (LAC) Health Department. The study team will engage key stakeholder populations and use regional estimates of HIV transmission and HIV program data to project the impact of alternative strategies for the optimal allocation of resources to LAC HIV prevention programs relevant to EHE targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current studies in the non-human primate model led to surprising, important findings such as the possible dependence of the reservoir on myeloid cell infection and to the development of groundbreaking technologies for the investigation of the tissue reservoir. By leveraging these new insights and technologies, we will investigate the dynamics of the HIV reservoir with unprecedented, unbiased resolution, including dissecting the role of little known, tissue resident cell targets of HIV infection of myeloid origins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The work from the proposal will identify disparities across sex in cardiovascular disease, build a novel sex- specific model for optimal revascularization strategy, and understand patient experiences on coronary artery disease treatment, among dialysis patients. With cardiovascular disease being the leading cause of death in dialysis patients and inadequate recruitment of women with end-stage kidney disease in the clinical trials, understanding the impact of sex on cardiovascular disease-related health status in dialysis patients becomes highly significant. The net effect will hopefully be an improvement in the quality of life, reduction in sex disparities in cardiovascular disease, and an overall increase in survival, among dialysis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Offspring of depressed mothers are three-to-six times more likely to meet criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD) by early adulthood than are individuals in the general population; however, not all high risk (HR) youth develop MDD, suggesting factors that may exacerbate risk profiles. The current project combines measures of brain function, psychophysiology, and behavior across three time points during a developmental window of heightened MDD risk to study how deficits in negative emotion processing are implicated in both the development and course of depression among HR offspring. By exploring how biological sex and puberty interact with negative emotion processing styles to predict depression profiles in HR youth, findings from the current study have significant potential to inform novel prevention and intervention targets for specific populations of at-risk youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV (PLWH) commonly report chronic pain and are more likely to receive prescription opioids, placing them at elevated risk for adverse events. However, data are limited for a growing population of older PLWH 65+ years with multiple comorbidities, increasing polypharmacy, and increased risk for untoward drug- drug interactions. Using large-scale administrative claims data and machine learning approaches, this project will analyze prescription opioid use, risks, and outcomes in older PLWH, generating valuable new information and tools to support clinical decisions and more precisely target prevention and treatment interventions to improve health for older PLWH who use opioids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The Spencer S. Eccles Health Sciences Library at the University of Utah, will implement a 5-year grant to bring quality health, public health, and biomedical information resources within easy reach of the public and all health and public health professionals, with emphasis on medically underserved communities. We will address this charge by improving access to quality health information in Region 4 (Arizona, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, New Mexico, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah, and Wyoming) while collaborating with other Network of the National Library of Medicine Regional Medical Libraries, Offices, and Centers nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV post-treatment controllers (PTCs) are individuals who can maintain virologic suppression after interruption of antiretroviral therapy and represent a natural model of sustained HIV remission. However, our understanding of the virologic determinants of HIV remission remains incomplete, which is in part due to the scarcity of PTCs identified through any one research center or clinical trial, and in part because of the limited scope of viral reservoir studies that have been performed to date. The main goal of this proposal is to perform an in-depth virologic analysis of PTCs and our overarching hypotheses are that HIV reservoir characteristics can provide mechanistic insights behind their ability to achieve HIV remission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The optimal host response to mucosal infection relies on the critical balance between pathogen killing (immunity) and limiting immunopathology (tolerance) in the host. Host disease tolerance is especially important in infections with macroparasites such as helminths that cause significant tissue damage, therefore investigating these host disease tolerance mechanisms may be applicable to the treatment of tissue injury and inflammation of significant public health impact. This proposal will investigate how the secreted protein RELMa contributes to host disease tolerance to helminths through regulation of alternatively activated macrophage subsets, macrophage-helminth interactions and macrophage-lung stromal cell interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative During cell division, the cell must accurately segregate its chromosomes to its two daughter cells and any errors in this process can lead to birth defects and diseases such as cancer. The kinetochore is essential to ensuring that force is transmitted from spindle microtubules to move chromosomes, and here we ask how the kinetochore can do so under high forces without structural failure. This work will provide insight into the structural engineering principles underlying the kinetochore’s robust structure and function, and in the long run inform on possible failures linked to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this supplement application we will train a postbac student, Nathan Ho, on single molecule and biochemical approaches investigating how mammalian histone methylases (‘writers”) engage with the chromatin substrate. In the formation of repressive chromatin structures, these “writers” deposit repressive information and we aim to understand how their own reaction product, their oligomeric state, or the density of chromatin, influence “writer” association with chromatin. In the time Nathan is in the lab, we will address all the training goals he has articulated via his myIDP with structured and continuous mentoring, in-lab training, and opportunities to refine communication of science and incorporating relevant literature into his research.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: NARRATIVE Although multiple sclerosis (MS) has a significant impact on physical functioning and is a major cause of non- traumatic disability in younger adults in the U.S., traditional endpoint measures in clinical trials focus on mobility and overlook impacts on upper extremity and other aspects of physical function that are important to people with MS; therefore, it is important that MS clinical trials measure the full range of physical function and the impact of new MS treatments on physical function. The overall objective of this project is to prepare and submit a Full Qualification Package to support the qualification of the PROMISnq Short Form v2.0 - Physical Function - Multiple Sclerosis 15a for use as a patient-reported measure of physical function among individuals diagnosed with all forms of MS. The impact of this work will be the advancement of a publicly available, psychometrically sound measure of physical function that can be used in MS treatment trials to better assess and understand the impact of new treatments on physical function in individuals with MS.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development of a Full Qualification Package (FQP) for the PROMISnq Short Form v2.0 - Physical Function - Multiple Sclerosis 15a (DDT COA #000123)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study gene expression changes elicited by brain stimulation using tissue obtained from neurosurgical patients. First, we will compare gene expression profiles between stimulation and non-stimulated tissue from the lateral temporal cortex in vivo. Second, using neural tissue cultures of human cortex, we will examine gene expression changes elicited by ex vivo stimulation over six days, and connect stimulation-related changes in neural connectivity with gene expression data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE OF HEALTH ST
PHR: Relevance to Public Health The proposed project strengthens surveillance of respiratory illness and influenza by building-on existing infrastructure, Regional partnerships and networks, and research projects. The public health significance of this project is to understand the impact of influenza and other respiratory virus on the psychomotor, cognitive, and behavioral development of small children in a large cohort. Outbreak investigation will be deployed if necessary. The in-depth understanding of respiratory illness and influenza in pediatrics population offer tremendous public health implications with repercussions at international levels. The proposed project will help generate surveillance and research protocols and public policies. This information will be most useful for future research and to determine the impact of respiratory illness during pregnancy on the development of the offspring. We anticipate that frequent and severe cases of influenza and other respiratory viral infections, during pregnancy and early life affect neurocognitive, psychomotor, and behavioral development in infants, this will assist clinicians and researchers in the following manner:  a. Prevention of influenza would be more proactive.  b. The innovative study will provide results that can be used and replicated globally.  c. Influenza vaccination during pregnancy will be promoted more actively. Another important contribution of the study is the analysis of demographic, social, and cultural factors that impact the onset of respiratory illnesses during pregnancy. As well as the use of the Bayley's III Test to evaluate the impact of cognitive, psychomotor, and language development. And, finally the innovative inclusion of behavioral analysis in the participants' follow-up will contribute immensely to universal knowledge and applied to public health policies and interventions. The study will provide enormous contributions to public health. The results will generate the tools and necessary information to promote influenza vaccination among pregnant women. This is a segment of the population, where vaccination was been low in many countries. If the results of the study prove positive to prevent influenza and furthermore the impact in their offspring development, this will generate compelling information to promote and educate the population at large and health care providers on the importance of vaccination against influenza and prevention of respiratory illness during pregnancy.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-20-001 Psychomotor and cognitive development problems in a cohort of children after respiratory infection during pregnancy and/or early childhood

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: To date there are no effective therapeutic treatments for preventing age-related loss of muscle mass and function, or to enhance recovery of muscle following atrophy and injury. The studies outlined in this proposal will test the effectiveness of dietary supplementation with fish oil to prevent the loss of muscle mass and function with age and enhance the recovery of muscle mass and function following disuse-induced atrophy in a rat model that has high translatability. This research is relevant to the Veteran’s Administration since a significant number of patients in the system will require rehabilitation to recover skeletal muscle mass following atrophy induced by bed rest, immobilization, or neural trauma. The aging population represents a growing medical and monetary concern for the VA, since the elderly will suffer greater consequences of atrophy due to poor recovery. The development of effective therapies for the enhancement of muscle recovery following atrophy in the elderly is an unmet clinical need, and is the long-term goal of our research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The BRCA1-BARD1 protein complex acts to eliminate highly toxic DNA double-strand breaks, to ensure the faithful propagation of our genetic blueprint, and to suppress cancer development. However, there is little information regarding the intricate roles fulfilled by BRCA1-BARD1 in these processes, or how loss of specific BRCA1-BARD1 functions leads to tumorigenesis. Elucidating the DNA and RAD51 interaction interfaces of BRCA1-BARD1 and their function in DNA damage repair and DNA replication fork preservation will help illuminate the functional consequence of cancer mutations in BRCA1-BARD1 and lay the foundation for developing therapeutic strategies to target tumors deficient in DNA repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ploidy altering mechanisms such as cell-cell fusion and whole genome doubling (WGD) can drive intratumoral heterogeneity and may play a prominent role in chemotherapeutic response. We will use expressed DNA barcodes to longitudinally dissect the rates and roles of pre-existing aneuploidy and therapy-induced ploidy alteration at single cell resolution and multi-scale data will be used to parameterize and validate a predictive model of therapeutic response. In systematically investigating mechanisms of ploidy alteration at a single cell resolution, we may reveal therapeutically targetable drivers of genome instability with radical implications for the treatment and prognosis of TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mammalian SWI/SNF complexes are multi-subunit protein assemblies that play critical roles in establishing and maintaining DNA accessibility and gene expression. I aim to define the role of a newly-described, mammalian-specific subunit, BCL7, in SWI/SNF complex function in the human cell context with respect to a) SWI/SNF complex biochemical integrity; and b) SWI/SNF genome-wide chromatin targeting and DNA accessibility generation in B cell lymphomas and normal primary B cells. This research will elucidate new mechanisms of mSWI/SNF activity and its role in the regulation of gene expression in normal and disease states.

PHR: Project Narrative: Research on CD and CU traits has increased greatly in recent years, yet, the mechanisms underlying CU traits in this high-risk population remain poorly understood. Our research strategy integrates cutting edge virtual reality fear induction technology while measuring multiple physiological indices in youth with CD to differentiate boys and girls with varying levels of CU traits. The outcomes from this research will provide a more accurate physiological fear profile for youth with CU traits, which will lead to improvements in gender-responsive intervention strategies, with the ultimate aim of early detection and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop patient-personalized cochlear implant stimulation models that could provide useful programming-assistance to clinicians and lead to better device settings. Thus, the methods developed in this project could potentially be used to improve hearing outcomes for new and existing cochlear implant recipients and improve the efficiency of the clinical programming process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research reduces modifiable risk factors to prevent colorectal cancer among American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) older adults, who experience pronounced cancer health disparities (CHDs). Results contribute to a growing field of implementation science to address CHDs and follows landmark efforts to align with ethical, strengths-based practices for public health research with AIAN communities. At completion of the proposed aims, the trainee will transition into early-career investigator stage equipped with the expertise, experience, and networks to successfully launch an independent research career focusing on behavioral interventions to reduce CHDs among diverse, geriatric populations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Children who are born preterm are at a high risk of development sensorimotor deficits, including developmental coordination disorder (DCD), one of the most common yet least studied developmental motor disorder. This study aims to investigate the predictive relationship between somatosensory processing deficits during early childhood in preterm children, and later motor development. Better understanding of the relationship between somatosensory deficits and motor development will allow us to identify children who experience these difficulties before they show significant motor delays and to develop tailored interventions for them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human papilloma virus (HPV) infection accounts for nearly all cervical and anal squamous cell carcinomas, a subset of other anogenital squamous carcinomas, and increasing rates of head and neck squamous cell carcinomas – all with relatively heterogenous clinical outcomes due to a lack of personalized care. Here, I propose a pan-cancer genomic analysis using extensive patient cohorts and targeted sequencing techniques to investigate the heterogeneity surrounding HPV-associated cervical, oral, and anogenital cancers as an ideal project to train as a future physician-scientist with an exceptional sponsor and complementary teams to support my research and clinical training. Through completion of this project, I will demonstrate that patients can be stratified in the clinic beyond anatomy and cytopathology, accommodate treatments to individuals, and work to improve patient outcomes through personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Aneuploidy is a cellular state in which cells contain extra or missing chromosomes. 90% of solid tumors are aneuploid, and aneuploidy has been shown to contribute to drug resistance, metastasis, and worse patient outcomes. The goal of this project is to use CRISPR screening to uncover aneuploidy-specific genetic dependencies that will serve as promising targets for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Cancer is a leading cause of mortality and morbidity in the world. Among emerging immunotherapy technologies, vaccination strategies that both generate new antigen-specific T cell responses against tumor cells and amplify existing responses are particularly promising. We have now discovered just such a method called CART-RNA and through a unique collaboration between chemists, cancer immunologists, and biostatisticians we propose to advance this method and demonstrate its efficacy in the therapy of cancer in preclinical models with the clear goal of eventual application in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy and chronic alcohol drinking is a major medical and public health problem that is frequently diagnosed as alcohol use disorder (AUD). Existing FDA approved treatment options for AUD have limited efficacy and adverse effects; thus, alcohol associated organ injury especially liver injury is a commonly observed comorbidity. This project may lead to the use of Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG (LGG) as a novel effective therapy for AUD and concomitant moderate alcohol associated hepatitis (AH).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Worsening population-level trends in cardiometabolic health highlight the profound need to move away from traditional disease models focused on the remediation of downstream cardiometabolic risk factors to instead focus on relevant upstream exposures. A robust literature shows early life adversity exposures predict a host of cardiometabolic health outcomes, yet few studies have tested interventions designed to act on upstream adversity exposures to prevent cardiometabolic disease. The proposed study represents a unique and time sensitive opportunity to leverage an existing RCT in which a parenting intervention was implemented in a sample of low income, and postnatal women to determine whether benefits of the parenting intervention, originally designed to impact parent-child behavioral and relationship outcomes in infancy, may extend to the child’s cardiometabolic health in early childhood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer shows remarkable resistance to T cell immunotherapy. This proposal will use mouse models of pancreatic cancer to study the role of toll-like receptor 2 in regulating T cell surveillance in cancer. Findings will improve our understanding of mechanisms that regulate the anti-tumor potential of T cells and may reveal novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The vast majority of new cancer drugs fail to significantly help the patients who try them. We believe that this is in part because the targets of these drugs have not been determined correctly. We will use a set of genetic techniques to discover the real targets of several different cancer drugs, which may help clinicians identify which patients would be most likely to benefit from receiving them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study, focused on infants at elevated risk for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and attention- deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), will identify early markers of self-regulation and social communication symptoms across early development with a focus on attention regulation, emotion regulation, and psychophysiological indicators. It will also enhance our understanding of relationships between self-regulation and social communication problems over time. The goal is that this research will improve early identification of disorders like ADHD and ASD, and encourage the development of process-focused interventions that can be applied across a range of infants and toddlers at risk.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Up to 5.3 million people in the U.S. live with long-term disabilities after traumatic brain injury (TBI), and patients with moderate and severe TBI have the highest acute, subacute, and long-term need for resources. Untrained friends and family members often assume caregiving responsibilities; however, few are prepared to do so, and caregivers subsequently experience problems with depression, health, and poor life changes as a result of caregiving. The goal of this study is to determine if early involvement of the caregiver acutely after adult TBI with a novel online intervention, CG-Well, is feasible, acceptable, and associated with improved caregiver wellbeing compared to a control group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary fibrosis is thought to be driven by epithelial injury and self-sustaining pathological feedback loops. However, there is abundant evidence that the lung can resolve fibrosis during successful tissue repair, though the cellular mechanisms and molecular mediators are not well understood. This project will study whether epithelial dopamine synthesis is an essential trigger of fibrosis resolution, and whether dopaminergic signaling can be harnessed in experimental lung fibrosis and human fibrotic lung tissue to promote lung repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The five year survival rate of ovarian cancer patients has remained at 47% for decades, highlighting the urgent need for therapeutic strategies that activate potent anti-tumor immune responses. One such strategy is epigenetic therapy, which stimulates an immunogenic response in cancer cells by inducing the transcription of repetitive elements (REs)—genomic regions that are normally silent. The goal of this project is to investigate REs as an inducible source of tumor-associated antigens that can be directly targeted by RE-specific T cells in combination with epigenetic therapy, resulting in an increased anti-tumor immune response and potentially curative immune therapy for ovarian cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The pathogen Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M.tb) causes pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) in millions of humans each year, and the global disease burden has stagnated because we have a small vaccine pipeline. Here, we develop, test, and optimize novel prime/boost heterologous protein/RNA vaccines against TB in advanced preclinical animal models. The vaccines we identify will provide candidates for clinical trials by better predicting efficacy across genetically diverse experimental animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH  The goal of this project is to develop and evaluate next generation MRI technologies on an FDA approved ultrahigh field (UHF) MRI system (Siemens 7T Terra) that allow in vivo quantitative imaging of microvascular blood flow across the cortical layers and columns in a live human brain. This new technology will greatly improve our capabilities for understanding brain function at the level of circuits and their aberrations in brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Although the unique regenerative potential of the oral mucosa has long been recognized and appreciated, the mechanisms that facilitate rapid wound closure, limited inflammatory response and the non-scarring phenotype of the oral cavity are unknown. This proposal will build off our lab’s preliminary characterization of the oral epithelial progenitor cell (OEPC) population to dissect how low and high inflammatory conditions can alter OEPC response to injury and the ability of the oral mucosa to heal. This work acts as a necessary first step in understanding the superior regenerative capacity of the oral mucosa and the regulatory ability of inflammation, which will aid in our understanding of chronic inflammatory diseases in the oral cavity and facilitate the development of therapies that harness the innate mechanisms of the oral mucosa to improve or stimulate wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Acute myeloid leukemia (AML), one of the most common and fatal forms of hematopoietic malignancies, is a stem cell disease caused by gene mutations and genomic rearrangements. Here, we will investigate the novel role of YTHDC1 in the development and maintenance of AML and elucidate the mechanisms underlying the role of YTHDC1. This study will advance our knowledge and understanding of molecular basis of AML, potentially leading to the identification of a new effective treatment for AML patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emotion dysregulation is a transdiagnostic risk factor for psychopathology, and as such, the elucidation of specific longitudinal pathways by which children develop emotion regulation or dysregulation is critical. This research will (1) determine which aspects of maternal emotion regulation are most relevant for maternal emotion-related socialization behaviors over time, and (2) evaluate the influence of maternal emotion regulation on child emotion regulation over time, and the extent to which maternal emotion-related socialization behaviors mediate that association. Accordingly, this research will inform public health efforts to improve children’s emotion regulation and psychological functioning by identifying processes (i.e., maternal emotion regulation, emotion-related socialization behaviors) that may be targets for translational programs aimed to improve children’s ER and reduce risk for psychopathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Bronchopulmunary Dysplasia (BPD) is a disease of pre-term infants whose lungs are injured upon exposure to excess oxygen from ventilators, impairing effective gas exchange in the lungs. Ayuvis Research is developing a novel class of immunomodulating compounds derived from chitin that decrease inflammation, improve lung vascularization, decrease pulmonary hypertension and altogether prevent the depelopment of BPD in preclinical large animal model. Our objective in this proposed grant application is to test the safety and pharmacokinetic profile of our lead compound in a Phase I SAD/MAD Clinical Trial in healty human volunteers, which is a key stage in the development of our much needed prophylactic treatment for BPD in infants and treatment for other life-threatening lung conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epilepsy is a chronic, debilitating neurological condition that affects 50 million people worldwide. Although it often runs in families, the genetic causes of familial epilepsy are not well understood. This research will help us understand the genetic causes of familial epilepsy, identify biological mechanisms that could be potential treatment targets, and develop new tools that use genetic information to improve the diagnosis and treatment of people with epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a common cardiac disorder that in some people can lead to substantial limitations in acts of daily living, poor prognosis, and mortality. Gold standard therapy for patients who do not respond to medical management are invasive septal reduction surgeries that have a high rate of serious side-effects and mortality. This proposal will validate a new minimally invasive method to precisely treat the source of the obstruction in a procedure that we believe will be safer and better suited for many patients than the currently available treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The year after birth, also known as the “fourth trimester”, is a growing focus of efforts to address high rates of maternal morbidity and mortality in the United States, which disproportionally affect racial-ethnic minorities, rural women and Medicaid beneficiaries. Yet, high-quality evidence on postpartum health and wellbeing and the drivers of postpartum health disparities is severely lacking. This project will address this important gap by collecting and analyzing rich multi-state survey data on the health and social needs of postpartum women in the year after birth, producing data of high scientific value with the aim to identify mechanisms that could be targeted to reduce postpartum health disparities.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of the proposed training program is to increase research into the detection, prevention and treatment of drug-resistant infections in West Africa, and expand knowledge and skills in clinical microbiology. The program involves providing a rigorous PhD student training, and offering tailored training to junior scientists and faculty from West Africa, in antimicrobial resistance. The major outcome will be a significant increase in antimicrobial resistance research capacity in the West African sub-region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: NARRATIVE: This Conte Center investigates the slow brain network fluctuations that control the ebb and flow of cognition and related behavioral performance on a moment-by-moment basis. Understanding these slow fluctuations and their underpinnings has broad scientific and public health significance, as they provide critical scaffolding for most, if not all other brain operations. This Center’s discoveries will contribute to the integrated mechanistic understanding of how neural activity and autonomic influences combine in the organization of behavior and cognition and to improved treatment of neural, autonomic and behavioral-cognitive deficits in people with neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The use of radioembolization has been shown to be successful for the treatment and downstaging of hepatocellular carcinoma as well as liver metastases, with response rates of 25-60%. Localized microbubble cavitation triggered by noninvasive ultrasound has been shown to sensitize malignant tissue to radiotherapy by inducing vascular endothelial-cell apoptosis. We propose a first-in-humans randomized clinical trial to determine the benefits of using localized microbubble cavitation to improve patient outcomes and predict treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypoxia induces glycolysis enzymes to coalesce into RNP condensates, termed Glycolytic bodies (G bodies), whose formation correlates with increases of glucose flux and cell proliferation in yeast. Using a wide array approaches, we will test the function, structure, and regulation of G body formation in yeast and mammalian systems. This work will reveal mechanisms of condensate function and principles of cell adaptation to hypoxia, providing insights into how cancer cells proliferate in hypoxic tumor microenvironments.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Every year approximately 15,000 Veterans are hospitalized for stroke, and up to 40% of those Veterans will experience stroke-related language impairment (i.e., aphasia). Stroke-induced aphasia results in increased healthcare costs and decreased quality of life. As our population of Veterans continues to age, there will be an increasing number for Veterans living with the aphasia and its consequences. Those Veterans deserve to receive aphasia treatment designed to facilitate the best possible outcomes. In the proposed study, we will investigate optimal treatment intensity and predictors of treatment response for a novel word retrieval treatment. The knowledge we gain will have direct implications for the selecting the right treatment approach for the right Veteran.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Adapting behavior to learn, or to make correct decisions, is necessary for the survival as an individual or species as well as for ongoing maintenance of bodily and mental health. Our research is dedicated to identify fundamental functions of cortico-striato-dopaminergic circuits in adapting behavior during reinforcement learning and cost- benefit deliberations, especially when the learning efficacy or evaluation bias is tuned by instantaneous motivational state. We hope, and expect, that the findings of our research will contribute to the efforts in the field to alleviate sufferings of people, due to the maladaptive mood, motivation and cognition, as manifested in a variety of neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The ECOG-ACRIN Central Biorepository and Pathology Facility (EA CBPF) will receive process, store and distribute high quality, well-annotated tissue specimens as well as blood and other biological fluids from patients participating in NCTN and NCORP clinical trials and assist NIH/NCI-supported specimen banking organizations. The specimens will encompass tumor and non-malignant tissue and cytology specimens, peripheral blood, bone marrow, and other fluid samples, from multiple tumor sites (e.g., tumors of the brain, breast, gastrointestinal tract, genitourinary tract, gynecologic/reproductive system, head and neck, skin, liver, lung, soft tissue, thyroid gland and other cancers) and hematologic malignancies (leukemia, lymphoma, and multiple myeloma and related diseases).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Glycans play crucial roles in a wide range of biological functions, including critical roles as human milk oligosaccharides (HMOs) that protect from infection, maintain proper microbiota, and aid in infant development. The synthesis of complex HMOs is presently too costly for their widespread use. This project aims to develop an inexpensive, modular, and flexible synthesis strategy for enzymatic glycan assembly from simple building blocks as a proof-of-concept for scalable HMO synthesis that will expand their use as human therapeutics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: This study will examine the impact of a new clinical decision support tool for rehabilitation after total knee arthroplasty (TKA). Typically, TKA rehabilitation is generic with most patients receiving the same dosage and contents of rehabilitation despite notable diversity among patients who undergo TKA. Our clinical support decision tool is designed to help physical therapists tailor rehabilitation treatments and dosages to the individual needs, goals, and preferences of Veterans recovering from TKA. This study has the potential to improve Veterans’ functional recovery after TKA, while simultaneously reducing the average number of physical therapy visits Veterans attend after surgery by tailoring rehabilitation dosage based upon need. This will ensure the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) has the resources and capacity to provide adequate rehabilitation to every Veteran seeking TKA in the VHA system. Additionally, if successful, this clinical decision support tool could be used to improve outcomes and access for additional patient populations in the future.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic pain has a highly negative impact on Veterans, especially those with serious mental illness (SMI). Chronic pain leads to poorer mental health and physical functioning, and represents a critical obstacle to rehabilitation and recovery. Despite known high prevalence rates of chronic pain in SMI populations, there is little research to: a) evaluate nonpharmacological pain management strategies in this population, and b) examine directional relations between chronic pain and SMI symptoms. This study aims to address research and clinical gaps by: a) testing the feasibility and acceptability of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Chronic Pain (CBT-CP) - a VA evidence-based psychotherapy for chronic pain in Veterans with SMI, and b) better assessing the complex relation between chronic pain and psychiatric symptoms and their impact on functioning. Results from this study will inform us as to whether CBT-CP is feasible to implement, acceptable to Veterans with SMI, and worth examining in its standard or in an optimized form in a larger clinical trial.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Damage to primary visual cortex and adjacent regions (area V1+) after stroke typically results in dense contralateral loss of vision, which can have devastating consequences for one’s quality of life. This is a common problem in the VA population. There are currently no effective methods to restore vision in subjects with dense visual field scotomas as a result of V1 lesions. The chief aims of our proposal are: 1) To use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) population receptive field analysis methods to identify regions of the visual field that have high potential for rehabilitation after lesions of the primary visual cortex. 2) To study how the strength of visual modulation in spared visual areas changes with rehabilitative training, and whether observed changes correlate with recovery. This will be a first step towards our long-term goal, which is to develop a rational, fMRI based, approach to visual rehabilitation following cortical lesions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Access to a flexible spectrum of family-based VA mental health care for Veterans is mandated by law. Research shows that relationship distress harms Veterans’ mental health, physical health, and mortality, while healthy relationships provide resilience and facilitate recovery from illness. However, there are many barriers to accessing couple and family care within VA, including system-level barriers such as insufficient access to specialty providers and couple-level barriers such as difficulty coordinating schedules and finding childcare. OurRelationship is an evidence-based, coached online intervention for couples that provides flexible, accessible, and scalable treatment to improve relationship functioning. This proposed CDA-2 project will test whether OurRelationship is effective for improving Veterans’ intimate relationships and supporting their rehabilitation. This study supports the mission of the 2018-2024 Strategic Plan of the Department of Veterans Affairs by improving Veterans’ relationship functioning to enhance their overall quality of life.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal investigates the role of RAS-ERK signaling in regulating the function of RbAp46 and RbAp48 proteins during meiosis I and oocyte maturation respectively. Meiosis I and oocyte meiotic maturation are fundamental and conserved processes across metazoans, the knowledge gained from this research has implications to understanding both infertility and birth defects. The role of RbAp46 and RbAp48 in regulating female germ cell development, their intersection with and regulation by the ERK signaling pathway and a role for RbAp46 independent of gene expression have never been defined before and understanding these form the basis of this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Adipose tissue has a complex relationship with its intrinsic lymphatic vasculature-- it is known that defective lymphatic function promotes obesity and, conversely, obesity compromises lymphatic flow; the mechanisms for these effects are unknown. We have identified a small peptide hormone, neurotensin (NTS), that is produced by lymphatic endothelial cells and which acts on adipocytes to repress thermogenesis. Here we propose to determine how NTS production is regulated, how it affects adipocyte biology, and what impact it has on metabolic health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Suicide prevention is the top clinical priority for VA/DoD and despite VA/DoD recommendations to include family members in suicide related care, there is currently no couples-based suicide-specific intervention. Suicide theories and rehabilitation psychology highlight the importance of healthy interpersonal connection, and research has found that suicidality and relationship functioning are intimately tied. Including a relationship partner in suicide related care has the potential to enhance treatment outcomes and save Veteran lives. This CDA-2 proposal will refine and pilot the first couples-based suicide-specific intervention–Treatment for Relationships and Safety Together (TR&ST) –and examine acceptability, feasibility and preliminary efficacy for a larger Randomized Controlled Trial. This Career Development Award is the first step toward developing a vital program of research within VHA focused on enhancing interpersonal functioning and suicide related care by involving family members in treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The cerebellum receives sensory information, makes short-term predictions, and coordinates movements; its dysfunction can contribute to ataxia, dystonia, dyslexia, and autism spectrum disorders. The sensory input from the environment is received by Purkinje neurons in the cerebellum, which process and transmit it to neurons in the cerebellar nuclei, which further integrate the information with additional sensory signals and then send it to brain regions that control the timing and sequencing of behaviors. In the current application, we propose to study how neural signals are transformed as they are transmitted from Purkinje neurons to neurons in the cerebellar nuclei, and what aspects of signaling change under pathological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The current opioid crisis has been driven in part by abuse of prescription opioid painkillers. The current proposal will investigate the ability of a novel series of compounds called kappa opioid agonists with unique signaling and behavioral profiles to decrease the abuse-related effects of oxycodone without introducing new side effects. The results of this drug-discovery phase proposal will provide foundational work that could lead to dual-acting compounds and/or drug-combination formulations for the treatment of pain without the burden of abuse liability.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 258,000 Veterans with serious mental illness receive VA services. Over 60% of these Veterans have a service-connected disability that impairs their ability to work, go to school, and/or have successful personal lives. Increasing positive outcomes for these Veterans is essential, and requires improving their ability to work with VA providers to achieve their individually identified treatment goals. Veterans with serious mental illness often struggle to communicate effectively, impairing their ability to have their voices heard during treatment appointments. This project will adapt and evaluate a group-based decision-making intervention that targets skill sets that Veterans need to communicate more effectively with providers. Findings from this study will offer useful information about Veteran-provider communication in general, and the decision-making intervention in particular. If the decision-making intervention is effective, it would help Veterans with serious mental illness, and might also help Veterans with other chronic health conditions, like PTSD and chronic pain.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The purpose of the next phase of this epidemiologic project known as “Noise Outcomes In Service members Epidemiology Study 3.0” (NOISE Study 3.0) is to gather information from Veterans recently separated from military service, and active duty Service members, about their military and non-military noise exposures, other relevant military and non-military exposures (e.g., ototoxicants, bombs/blasts, TBIs), tinnitus, hearing loss, and other hearing-related health concerns. Over 1,000 participants have completed baseline testing, and participants complete annual follow-up assessments. The proposed study will continue this longitudinal study and expands the test battery to add behavioral and electrophysiologic measures to test the integrity of multiple stages of auditory processing. The goals of NOISE Study 3.0 are relevant to the VA as they pertain entirely to Veterans' current and future health care needs. This research will offer unparalleled insight into the hearing health of Veterans, informing prevention, intervention, and rehabilitation efforts at the VA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of the proposed research is to develop a platform to mechanistically examine genetic modifiers of PD in patient-derived neurons, microglia and astrocytes. We hypothesize that these glial cells normally offer protection to neurons, and we proposed to examine how this protection becomes harmful in PD. We will focus on GBA1-PD but the main idea was to develop these novel experimental approaches as a platform for other studies in PD, as well neurodegeneration more broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Malaria burden reduction and malaria elimination require an evidence-based approach to quantifying the ecology of mosquitoes, human-mosquito interactions, and residual transmission. The idiosyncratic challenges facing vector control are best addressed through adaptive vector control, which combines elements of integrated vector control and adaptive management. We propose to develop adaptive vector control, in partnership with the Bioko Island Malaria Elimination Program, to quantify residual transmission and spatially target vector control in the urban context of Malabo, Bioko Island, Equatorial Guinea.

PHR: The overall study goal is to determine whether early postnatal factors can counteract the adverse influences of maternal gestational diabetes during fetal life, and ultimately have lasting benefits on future metabolic health of the child. This study will provide new insights on early postnatal factors (breastfeeding, infant diet including sugar-sweetened beverages, sleep, and temperament) specifically for this high-risk group of children exposed to gestational diabetes, and the ability of these factors to reduce their future risk of obesity and type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain edema is a devastating process affecting millions of people; yet, there is no cure- it remains a fundamental cause of death and disability in TBI and many other diseases, costing billions of dollars. Given the complex network of pathways contributing to brain edema, compounded by individual variation, it is inevitable that current non-specific therapies are unsuccessful at improving outcomes- harnessing patient differences to direct precision medicine is imperative for effective treatment. This translational work seeks to address this major deficiency: by evaluating effects of individual differences and targeted treatment on edema subtypes in a key pathway of TBI edema (Sur1-Trpm4), it aims to provide clinicians and researchers with a sophisticated toolkit to identify and stratify patients at risk, target the intervention, prognosticate, and optimize clinical trial design, thus directly advancing precision medicine-based care and the NINDS mission to reduce the burden of neurological disease.
